summary: Paul Merson and Andros Townsend are engaged in a back-and-forth argument.  Merson initially criticized Townsend's inclusion in the England team, stating that if Townsend could make the team, anyone could.  Townsend then scored an equalizer for England against Italy, prompting Merson to admit he was wrong.  However, Merson later criticized Townsend again for only playing seven minutes in Tottenham's 0-0 draw with Burnley.

Chelsea has made a formal offer to acquire 22-year-old FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto.  If the transfer is completed, Muto will be loaned to Chelsea’s partner club, Vitesse Arnhem, for the next season.  Muto, who recently graduated from Keio University with an economics degree, has 11 international caps for Japan and scored 16 goals in 37 appearances for FC Tokyo.  While he is honored by the offer, Muto has not yet decided whether to join Chelsea.  The deal is rumored to be around £4 million, and is unrelated to Chelsea’s sponsorship deal with Yokohama Rubber.

A large-scale study in Finland found that babies given antibiotics in their first six months of life are more likely to be overweight toddlers.  Researchers compared the weight and height of over 12,000 two-year-olds with their antibiotic prescription records.  One in five boys and one in ten girls were overweight or obese by age two; those who had taken antibiotics as babies were especially likely to be overweight.  While the study doesn't prove causation, it suggests that antibiotics may kill gut bacteria that normally process food, leading to weight gain.  The researchers warn that antibiotic use before six months of age or repeated use in infancy is associated with increased body mass and may contribute to the childhood obesity epidemic.

A Queen's Guard slipped on a manhole cover during the Changing of the Guard at Buckingham Palace.  The fall, which was caught on camera by a tourist, caused the guard to drop his rifle and his bearskin hat.  He quickly got up, but was visibly embarrassed by the incident in front of the large crowd.  The Ministry of Defence declined to comment.

A&E, Lifetime, and History networks will simulcast a remake of the 1977 miniseries "Roots" in 2016.  The new miniseries will be more closely based on Alex Haley's novel and will include input from scholars of African and African-American history.  LeVar Burton, who played Kunta Kinte in the original, will co-executive produce.  The remake aims to introduce the story to a new generation.

Christopher Lawler, a former royal footman, claims that on his first day working at Clarence House in January 1978, he was pinned to a chair and groped by male staff members who tried to force him into an orgy.  He reported the incident to Clarence House at the time but his complaint was ignored.  After learning of an investigation into historical child abuse, he contacted the Palace again last year.  The police are now investigating.

Oregon couple Jesse and Melissa Meek announced their pregnancy in a YouTube video that parodies the theme song from the 90s sitcom *The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air*.  The video, which has over 1.7 million views, shows the couple rapping about their journey to parenthood.  They conceived faster than expected and shared a sonogram at the video's end.  The couple filmed five takes and are considering another video after learning the baby's gender.  They made the video to share the news with distant loved ones, and its popularity was unexpected.  Jesse is a descendant of Oregon pioneer Joseph Lafayette Meek.

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh in the film *Gone With the Wind* sold for $137,000 at auction.  The gray jacket and skirt ensemble, originally slate blue-gray, was worn in several key scenes.  The dress was among over 150 items from the film's private collection of James Tumblin, a former Universal Studios employee who acquired it for $20.  Other auction highlights included a Leigh hat ($52,500), Gable's suit ($55,000), and a bonnet worn by Leigh and Olivia De Havilland ($30,000).  *Gone With the Wind*, celebrating its 75th anniversary last year, is based on Margaret Mitchell's novel.

A two-year-old boy fell 10-12 feet into a cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after his mother dangled him over the edge.  His parents rescued him before emergency personnel arrived. The boy sustained minor injuries and is in stable condition.  The cheetahs did not attack him.  Zoo officials plan to file child endangerment charges against the parents.

A speed camera in Birmingham, West Midlands, that has been non-operational for two years, is now pointed at a residential house.  Approximately 300 cameras were deactivated in March 2013 due to obsolete technology.  Birmingham City Council is aware of the situation and will investigate, potentially removing the camera.  The camera will not be included in a planned pilot program using updated technology.

Usain Bolt will compete in the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas for Jamaica on May 2 and 3.  Bolt stated that he is fit and ready to run, adding that he aims to make his country proud.  The full Jamaican team roster will be released soon.  JAAA General Secretary Garth Gayle expressed his excitement over Bolt's participation.

Neymar and Dani Alves showed their support for Barcelona's basketball team by attending their Euroleague game against Real Madrid, which Barcelona won 85-80.  Despite the win, Real Madrid remains atop their division by a small margin.  Neymar also recently led Brazil to a 1-0 victory over Chile.  Barcelona's next La Liga match is against Celta Vigo.

From Friday to Monday, 8,480 migrants were rescued by the Italian Coast Guard.  The Italian Coast Guard received SOS calls from 20 boats in distress on Monday alone.  Save the Children fears 400 migrants are missing after a ship carrying 550 capsized, though the Coast Guard has not confirmed this. Over 10,000 migrants arrived in Italy during the first three months of 2015, with about 2,000 rescued at sea during the first weekend of April.  At least 480 migrants have died crossing the Mediterranean this year due to bad weather and overcrowded vessels.

Alexis Sanchez chose Arsenal over other clubs, including Liverpool, to continue his football career.  Arsene Wenger doesn't know the exact reason for Sanchez's decision but is happy he joined Arsenal.  Liverpool's interest in Sanchez may have been used as leverage in negotiations for Luis Suarez's transfer to Barcelona. Sanchez has quickly adapted to Arsenal and is a top player, scoring 19 goals this season. Wenger also played down speculation of Arsenal's interest in Liverpool's Raheem Sterling.

Sir Bradley Wiggins will attempt to break the cycling hour record on June 7th at London's Olympic Velodrome.  The current record is 52.491 km, set by Rohan Dennis.  Wiggins' attempt will be broadcast live on Sky Sports, and tickets go on sale April 19th.  He will be aiming for his eighth Olympic medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics.

In the Fed Cup, Serena Williams overcame Sara Errani in a hard-fought match, winning 4-6 7-6(3) 6-3, despite feeling unprepared for the clay court.  The US team, however, lost the tie 3-2, dropping to World Group II.  Williams acknowledged needing improvement for the clay court season, while US captain Mary Joe Fernandez expressed determination to return to the elite group next year.

River Plate is interested in signing Radamel Falcao, who previously played for them from 2001-2009.  River Plate vice president Matias Patanian stated that they “dream of Falcao” and that “the doors are open”.  However, a deal is complicated because Falcao is currently on loan at Manchester United, where he has scored only four Premier League goals this season.  Falcao’s future depends on whether Manchester United will keep him or if he will return to Monaco.  Despite his struggles at Manchester United, Falcao recently scored three goals in two games for his country, tying the all-time Colombia goal scoring record with 24 goals.  During his time at River Plate, Falcao scored 34 goals in 90 appearances.

Ella Henderson, a 2012 X Factor finalist, is the face of Batiste's 2015 "Ready For It" campaign.  This is her first brand collaboration.  The campaign features various hairstyles and will include a TV advertisement using her single, "Mirror Man."  The partnership was facilitated by MILES agency.  Henderson uses Batiste and is excited about the collaboration.  Her management sees this as a great match between a respected brand and a talented artist.

A billboard in Kenosha, Wisconsin, featuring police officer Pablo Torres, who fatally shot Aaron Siler on March 14, has sparked outrage among Siler’s family and friends.  The billboard, paid for by the Kenosha Professional Police Association, thanked the community for its support.  Siler, who had an active felony warrant, was shot after a vehicle and foot pursuit during which he armed himself with a weapon.  Torres is currently on leave pending investigations into this shooting and a previous shooting of a suicidal man ten days prior.  The investigation into the shooting of the suicidal man has been deemed justified, while the investigation into Siler’s death is ongoing.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in clashes with militants near the Pakistan border on Monday.  Three militants were also killed.  Jaish al Adal, a Sunni Muslim anti-Iranian group, claimed responsibility for the attack.  The group operates in Pakistan's Balochistan province and has conducted similar attacks in the past, including one in 2013 that killed 14 Iranian border guards.  Iran has asked Pakistan to apprehend the surviving militants, and Pakistan has condemned the attack and pledged to investigate.

Japan's Defense Minister Gen Nakatani stated that the country's Air Self Defense Force has never encountered a UFO.  This response was given to a query from politician Antonio Inoki, who has had a varied career including professional wrestling and  attempts at diplomacy.  Inoki also claims to have seen a UFO but admits uncertainty about the existence of aliens.  The topic of extraterrestrial visitors has been previously discussed by Japanese politicians, including the legal implications of an alien invasion.

Jin Pai, 35, was hospitalized with deep cuts to his leg and buttocks after a toilet he was squatting on in Hefei Xinqiao International Airport collapsed.  He was standing on the toilet rim because he did not want his bottom to touch the seat.  Airport officials believe the incident was an accident, and police advise using the toilets as intended.

Kevin Rebbie, 56, of Limerick Township, Pennsylvania was arrested for filming a 15-year-old girl in her bathroom with a hidden camera over a 3-4 year period.  The girl also reported that Rebbie had been molesting her since she was 9 years old.  Police found 41 videos on Rebbie’s computer, 34 of which showed victims showering.  Rebbie admitted to filming the girl and other juveniles.  He is being held on $500,000 bail and faces charges including aggravated indecent assault, unlawful contact with a minor, sexual abuse of children and invasion of privacy.  His preliminary hearing is May 1.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama’s new series of photos depicts daughters smiling at the camera next to their fathers dramatically leaping in the air.  The photos, part of Aoyama’s book *Daughter and Salaryman*, show fathers in suits making energetic jumps, some appearing pained, while their daughters wear casual clothing.  The photos, taken at various Japanese landmarks, have gained online attention for their unusual nature.

Kevin Pietersen's potentially sensational return to the England cricket team is a step closer as he's rejoined Surrey.  While the dismissal of England's managing director, Paul Downton, is a major talking point,  Pietersen's jovial mood at the Surrey team photo shoot contrasts with his thoughtful reflection on his possible return to the international stage after being controversially axed in 2014.  Surrey's season begins April 19th against Glamorgan.

Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt fired and rehired Brazilian coach Ze Maria within one week.  After a 2-0 loss to FC Botosani, he was fired a second time.  The team is currently 16th in the standings, six points from safety.  Ze Maria's replacement is Serbian Vanya Radinovic.

Radamel Falcao's former Monaco teammate, Nabil Dirar, believes Falcao regrets his unsuccessful loan move to Manchester United.  Despite being unhappy in France, Dirar thinks Falcao would have been better off staying at Monaco, where he would have played and participated in the Champions League.  Falcao's Manchester United loan has seen him score only four goals this season, making a permanent transfer unlikely due to the high cost.

A very tall man wearing a distinctive cartoon mask robbed a Christchurch dairy on Saturday.  He was wearing a fluoro orange sweatshirt and stole the till and approximately $1500 in cash.  Police are asking for the public’s help in identifying him.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old Texas math teacher, was arrested for a second time on Monday.  She is accused of having sex with a 15-year-old student on two consecutive nights in January. This follows a previous arrest on March 19th for an inappropriate relationship with another 15-year-old student, where she admitted to kissing the student and allowing him to touch her breasts.  Granado was released on a $50,000 bail.  The Irving school district says they took immediate action and placed her on administrative leave.

A video of a crocodile with a dead dog in its mouth has received over 500,000 views.  The incident occurred in the Puerto Vallarta marina in Mexico.  A tourist, Tim Weston, witnessed the event and reported that the crocodile held the dog for hours.  The dog belonged to a local bike shop owner.  Weston noted that a crocodile sanctuary is located nearby.  Social media users reacted with horror to the video.  American crocodiles in the area can grow up to 6 meters long and are increasingly interacting with humans due to urbanization.

Despite a 2-0 loss to Southampton, Hull City manager Steve Bruce remains confident that his team can avoid relegation from the Premier League.  While their initial goal of 10 wins to ensure survival is unlikely, Bruce believes 8-9 wins might suffice.  Hull's struggles are attributed to significant injuries to key players.  Despite upcoming difficult matches, Bruce is positive they can secure the necessary wins to stay in the Premier League.

Ian Guffick, a teacher at Mitton Manor Primary School, allowed students to change their answers after the completion of the SATs exams.  He also altered answers himself.  This resulted in an investigation, the annulment of all the school's SATs results, and Guffick's dismissal.  A panel found his conduct unacceptable but not fraudulent.  He was banned from teaching for at least two years, with the option to appeal.

Anders Lindegaard, Manchester United goalkeeper,  married Swedish model Misse Beqiri in Mauritius last year.  The couple, who have a son together and have been dating since 2012, enjoyed a day off together.  Despite Lindegaard's limited playing time with Manchester United since 2010, he is reportedly happy with his wife and family.

Thirteen letters from Yankee Stadium, expected to sell for $300,000-$600,000, failed to receive any bids at a Sotheby's auction except for a $260,000 bid from a Sotheby's employee.  Reggie Jackson, the current owner, had hoped a new generation would enjoy them.  He purchased them in 2008 after the stadium's final game.  The letters were installed in 1976 and removed in 2008.  In contrast, a New York Mets bullpen car, estimated at $20,000-$30,000, sold for $112,500.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers addressed the recent off-field behavior of Raheem Sterling and Jordan Ibe, involving nitrous oxide and shisha pipes.  While speaking to them, Rodgers emphasized their professional responsibilities as elite athletes.  He chose not to discipline them, wanting to move past the incidents.  Rodgers also commented on Liverpool's near misses in recent competitions, viewing them as part of a learning process.  He will decide whether to reinstate Steven Gerrard, who is available after suspension, for the upcoming FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa.

Mesut Ozil, Arsenal’s German star, returned to London after a successful international match where Germany beat Georgia 2-0.  He posted a picture of himself with his dog, captioned “Home Sweet Home,” showcasing his downtime.  Ozil, who had been ill and missed Arsenal’s last game, is expected to play against Liverpool.  He’s been in good form since recovering from an injury, scoring three goals and providing four assists since January.  Ozil also stated that he is adjusting well to English football, enjoying the frequent matches.

Barcelona president Josep Maria Bartomeu stated that Luis Enrique will not be replaced and that the club is very happy with his performance.  Enrique signed a two-year contract last summer and is six games away from winning the La Liga title.  Bartomeu was impressed by Enrique's work ethic, citing his preparation for the Valencia game after the Champions League match against PSG.  Barcelona is pleased with Enrique because they are still in contention for three trophies.

Liverpool's vice-captain, Jordan Henderson, has agreed to a new long-term contract with improved terms of around £100,000 per week, running until 2020.  This follows contract extensions for Sturridge and Coutinho.  Henderson, signed in 2011, has significantly improved under Rodgers and is a candidate to replace Gerrard as captain.  Discussions with Raheem Sterling regarding his contract will resume at the end of the season.

Filipe Luis, despite interest from Atletico Madrid, wants to fulfill his three-year contract with Chelsea.  Although he hasn't solidified a starting position, he is happy in London.  His focus now shifts to Chelsea's Premier League title run, with manager Jose Mourinho demanding continued focus to win their remaining nine difficult matches.

Nathan Hughes’ three-match suspension was overturned on appeal.  Hughes was initially banned for a March 27 incident where his knee collided with George North’s head, knocking North unconscious.  Although the collision was deemed accidental, the initial disciplinary panel ruled Hughes’ actions reckless.  The appeal panel overturned the ban, citing new evidence and concluding that no foul play occurred.  Hughes missed a match due to the suspension but is now free to return to play.

Wildfires in southeastern Siberia caused stunning sunsets in the Pacific Northwest.  Farmers burning fields started the fires, which spread rapidly due to strong winds, destroying dozens of villages.  The smoke traveled across the Pacific Ocean, resulting in vibrant red sunsets from the smoke particles filtering out shorter wavelengths of light.  As the smoke dissipates, the sunsets will return to normal.

Becky Schoenig of St. Louis, Missouri had her brand new 2015 Ford Fusion stolen.  On April 1st, police recovered her car, which had been modified with red rims, red detailing, and orange accents on the steering wheel.  Schoenig reacted with humor on Facebook, and is now having the car professionally cleaned due to lingering smells of cigarettes and marijuana.  She is also creating a smoothie at her restaurant to honor the man who helped locate her vehicle.

Manchester City players face losing £500,000 each in bonuses if they don't qualify for the Champions League.  Their incentivised contracts, designed to comply with financial fair play rules, mean the squad stands to lose approximately £12 million total if they fail to reach the group stages.  Currently in fourth place, four points ahead of Liverpool, City must secure a top-four finish to avoid a qualifying round.  Their manager admits their season has deteriorated significantly since the start of 2015, with seven losses including early exits from the FA Cup and Champions League.  Their poor performance impacts their ability to attract top players like Paul Pogba, who is also sought by Manchester United.

Manchester United's Under 18 team beat Manchester City's Under 18 team by a score of 1-0 in a match held at Altrincham's stadium.  Callum Gribbin scored the winning goal with a free kick.  The match was notable for its high skill level and the number of local players involved.  The win puts Manchester United two points behind league leader Middlesbrough.  Manchester City, hampered by injuries, lost both playoff matches.

In a 1-1 draw with Italy, Joe Hart earned his 50th cap while Gianluigi Buffon earned his 147th. Hart called Buffon a legend and an inspiration, citing his impressive career at age 37 as something to aspire to.  Hart expressed his pride in his 50th cap and his desire to continue playing for his club and country.

Chipotle Mexican restaurants will partner with Postmates app to deliver food to customers in 67 cities.  A nine percent service charge will be added to orders, with Postmates delivery fees starting at $5.  Other companies such as Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald's, and Burger King are also hoping to profit from the $70 billion food delivery market.  Recently, both Hillary Clinton and Marco Rubio were seen at Chipotle restaurants.

The parents of Martin Richard, an 8-year-old victim of the Boston Marathon bombing, are pleading with the Justice Department to drop the death penalty for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the man convicted of the crime.  They believe that taking the death penalty off the table, in exchange for life in prison without parole and a waiver of Tsarnaev's appeal rights, will bring closure and end the prolonged reliving of the tragedy for their family and the country.  The Richards' daughter was also severely injured in the bombing.  They acknowledge the heinous nature of the crime but feel that years of appeals would only prolong their suffering.

A mystery billionaire spent £400 million customizing a Boeing 747, which once held 600 passengers, into a luxury private jet.  The three-year project included building bedrooms, multiple lounges, a dining room with an adjoining kitchen, and an "aeroloft" with eight beds.  The plane also features a conference room and can accommodate dozens of guests.

SpaceX launched a Falcon 9 rocket carrying a Dragon cargo spacecraft to the International Space Station.  The rocket's landing on a drone ship was unsuccessful, though the launch itself and Dragon's journey to the space station were successful.  SpaceX aims to reuse rockets to reduce space access costs.  The Dragon will deliver supplies to the space station and return with experiments and trash. This was SpaceX's sixth mission to the ISS and second launch attempt.

Priscilla Presley will be a witness at the first wedding held at the new Elvis Presley’s Graceland Wedding Chapel inside the Westgate Hotel in Las Vegas on April 23.  A contest is being held for one Elvis-obsessed couple to win the wedding, which includes a reception, two-night hotel stay, airfare, and concert tickets.  Priscilla emphasized that this is a first-class event, not a joke, and no Elvis impersonators are allowed.  The chapel is part of the first permanent Graceland exhibit outside of Memphis.  Couples must submit videos or photos to enter the contest.

Liverpool beat Newcastle 2-0 on Monday, with goals from Raheem Sterling and Joe Allen.  Jordan Henderson and Simon Mignolet played their 47th game of the season, tying the record for appearances in the top five European leagues.  Despite recent losses, Henderson believes Liverpool can catch Manchester City, who are four points ahead in the Premier League.

Roma defeated Napoli in a Serie A match on Saturday, ending a four-month home winless streak.  Miralem Pjanic scored in the 25th minute, and Morgan de Sanctis's goalkeeping secured the victory.  The win put Roma provisionally four points ahead of Lazio.  Napoli's winless streak extended to five matches.  Security was tight due to a previous incident, but the match proceeded without incident.  Roma played without injured players Francesco Totti and Gervinho.

Doncaster Rovers played Fleetwood Town in a League One match that ended in a 0-0 draw.  The game lacked excitement, leading to a very short, 27-second highlight reel posted on the club's YouTube channel.  The highlight reel only contained 14 seconds of actual match action.

Roland Giroux has a unique bond with his blood parrot cichlid.  He massages the fish daily for 15 minutes, and the fish actively seeks out this interaction, even following Giroux’s hand to the surface when he removes it from the tank.  Giroux, who posts videos of his fish online, explains that he had to remove the cichlid’s tank mates due to bullying, and that hand-feeding led to a closer relationship.  The blood parrot cichlid, a hybrid first bred in Taiwan around 1986, shows signs of enjoyment during these interactions.

Ben Stokes, a fiery but talented cricketer, rejoined the England team after a year of ups and downs, including a wrist injury from punching a locker.  His clash with Marlon Samuels was addressed positively after a talk with coach Peter Moores.  While his aggression needs managing to avoid being pigeonholed, his exuberance is valuable and should be nurtured. England aims to utilize Stokes and Chris Jordan as much as possible to help them develop into top international players.

Wales and Belgium will play in a qualifying match for Euro 2016 on June 12th at the Cardiff City Stadium.  All 33,000 tickets have sold out.  Both teams have 11 points; Belgium is ranked higher due to goal difference.  Wales' recent 3-0 victory over Israel has increased anticipation for the match.  The team prefers the Cardiff City Stadium to the Millennium Stadium due to its more intimate atmosphere.

England's Under-17 team, the defending champions, will play in the UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria next month.  They are in Group D with Italy, Holland, and the Republic of Ireland, opening against Italy on May 7th.  The squad includes players from various Premier League clubs, with notable call-ups for Chris Willock (Arsenal) and the return of Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold (Liverpool).

Manchester City is looking to sign 14-year-old Anderlecht playmaker Evangelos Patoulidis, a highly touted talent who previously rejected Barcelona's offer.  City has spoken with Anderlecht's chairman to negotiate a compensation package.

Vanessa Santillan, a 33-year-old transgender escort from Mexico, was found dead in her Fulham flat at the end of March.  She had been strangled and beaten. A 23-year-old man was arrested and bailed in connection with her death.  Police are appealing for information from anyone who had contact with Santillan in the hours before her death.

Dawn, who has had seven miscarriages, appeared on *The Jeremy Kyle Show* to confront her friend Jamie, who stole £207 that was intended for her son Daniel James’s gravestone.  A lie detector test confirmed Jamie’s guilt, causing Dawn to become distraught and leave the show.  Jamie had previously been imprisoned for burglary.

On Wednesday, ISIS released over 200 Yazidis (mostly women, children, elderly, and ill) in northern Iraq.  Arab tribal leaders assisted in the release, though the motivation remains unclear. The freed Yazidis were taken to Irbil by the Peshmerga.  This follows previous releases of Yazidi children and the elderly since ISIS’s attacks last summer, which caused a humanitarian crisis and displacement of hundreds of thousands of minorities.  The Yazidi people, of Kurdish descent, practice a pre-Islamic religion and have a history of persecution. ISIS’s actions against them have been exceptionally cruel, including mass killings, rape, and enslavement.  An international coalition responded with aid, rescues, and airstrikes against ISIS.

Harry Kane, a Tottenham striker, is nominated for the PFA Player and Young Player of the Season awards.  A Copa90 animation highlights his best goals and celebrations this season, including his long-range goal against Chelsea, a headed goal against Arsenal, and his England debut goal.  The animation is titled 'Harry Kane - PFA Player of the Year?' and was released before the awards ceremony on Sunday.

Jamie Carragher supports Brendan Rodgers remaining Liverpool’s manager despite the team’s third consecutive trophyless season and likely finish outside the top four.  Carragher believes Rodgers should be judged beyond one game and that the team needs to improve player integration and make the right signings to succeed next season.  Carragher also received a Beacon Award for his community work.

Four-year-old James Hayward’s toy gun was confiscated at East Midlands Airport by security.  His father called the security staff “over-zealous,” and said the pat-down and confiscation of the toy were “ludicrous.”  The airport apologized for the inconvenience but stated that regulations prohibit items resembling prohibited items, and that they offered to return the toy.  James received a replacement toy gun after returning from his family’s trip.

A 31-year-old man in Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, Australia, posted a Gumtree ad seeking a girlfriend/wife.  He describes himself as athletic, tattooed, and financially successful, and offers a generous compensation package including a car, phone, laptop, and gym membership.  His requirements for a partner include being fit, attractive, reliable, honest, loyal, a good cook, handy, and comfortable both outdoors and indoors.  He prefers a non-drinker and non-smoker.

Greg Dyke, FA chairman, is pushing for radical changes to increase the number of homegrown players in club squads from eight to twelve, facing opposition from the Premier League.  His proposals include changing the definition of "homegrown" to three years' training in England before age 18.  Five former England managers support Dyke, warning that blocking the proposals risks England falling behind other football nations.  They cite the low percentage of English players in Premier League starting lineups and emphasize the need for more opportunities for young English talent.

Demelza Poldark, played by Eleanor Tomlinson, gives birth to her baby daughter in the next episode of *Poldark*.  The timeline of the pregnancy is unrealistic; the announcement of the pregnancy and the birth happen within a short time frame.  Ross Poldark, played by Aidan Turner, is shown to love his wife and new daughter.  Fans have commented on the show's fast-paced pregnancies on social media.

Leicester City, three points from safety, plays Swansea on Saturday.  After back-to-back wins, including a last-minute victory against West Brom, manager Nigel Pearson cautions against overconfidence and urges the team to focus on their own performance, not their rivals.  He emphasizes that Leicester's fate is in their own hands.

A North Pacific gray whale named Varvara swam approximately 14,000 miles, breaking the record for the longest mammal migration ever recorded.  Varvara's journey from her feeding grounds off Russia’s Sakhalin Island to Baja, Mexico, surpassed the previous record of 10,190 miles set by a humpback whale.  This long migration, encompassing three major breeding areas for eastern gray whales, suggests Varvara may be an eastern gray whale, rather than the endangered western gray whale she was initially believed to be.  This discovery may require a reevaluation of the number of western gray whales, currently estimated at only 150.

On the Shiretoko Peninsula near Rausu, Hokkaido Island, Japan, 1,000–1,640 feet of seabed rose as high as 50 feet above sea level.  Geologists attribute this to a nearby landslide caused by melting ice and snow.  The newly emerged landmass is roughly 100 feet wide, and local residents reported no tremors or sounds preceding the event.  Authorities believe the event is unrelated to the recent earthquake in Kathmandu.

Gregory van der Wiel, a Paris Saint-Germain player, denied rumors of him leaving the club, stating that he loves the club, city, and his teammates.  He recently had a disagreement with manager Laurent Blanc after being dropped from a Champions League game but insists he wants to stay and sign a new contract.  However, PSG is also linked to Dani Alves, which may impact Van der Wiel's future.

Carlos Tevez wants to leave Juventus before his contract expires in 2016 to return to his first club, Boca Juniors.  Boca Juniors has confirmed that they are close to finalizing a deal, but Tevez must first terminate his contract with Juventus.  Juventus, while reluctant to lose their top scorer (Tevez scored 17 goals this season), has accepted his decision and is seeking replacements.  Tevez's international manager stated that the move would not affect Tevez's position on the Argentinian national team.

During a Champions League match between Bayern Munich and Porto, Bayern Munich manager Pep Guardiola ripped his trousers, revealing his underwear.  Bayern Munich won the match 6-1, advancing to the Champions League semi-finals.

A multi-vehicle crash on Brisbane Valley Highway, 2km south of Fernvale, involved ten people, including four children.  A 40-year-old man and a five-year-old boy (chest injuries/pain) were airlifted to Princess Alexandra Hospital, followed by a 27-year-old woman (arm injuries) and a six-year-old girl (abdominal pain). Six others were transported to Ipswich Hospital with minor injuries.  The highway was closed for several hours.

Arsenal plays Chelsea this Sunday at 4pm.  Arsenal player Mesut Ozil received a new Apple Watch and shared his excitement on Instagram, comparing it to Michael Knight’s watch from Knight Rider.  Arsenal trails Chelsea by 10 points with six games left in the season, but the return of Jack Wilshere has boosted the team.  Ray Parlour believes Wilshere has great potential but his fitness is a concern.

Referee Mark Clattenburg will officiate the Manchester derby between Manchester United and Manchester City at Old Trafford.  Despite having sent off three players from both teams this season (two from Manchester United and one from Manchester City), Clattenburg will be joined by assistants Simon Beck and Jake Collin, with Jonathan Moss as the fourth official.  The match is highly anticipated as it could determine which team finishes second in the league.

Bob Katter, a federal MP for Kennedy, released a statement accusing the Queensland Government of believing Billy Gordon, an embattled MP, was “a little black puppet on a string,” implying the government assumed Gordon would resign after accusations of domestic violence.  Katter, who is of Lebanese descent, stated that he has faced racism from both major parties and sympathizes with Gordon.  His statement sparked social media criticism over his terminology, but Katter defended it, citing his own experiences with racism.  He used the examples of federal MPs Tony Windsor and Rob Oakeshott to illustrate how independents can become puppets for the government, but asserted Gordon would not.

Dayna Dobias, a 19-year-old from Downers Grove, Illinois, was born with cerebral palsy.  She creates videos of herself dancing to challenge stereotypes about disability and inspire others.  Dobias says she has faced bullying and stares because of her disability, but she wants to show people that having cerebral palsy doesn't prevent her from living a full life—she drives, attends college, and even does motivational speaking at local schools.

Manchester United's Javier Hernandez is desired by Orlando City, who have a large Latin-American fan base.  Hernandez had a difficult loan period with Real Madrid.  Other clubs interested in Hernandez include eight European teams, Southampton, Stoke, West Ham, and Everton.  Manchester United wants approximately £8 million for Hernandez.  Meanwhile, Manchester United offered a revised contract to Andreas Pereira, who has also attracted interest from Paris St Germain, Juventus, PSV Eindhoven, and Feyenoord.

Early Saturday morning at approximately 12:15 am, a group of at least three suspects approached a white Dodge Charger at a 76 gas station in South Los Angeles.  An argument ensued, after which the suspects attempted to carjack the driver. When this failed, they poured gasoline on the vehicle and set it ablaze.  The driver and two passengers escaped unharmed, but the car was destroyed. The Los Angeles County Fire Department is investigating the incident as arson, and the suspects are still at large.

Charles Manuel, a chiropractor from Lamoni, Iowa, surrendered his license after admitting to trading services for sex and performing exorcisms on patients.  Despite this, he had perfect five-star patient satisfaction ratings on HealthGrades.com based on three reviews.  He cannot reapply for his license for at least 10 years.

The U.S. is complaining to Moscow about a Russian SU-27 fighter jet intercepting a U.S. RC-135U reconnaissance plane in international airspace over the Baltic Sea on Tuesday.  The U.S. deemed the Russian pilot’s actions unsafe and unprofessional due to aggressive maneuvers. Russia claims the U.S. plane’s transponder was off, a claim the U.S. denies.  This is not the first such incident; a similar incident occurred a year prior over the Sea of Okhotsk.

An FBI agent's sniper rifle was stolen from his car in the parking lot of the Marriott Springhill Suites in Salt Lake City.  The thief broke the car window, used a rope and another vehicle to remove the rifle case from its locks, and then escaped with the rifle, along with the agent's gear bag, backpack, clothing, and tools.  The theft occurred the week before President Obama's visit to Utah.  While some of the agent's belongings were recovered, the rifle has not been found.  The hotel lacked surveillance cameras.

71-year-old Luigi Costa is accused of murdering his neighbor, Terrence Freebody, in July 2012, by stomping on his head, slitting his throat, and stabbing him multiple times.  A forensic psychiatrist, Professor Paul Mullen, testified that Costa's mental state was compromised by dementia and alcohol abuse at the time of the murder.  The prosecution disputes the claim that Costa's memory loss was feigned.  The jury will consider Costa's mental state in determining guilt or innocence.

Ross Barkley missed a penalty kick in Everton's 1-0 win against Burnley, despite Leighton Baines's success rate of 15 out of 16 penalty kicks in the Premier League.  Manager Roberto Martinez defended Barkley's decision, stating that he allows several players to take penalties depending on how they feel.  Although Barkley's penalty was saved, Mirallas scored the winning goal.

On Thursday, at 11:30 a.m., two passengers were found dead in their stateroom aboard the ms Ryndam, a Holland America Line cruise ship.  The ship was in San Juan, Puerto Rico, at the time, having departed from Tampa, Florida on March 29th.  Authorities, including the FBI, are investigating and believe the deaths may be a murder-suicide.  The bodies were discovered by the ship's cleaning staff.

Patrick Kluivert, former Holland forward and assistant coach, led Curacao to victory in the first round of 2018 World Cup qualifying.  Curacao drew 2-2 with Montserrat in the second leg, winning 4-3 on aggregate after a 2-1 win in the first leg.  Charlton Vicento's 87th-minute goal secured the victory.  Curacao will next face Cuba on June 8th and 16th.

Esteban Cambiasso, a key Leicester City player, believes that keeping Leicester City in the Premier League would be just as rewarding as winning a major trophy, like the 15 he won in his career at Inter Milan.  Despite Leicester City being seven points from safety with eight games left, Cambiasso is confident they can avoid relegation.  He is happy in Leicester and might stay beyond his one-year contract.

A 23-year-old mother of two, Gemma, is at risk of being banned from seeing her children by her own mother, Debbie.  Gemma handed her two children to Debbie when they were four months old.  Debbie is threatening to ban Gemma because of her drinking, partying, use of the legal high MKat, and suspected theft (including an iPad).  Gemma admits to past theft from her mother but denies stealing the iPad.  Debbie, who has raised the children since they were infants, says Gemma is unfit to be a mother because she prioritizes partying over her children.

During a Chelsea-Manchester United match, Chelsea's John Terry made a strong challenge from behind on Manchester United's Radamel Falcao.  This resulted in a loose ball that led to Eden Hazard's goal for Chelsea.  However, Sky Sports pundits Thierry Henry, Jamie Redknapp, and Graeme Souness believed Terry's challenge was a foul that should have stopped play.  They cited Terry's elbow to Falcao's head as the reason.

On Thursday morning, Lady Antebellum singer Hillary Scott’s tour bus caught fire on Interstate 30 near Dallas.  Everyone on board—Scott, her husband, the tour manager, and the driver—safely evacuated after a tire blew out.  While the bus was destroyed, Scott salvaged her Bible.  Bandmates Charles Kelley and Dave Haywood were not on the bus.  The band is scheduled to perform at the ACM Awards on Sunday.

Dr. Adrian Quarterman of Dundee University is working on a space-based laser system that converts sunlight into energy via satellites equipped with mirrors and semiconductors.  This energy is then beamed to Earth, potentially providing solar power even in areas like Scotland and offering rapid power restoration to disaster zones.  While initial Scottish trials were successful, further trials will take place in Portugal.  The power of this laser is significantly less than what is depicted in science fiction; it is not powerful enough to be weaponized, unlike a separate proposal by Tokyo researchers to use lasers mounted on the ISS to remove space debris.  However, Dr. Quarterman acknowledges concerns about the control of his satellites.

54-year-old Stephen Munden, a convicted pedophile with a history of child sexual abuse and possession of indecent images of children, escaped from a psychiatric unit near Hook, Hampshire on Tuesday at 6:15 pm.  He is described as 5ft 8ins tall, heavy build, with dark hair, and may be clean-shaven.  Munden was detained under the Mental Health Act after being convicted of sexually assaulting a three-year-old girl on a bus.  Police are urging anyone with information on his whereabouts to contact them immediately.

V. Stiviano must return over \$2.6 million in gifts to Shelly Sterling after a Los Angeles judge ruled in Shelly Sterling's favor.  Shelly Sterling's lawsuit claimed Stiviano targeted wealthy older men, and that Donald Sterling used marital funds to purchase Stiviano lavish gifts including a Ferrari, two Bentleys, a Range Rover, and a \$1.8 million duplex.  The gifts also included more modest items such as an Easter bunny costume, a blender, and lingerie.  The ruling sets a legal precedent for injured spouses to recover damages from recipients of ill-gotten gifts.  The case follows Donald Sterling's ban from the NBA after a recording surfaced of him criticizing Stiviano for associating with African-Americans on social media.

Thierry Henry believes Arsenal needs to sign four players to win the Premier League title: a goalkeeper, center back, defensive midfielder, and striker.  He specifically cited Olivier Giroud's limitations as a striker, suggesting that Arsenal cannot win the league with him as their first choice.  Henry used Chelsea's recent success after acquiring Courtois, Matic, Fabregas, and Costa as an example of the necessary improvement.  Currently, Arsenal is third in the league, tied with Manchester City.

Maurice Van Ryn, the wealthy NSW businessman and Bega Cheese boss, pleaded guilty to 12 sex offenses, including persistent sexual abuse of a child.  One victim, a young woman, shared the severe impact of the abuse in court, stating that she is scared for her future relationships and didn’t understand why she was targeted.  She kept the abuse secret until she heard of his arrest, and since then has attempted suicide.  The hearing is ongoing.

Serge Gnabry, a 19-year-old Arsenal midfielder, is recovering from a serious knee injury that sidelined him for over a year.  He recently played 90 minutes in two games for the Arsenal Under 21s, and reports feeling “better and better,”  He is looking forward to his next game.

23-year-old Jacob Phillips died after falling 70 feet from a cliff in Penarth, South Wales.  He had fled a taxi to avoid paying the fare after a night out with friends.  The taxi driver said he would not have left Phillips if he had known the danger.  The coroner ruled the death accidental, stating Phillips likely became disoriented in the dark and unaware of the cliff edge.

Thousands of British holidaymakers did not receive compensation for passport delays last summer, despite the passport agency making a £42 million profit and managers receiving bonuses up to £3,500.  Only 2,191 compensation applications were approved (totaling £203,066), while ministers refused a blanket refund, citing the creation of a precedent.  Many people, like Mathew Bean and Hayley Kirkham, who lost money due to delays, were refused compensation.

A semi-detached home in Horfield, Bristol, untouched since the 1930s, is up for auction on April 30th.  The house features original stained-glass windows, oil-fired central heating, a mint-and-black bathroom, a wood-panelled hallway, vintage cupboards, and original 1930s tins of food.  Despite some upgrades (double glazing), the property's guide price is £200,000-£250,000.  Auctioneers believe the renovation costs might deter developers, making it ideal for antique enthusiasts.
Colin Kaepernick became the 49ers' starting quarterback in 2012 after Alex Smith suffered a concussion.  He led the team to the Super Bowl in 2013, where they lost to the Baltimore Ravens.
Soul Food is a 1997 American comedy-drama film produced by Kenneth "Babyface" Edmonds, Tracey Edmonds, and Robert Teitel and released by Fox 2000 Pictures.
Anne Rice, born in New Orleans, lived in Texas and San Francisco.  Route 495 is a 3.45 mile freeway in Hudson County, New Jersey, connecting the New Jersey Turnpike to NY 495 via the Lincoln Tunnel.
Telemundo is an American Spanish-language television network owned by Comcast through NBCUniversal.

Damon Albarn, raised in East London and Essex, formed the band Blur with Graham Coxon.  Blur's debut album *Leisure* was released in 1991.  Albarn's debut solo album, *Everyday Robots*, was released in 2014 and included collaborations with Brian Eno and Natasha Khan.
Mogadishu, also known as Hamar, is the capital and largest city of Somalia.  Many important national institutions are located there.
"Happiness in Slavery" is a song by Nine Inch Nails, featured on their 1992 EP, *Broken*.
Andrew Kevin Walker, born August 14, 1964, is an American screenwriter who has received a BAFTA nomination.

The 2007 film *Shooter*, starring Mark Wahlberg, depicts Force Recon veteran Bob Lee Swagger being framed for murder by a rogue private military company.  The TV series *Shooter*, starring Ryan Phillippe, features Swagger, a marksman in exile, who returns to action to stop a plot to assassinate the president.
*House, M.D.* is an American medical drama that aired on Fox for eight seasons, from November 16, 2004 to May 21, 2012.

Charles Manson was found guilty of first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder in 1971 for the deaths of seven people, including actress Sharon Tate.  He was also convicted of the murders of Gary Hinman and Donald “Shorty” Shea. Following his charges, recordings of his music were commercially released.

Sean Penn, born August 17, 1960, is an American actor, filmmaker, and political activist.  His career began with a television appearance in 1974, followed by his film debut in *Taps* (1981).  He gained critical acclaim for roles in films like *At Close Range*, *State of Grace*, and *Carlito's Way*.  Penn won two Academy Awards for Best Actor, one for *Mystic River* (2003) and another for *Milk* (2008).

Sir Donald George Bradman, also known as "The Don," was an Australian cricketer considered the greatest batsman of all time.  After retiring, he remained a significant figure in the sport for three decades as an administrator, selector, and writer.
L.A. Reid has been chairman and CEO of Epic Records (Sony Music Entertainment), president and CEO of Arista Records, and chairman and CEO of Island Def Jam Music Group.

Brad Wilk is best known for his drumming in Rage Against the Machine (1991-2000, 2007-2011) and Audioslave (2001-2007).  He began his career with Greta in 1990 and co-founded Rage Against the Machine.  In 2016, he was playing with Prophets of Rage.  A separate band, Rage, is a German heavy metal band formed in 1984.
The Millers, a multi-camera series on CBS, ran for two seasons (34 episodes) between October 3, 2013, and July 18, 2015.  CBS canceled the show on November 14, 2014, during its second season.

Ann Richards, the 45th Governor of Texas, served from 1991-1995.  Before that, she was the state treasurer and delivered the keynote address at the 1988 Democratic National Convention.  She was defeated in her reelection bid by George W. Bush in 1994.  Richards was known for her outspoken feminism.  There was also a jazz singer named Ann Richards who was married to Stan Kenton.
In 2011, Drake Bell independently released an EP titled *A Reminder*.

Stephen Verona wrote and directed the 1979 American drama film *Boardwalk*.  Janet Leigh, an American actress, singer, dancer, and author, is also mentioned.  She wrote four books between 1984 and 2002, including two novels.

Simón José Antonio de la Santísima Trinidad Bolívar y Palacios, known as El Libertador, was a Venezuelan military and political leader.  He played a key role in establishing Venezuela, Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, and Panama as sovereign states, independent from Spain.
The Bermuda Triangle, also called the Devil's Triangle, is a vaguely defined area in the western North Atlantic Ocean where many ships and aircraft have reportedly vanished mysteriously.
Colin Kaepernick became the starting quarterback for the 49ers in 2012, leading them to the Super Bowl that year and the NFC Championship in 2013.  He initially backed up Alex Smith.
"Marnie" is a 1964 American psychological thriller film directed by Alfred Hitchcock.

Advertising is a nonpersonal message used to promote a product, service, or idea through mass media such as print, broadcast, and digital channels.  It differs from personal selling in that it's not directed to a specific individual.
Noel Coward's 1930 play, *Private Lives*, was adapted into a 1931 American Pre-Code film directed by Sidney Franklin.

Maurice Harold Macmillan, the first Earl of Stockton, served as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from January 10, 1957 to October 19, 1963.  He was a British Conservative politician and statesman.

Aristotle, a Greek philosopher and scientist, was born in Stagira, Greece.  He attended Plato's Academy in Athens from age 17/18 to 37. After Plato's death, Aristotle tutored Alexander the Great beginning in 343 BC.

David Packouz, born February 16, 1982, is an American former arms dealer, musician, inventor, and entrepreneur.  He invented the BeatBuddy guitar pedal drum machine and is CEO of Singular Sound, a music technology company.

Magic Johnson played point guard for the Lakers for 13 seasons, winning 5 NBA championships and an NBA Finals MVP award.  He retired once, returned for 32 games, and then retired again.  In 2009, *Ebony* magazine named him one of America's most influential black businessmen; he also had various business interests and was a part-owner of the Lakers.

Tenacious D, an American comedy rock duo from Los Angeles, consists of Jack Black and Kyle Gass.  Formed in 1994, the band released three albums: *Tenacious D* (2001), *The Pick of Destiny* (2006), and *Rize of the Fenix* (2012).  They gained popularity in 1997 with their self-titled TV series.

James VI and I reigned as King of Scotland from July 24, 1567, and as King of England and Ireland from March 24, 1603, until his death on March 27, 1625.  Although Scotland and England remained separate states with their own governing bodies, James ruled both.  He desired a single parliament for both countries, succeeding mostly in Scotland but facing significant challenges in England, including the Gunpowder Plot and conflicts with Parliament.

Big Brother 2017 (also known as Big Brother 18) is the eighteenth series of the British reality television show.  Emma Willis hosts, and Marcus Bentley narrates.  Bentley has narrated the UK version of Big Brother since 2000.

The Free State of Saxony is a German federal state bordering Brandenburg, Saxony-Anhalt, Thuringia, Bavaria, Poland, and the Czech Republic.  It's the tenth largest German state by area (18,413 km2) and sixth most populous (4 million).  Its history spans over a millennium, and it's one of the northernmost wine regions in Europe.
East End Park, a former major league baseball park, is located in Cincinnati's East End neighborhood.  The song "In the End" was created by the American rock band Linkin Park.
Mel B. Brown's first solo single was "I Want You Back," a collaboration with Missy Elliott, released by Virgin Records.
Noah Cyrus is the youngest daughter of Billy Ray Cyrus and the younger sister of Miley and Trace Cyrus.

The Indian action thriller film *Mohra* (Pawn), directed by Rajiv Rai and released July 1, 1994, starred Akshay Kumar, Sunil Shetty, Raveena Tandon, and Naseeruddin Shah.  It was the second highest-grossing Indian film of 1994 and received nine Filmfare nominations in 1995.  Raveena Tandon replaced Divya Bharti in the lead female role after Bharti's death.  The film's songs were very popular.
"Hourglass" is a song by the British electronic duo Disclosure.  It is also the fourteenth studio album by singer-songwriter James Taylor.
Shane Black, born December 16, 1961, is an American screenwriter, director, producer, and actor.  He wrote the 1987 film *Lethal Weapon* and directed the 2005 film *Kiss Kiss Bang Bang*.
"A View to a Kill," released in 1985, is the 14th James Bond film and the last to feature Roger Moore as James Bond.

Papua, the largest and easternmost province of Indonesia, makes up most of western New Guinea.  Previously known as Irian Jaya (and before that, West Irian or Irian Barat), it once encompassed all of Indonesian New Guinea.
Augustus likely died of natural causes, though some rumored his wife Livia poisoned him.

Jennifer Lopez's career began with her 1999 debut album, *On the 6*.  In 2001, she simultaneously achieved a number-one album (*J.Lo*) and film (*The Wedding Planner*), a first for a woman.  Her relationship with Ben Affleck influenced her 2002 album, *This Is Me...Then*. After marrying Marc Anthony and experiencing some career setbacks, she returned to prominence in 2011 with her role on *American Idol* and the hit single, "On the Floor".

Working animals are usually domesticated and trained by humans to perform tasks.  These animals can be family members (like guide dogs) or used for pulling heavy loads (like draft horses).  They may also be used for milking or herding. Wild animals can sometimes be trained for work, but this is rare and usually for entertainment.

Billboard Dad is a 1998 American direct-to-video comedy film directed by Alan Metter and starring Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen.  Billboard magazine publishes the Top Latin Albums chart, the most important chart for Spanish-language albums in the American market, and the Regional Mexican Albums chart, a genre-specific weekly chart.

The 2010 Telugu Indian drama film, *Vedam* (English: Chant), was written and directed by Radhakrishna Jagarlamudi.  The film stars Allu Arjun, Manoj Manchu, Anushka Shetty, Manoj Bajpayee, Saranya Ponvannan, Deeksha Seth, Lekha Washington, and Siya Gautham.

Men in Black II, stylized as MIIB, is a 2002 American science fiction action comedy film.  The film stars Tommy Lee Jones, Will Smith, Lara Flynn Boyle, Johnny Knoxville, Rosario Dawson, Tony Shalhoub, and Rip Torn.
Sancho Panza, a character in Miguel de Cervantes' *Don Quixote* (1605), serves as Don Quixote's squire.  His commentary, known as "sanchismos," blends humor, ironic proverbs, and wit.
"The Adventures of Pluto Nash," a 2002 Australian-American film directed by Ron Underwood, is a science fiction action comedy starring Eddie Murphy in a dual role.
The world premiere of Hedda Gabler, by Henrik Ibsen, was held on January 31, 1891, at Munich's Residenztheater.  Ibsen himself attended.
Brazzers is a pornographic production company located in Montreal, Canada.
Timothy Simon Roth, born May 14, 1961, is an English actor and director.

Juventus Football Club, also known as Juve, is an Italian professional football club founded in Turin in 1897 by students, including its first president, Eugenio Canfari.  It is the second-oldest active football club in Italy, after Genoa.  Since 1903, its home kit has been black and white striped, and it currently plays in the 41,507-capacity Juventus Stadium.

Viola Davis played supporting and minor roles in various films and television shows from the late 1990s through the early 2000s.  Some examples include *Kate & Leopold* (2001), *Far from Heaven* (2002), and *Law & Order: Special Victims Unit*.

Jenna Jameson, born Jenna Marie Massoli on April 9, 1974, is an American entrepreneur and former pornographic film actress.  She began her career in erotic videos in 1993, after working as a stripper and glamour model.  She is known as one of the most famous adult entertainment performers.
The New Orleans Pelicans are a member of the National Basketball Association's Western Conference Southwest Division.

Starrcade was an annual professional wrestling event held from 1983-2000 by the NWA and later WCW.  Initially broadcast via closed-circuit television, it later transitioned to pay-per-view.  Jim Crockett Promotions produced Starrcade events under the NWA banner, including the third annual event in 1985, the fifth in 1987, and the fifteenth in 1997.
Jack Ryan Falahee, born February 20, 1989, is an American actor known for his roles as Connor Walsh in *How to Get Away with Murder* and Benjamin Stringfellow in *Mercy Street*.

Seohyun, a South Korean singer and actress, debuted as a solo artist on January 17, 2017, with her mini album, *Don't Say No*.  She is a member of the popular South Korean girl group Girls' Generation and has also had success as a stage actress.  *Don't Say No* is her debut extended play.

The Apple II, a highly successful 8-bit home computer, was primarily designed by Steve Wozniak and introduced in 1977 by Apple Computer.  Steve Jobs oversaw the case design, and Rod Holt developed the power supply.  The Apple II series was one of the first mass-produced microcomputers using text commands.

A&E, formerly Arts & Entertainment Network, is an American cable and satellite television channel.  It's the flagship property of A&E Networks, a joint venture equally owned by the Hearst Corporation and the Walt Disney Company's Disney-ABC Television Group.

L.A. Reid has held the positions of chairman and CEO of Epic Records, president and CEO of Arista Records, and chairman and CEO of Island Def Jam Music Group.  He also founded and was CEO of Hitco Music Publishing and co-founded LaFace Records.

There are two films titled *Veeram* (Valour): a 2014 Indian Tamil action film directed by Siva and produced by Vijaya Productions, and a 2016 Indian epic historical drama film written and directed by Jayaraj.

*Home for the Holidays* is a 1972 American made-for-television horror film directed by John Llewellyn Moxey and starring Sally Field, Eleanor Parker, Julie Harris, Jessica Walter, and Walter Brennan.  It premiered on ABC on November 28, 1972.  There is also a 1995 film with the same name starring Holly Hunter, Robert Downey Jr., Anne Bancroft, Charles Durning, Dylan McDermott, Geraldine Chaplin, Steve Guttenberg, Cynthia Stevenson, Claire Danes, Austin Pendleton, and David Strathairn.
Taran Hourie Killam, born April 1, 1982, is an American actor, comedian, and writer.
The online reality TV series, *The Sex Factor*, produced by xHamster, features sixteen contestants (eight men and eight women) competing to become porn stars.
John Hovig Dolmayan, born July 15, 1973, is a Lebanese-born Armenian-American songwriter and drummer.
Island Records is a British-American record label and a division of Universal Music Group (UMG).
Sikkim is a state located in northeastern India.
Christa McAuliffe became a social studies teacher at Concord High School in New Hampshire in 1983.
Ron Weasley is a fictional character in J. K. Rowling's Harry Potter series.
Mike Binder wrote, directed, and his brother Jack Binder produced the American drama film, *Reign Over Me*, which was distributed by Columbia Pictures and released on March 23, 2007.
Colin Kaepernick, born November 3, 1987, is an American football quarterback and current free agent.

Sheryl Lee appeared in the film *Cafe Society* (2016) and reprised her role as Laura Palmer in the Showtime revival of *Twin Peaks* (2017).  Sheryl Lee Ralph played Madame Morrible in the Broadway production of *Wicked* in 2016.
Matteo Renzi, born January 11, 1975, served as Italy's Prime Minister from February 2014 to December 2016.
The Road to El Dorado stars Kevin Kline, Kenneth Branagh, Armand Assante, Jim Cummings, Edward James Olmos, Tobin Bell, and Rosie Perez.

Selena Gomez's song, "Same Old Love," is featured on her second studio album, *Revival*, released in 2015.  *Revival* debuted at number one on the Billboard 200 chart, and "Same Old Love," along with two other singles from the album, reached the top of the Mainstream Top 40 chart.
Weekly Idol is a show hosted by comedian Jeong Hyeong-don and rapper Defconn.

Heavy metal music originated in the late 1960s and early 1970s in the United Kingdom and the United States.  Bands like Iron Maiden and Saxon continued the genre in the late 1970s as part of the new wave of British heavy metal.
Ashton Kutcher appeared in several romantic comedies, including *Guess Who* (2005), *A Lot Like Love* (2005), *What Happens in Vegas* (2008), and *No Strings Attached* (2011).
Topman, part of the Arcadia Group, is a men's clothing store chain with locations in the United Kingdom and Ireland.

The Industrial Revolution transformed Wales from an agrarian society to an industrial one, largely due to the growth of mining and metallurgy.  The South Wales Coalfield's development led to a rapid population increase.
Tool is a Grammy award-winning band that has toured worldwide and created chart-topping albums internationally.
YouTube is a video-sharing website based in San Bruno, California.  Alexa Internet ranks it as the second most popular website globally.
Sidse Babett Knudsen, born November 22, 1968, is a Danish actress who works in theater, television, and film.

Conrad Dunn's first significant film role was as Francis "Psycho" Soyer in the 1981 film *Stripes*.  *Stripes* also featured the first significant roles for John Larroquette, John Diehl, and Judge Reinhold.
The film *Raees* stars Shah Rukh Khan, Mahira Khan, and Nawazuddin Siddiqui.
Asylum Records is an American record label founded in 1971 by David Geffen and Elliot Roberts.
Guillermo del Toro created the American computer-animated fantasy series *Trollhunters*, which Netflix distributes.  DreamWorks Animation and Double Dare You produced the show.

The Armenian Genocide, also called the Armenian Holocaust, was the Ottoman government’s systematic extermination of 1.5 million Armenians, mostly Ottoman citizens.  Other groups, including Assyrians and Ottoman Greeks, were also targeted in similar genocidal campaigns.
Marcus Morgan Bentley is a British actor, broadcaster, and voice-over artist born on October 4, 1967.

William Jefferson Clinton, born August 19, 1946, served as the 42nd President of the United States from 1993 to 2001.  His first inauguration took place on January 20, 1993, at the US Capitol Building in Washington, D.C.

Danny Boyle, born October 20, 1956, is an English director, producer, screenwriter, and theatre director known for films such as *Shallow Grave*, *Trainspotting*, *The Beach*, *28 Days Later*, *Sunshine*, *Slumdog Millionaire*, *127 Hours*, and *Steve Jobs*.  *The Beach*, a 2000 film directed by Boyle, is based on Alex Garland's 1996 novel and adapted by John Hodge.
In the first week after an image of a dress appeared online, it was mentioned in over 10 million tweets using hashtags such as #thedress, #whiteandgold, and #blackandblue.
Major Bruce Middleton Hope Shand, born January 22, 1917, and deceased June 11, 2006, served as an officer in the British Army.
Advertising is a form of marketing communication that uses audio or visual methods to promote a product, service, or idea through openly sponsored, non-personal messages.

The Others, a 2001 film, won eight Goya Awards, including Best Film and Best Director, making it the first English-language film to win Best Film without any Spanish dialogue.  It also won three Saturn Awards: Best Horror Film, Best Actress (Nicole Kidman), and Best Supporting Actress (Fionnula Flanagan).

Ralph Fults, born January 23, 1911, and who died March 16, 1993, was a Depression-era outlaw and escape artist associated with the Barrow Gang, which included Raymond Hamilton, Bonnie Parker, and Clyde Barrow.

The 14th Dalai Lama, Tenzin Gyatso, was born in Taktser village, Tibet in 1935.  He was selected as the tulku of the 13th Dalai Lama in 1937 and publicly recognized in 1939. Following the 1959 Tibetan uprising, he fled to India, where he remains.

In World War II occupied Italy, four Buffalo Soldiers of the 92nd Infantry Division sought refuge in a small Tuscan village.  The film depicts their bond with the villagers and is presented as a flashback from the perspective of a survivor in 1980s New York.
Caroline Kennedy is an American author, attorney, and diplomat who served as the United States Ambassador to Japan from 2013-2017.

Home for the Holidays, a 1995 film, stars Holly Hunter, Robert Downey Jr., Anne Bancroft, Charles Durning, Dylan McDermott, Geraldine Chaplin, Steve Guttenberg, Cynthia Stevenson, Claire Danes, Austin Pendleton, and David Strathairn.
Anne Rice was born in New Orleans, lived there for a significant portion of her early life, then moved to Texas, and finally settled in San Francisco.
Stephen Hillenburg, born in Lawton, Oklahoma and raised in Anaheim, California, developed a childhood fascination with the ocean and art.

Many religious orders, including Catholic, Hindu, Sufi, Jain, and Buddhist, follow a mendicant lifestyle.  A monk, derived from the Greek word for "single, solitary," is a person who practices religious asceticism, either alone or with others, dedicating their life to serving others or living in prayer and contemplation outside of mainstream society.
The Mod Squad is an American crime drama series which aired on ABC from 1968 to 1973.
The Dark Tower is an upcoming American science fantasy western action horror film directed and co-written by Nikolaj Arcel.

Arizona, the 48th state admitted to the Union (February 14, 1912), is the sixth largest and fourteenth most populous state.  It is home to 27 federally recognized Native American tribes, including the Navajo Nation, the largest in the state and the U.S.  About one-quarter of the state consists of Native American reservations.
Smriti Mandhana, born July 18, 1996, is an Indian cricketer who plays for the Indian women's cricket team.
Emma Charlotte Duerre Watson, born April 15, 1990, is a French-British actress, model, and activist.  She was born in Paris, raised in Oxfordshire, and trained at Stagecoach Theatre Arts in Oxford.
Angela Bassett earned a bachelor's degree from Yale University and a master's degree in fine arts from drama school before beginning her film career in the mid-1980s.

The Congressional Space Medal of Honor is the highest NASA award.  Awarded by the President on the recommendation of NASA’s administrator, it recognizes astronauts’ extraordinary accomplishments during NASA-authorized spaceflights.  Frank Frederick Borman II is an example of a recipient.
The Saw franchise of films has grossed over $873 million worldwide.
*Down with Love* is a 2003 romantic comedy film.
Paul Nicholls is an actor best known for his roles as Joe Wicks in BBC's *EastEnders* and as DS Sam Casey in ITV's *Law & Order: UK*.
*Colombiana* is a 2011 French action film co-written and produced by Luc Besson and directed by Olivier Megaton.
Rick Yune was in the main cast of the Netflix series *Marco Polo* until its cancellation on December 12, 2016.
Kentucky is known for horse racing, bourbon distilleries, coal, My Old Kentucky Home, automobile manufacturing, tobacco, bluegrass music, college basketball, and Kentucky Fried Chicken.
The film *Boyhood*, filmed between 2002 and 2013, follows Mason Evans, Jr. from ages six to eighteen as he grows up in Texas with his divorced parents.
The 2016 film *Hush* was produced by Trevor Macy through Intrepid Pictures and Jason Blum through Blumhouse Productions.

The Penibaetic System, also known as the Sistema Penibético or Cordillera Penibética, is the southernmost of the three mountain ranges in the Baetic System located in the southern Iberian Peninsula.

Bonobos is a men's clothing brand offering suits, trousers, denim, shirts, shorts, swimwear, outerwear, and accessories.  Topman, part of the Arcadia Group, is a UK-based men's clothing store chain with locations throughout the UK and Ireland.
"Roar," the lead single from Katy Perry's 2013 album *Prism*, was released on August 10, 2013.
Saturn Corporation, or Saturn LLC, is a registered trademark and subsidiary of General Motors, established January 7, 1985.

The Armenian Genocide, also called the Armenian Holocaust, was the Ottoman government’s systematic extermination of 1.5 million Armenians, mostly Ottoman citizens.  Turkey, the successor state to the Ottoman Empire, denies that the term genocide accurately describes the mass killings that began in 1915.

Muslims believe the Quran was revealed by God to Muhammad through the angel Gabriel, gradually over 23 years, beginning December 22, 609 CE, when Muhammad was 40, and concluding in 632 CE with Muhammad's death.

The central nervous system contains the brain and spinal cord.  The brain is composed of the cerebrum, brainstem, and cerebellum, with the cerebrum being the largest part.  The cerebrum contains the thalamus, epithalamus, pineal gland, hypothalamus, pituitary gland, subthalamus, limbic structures (amygdala and hippocampus), claustrum, basal ganglia nuclei, basal forebrain structures, and three circumventricular organs.
T2 Trainspotting, a 2017 British comedy drama film, takes place in and around Edinburgh, Scotland.
AMGTV is an American family-oriented television network that broadcasts dramas, sports, movies, entertainment, how-to shows, hunting and fishing programs, children's shows, and other features.

Sir Donald George Bradman, an Australian cricketer, is considered the greatest batsman of all time.  Even after retirement and into his later years, he remained a national icon in Australia; Prime Minister John Howard called him the "greatest living Australian" in 2001.

Margaret Thatcher served as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 1979-1990, and Leader of the Conservative Party from 1975-1990.  She was the longest-serving British Prime Minister of the 20th century and the first woman to hold the office.  In 1975, she became the first woman to lead a major political party in the United Kingdom.

Randy Savage, whose real name was Randy Mario Poffo, was an American professional wrestler and color commentator.  He was best known for his work with the World Wrestling Federation (WWF, now WWE) and World Championship Wrestling (WCW).
Alice Cooper, born Vincent Damon Furnier on February 4, 1948, is an American singer, songwriter, and actor with a career spanning over five decades.
EA Black Box, a video game developer located in Burnaby, British Columbia, was founded in 1998 by former Radical Entertainment employees.  Electronic Arts (EA) later acquired the company.

Baiae was a resort town located on the Gulf of Naples in ancient Italy.  Herculaneum, a Roman town near Mount Vesuvius, was destroyed by volcanic flows in 79 AD.  The area near Naples contains significant historical sites including the Palace of Caserta and the ruins of Pompeii and Herculaneum.  Famous ruins exist worldwide, including sites in China, the Indus Valley, Judea, Zimbabwe, the Mediterranean, and the Americas.

No Country for Old Men is a cat-and-mouse drama set in 1980 West Texas, starring Tommy Lee Jones as Sheriff Ed Tom Bell, Javier Bardem, and Josh Brolin.  The film follows a Texas welder and Vietnam veteran.

Palo Alto, a charter city in California's Santa Clara County, is located in the San Francisco Bay Area.  Its name, meaning "tall tree," comes from the Spanish words *palo* (stick/tree) and *alto* (tall).

Albert Lawrence Brooks, born July 22, 1947, is an American actor, filmmaker, author, and comedian.  Andrew Stanton directed *Finding Dory*, co-directed by Angus MacLane, with a screenplay by Stanton and Victoria Strouse.

Morse code transmits text through a series of on-off tones, lights, or clicks, understandable by a skilled person without equipment.  Character length inversely correlates with frequency in English for faster communication.  It's less sensitive to poor signals than voice and usable in emergencies via improvised methods.
Alexandra Anna Daddario is an American actress born March 16, 1986.

On December 12, 2005, at 21:47 UTC, an earthquake of magnitude 6.5 struck northeastern Afghanistan.  The Hindu Kush mountain range, stretching 800 km near the Afghan-Pakistan border, contains numerous high snow-capped peaks, with Tirich Mir (7708m) being the highest.
As of 2015, Ripon College in Wisconsin had approximately 840 students, most of whom lived on campus.

Fox Sports is a brand name encompassing various sports channels and media worldwide, controlled or partially owned by the Murdoch family.  Rupert Murdoch, through News Corp and 21st Century Fox (created after a 2013 split of News Corporation), and his family via the Murdoch Family Trust, maintains ownership.
Wildfang is a women's clothing company in the U.S. that sells tomboy-style apparel.
Bessie Smith, born April 15, 1894, and who died September 26, 1937, was an American blues singer.
Speech recognition (SR) is a subfield of computational linguistics that uses computer science, linguistics, and electrical engineering to translate spoken language into text.
Aleister Crowley, born Edward Alexander Crowley, was an English occultist, ceremonial magician, poet, painter, novelist, and mountaineer who lived from October 12, 1875 to December 1, 1947.
*Poldark* is a British-American drama television series that premiered on BBC One on March 8, 2015.
*Dilwale Dulhania Le Jayenge*, starring Shah Rukh Khan and Kajol, was released on October 20, 1995.  Filming took place in India, London, and Switzerland between September 1994 and August 1995.

Timothy Simon Roth, born May 14, 1961, is an English actor and director.  Tim Roth, born December 6, 1975, is the guitarist, backing vocalist, and sole remaining founding member of the Canadian metal band Into Eternity.
Tatum O'Neal married John McEnroe in 1986 and they had three children together.

Sean Penn is a prominent actor who won two Academy Awards for his roles in *Mystic River* (2003) and *Milk* (2008).  His career began with *Taps* (1981), and he gained recognition through various roles in crime dramas such as *At Close Range*, *State of Grace*, and *Carlito's Way*.  He also received acclaim for *Dead Man Walking*, *Sweet and Lowdown*, *I Am Sam*, and *Into the Wild*.

Volcanic outgassing created Earth’s primordial atmosphere and oceans, which were toxic to modern life due to the lack of oxygen.  Earth cooled, forming a solid crust and allowing liquid water on the surface. Plate tectonics shape the oceans and continents.  Human activity significantly impacts the atmosphere and other surface systems, including the ozone layer, greenhouse gases, and soil and water quality. Water covers 71% of Earth's surface.
Nuuk, also known as Godthåb, is the capital and largest city in Greenland and in the municipality of Sermersooq.

Dean DeBlois wrote and directed *How to Train Your Dragon 2*, which stars Jay Baruchel, Gerard Butler, Craig Ferguson, America Ferrera, Jonah Hill, Christopher Mintz-Plasse, T.J. Miller, Kristen Wiig, Cate Blanchett, Djimon Hounsou, and Kit Harington.  The original cast returned, with Blanchett and Hounsou added as the voices of Valka and Drago.

*Down With Love*, a 2003 romantic comedy film directed by Peyton Reed, stars Renée Zellweger and Ewan McGregor.  The film is a pastiche of 1950s and 60s sex comedies, particularly those starring Doris Day and Rock Hudson.  A television series, *Down With Love*, aired in Taiwan in 2010 on CTV and GTV.
Paris (Paris Hilton album) incorporates elements of reggae, soul, and pop rock.

The 1981 American buddy military comedy film, *Stripes*, was directed by Ivan Reitman.  Starring Bill Murray and Harold Ramis, it also featured several actors in their first significant roles, including John Larroquette, John Diehl, Conrad Dunn, and Judge Reinhold.  Other actors appearing early in their careers included Joe Flaherty, Dave Thomas, Timothy Busfield, and Bill Paxton.
Janelle Monáe Robinson, born December 1, 1985, is an American singer, songwriter, actress, and model.  She is signed to her own label, Wondaland Arts Society, and Atlantic Records.
Singer Jewell is best known for her song "Love or Lust" from the film *Deep Cover*, and for singing choruses on songs by Snoop Dogg and Dr. Dre.
The University of Mississippi's student body is comprised of 55% undergraduate and 60% overall from Mississippi, with 23% minorities and international students from 90 nations.
The Mighty Ducks was produced by The Kerner Entertainment Company and Avnet-Kerner Productions and distributed by Walt Disney Pictures.
Johanna Braddy starred in the web series *Video Game High School* (2012-2014) and the Lifetime series *Unreal* (2015).  Currently, she stars in the ABC thriller *Quantico* as Shelby Wyatt.

Martin Van Buren, a member of the Democratic Party, served as the eighth President of the United States (1837-1841), eighth Vice President (1833-1837), and tenth Secretary of State (1829-1831).  He was a key supporter of Andrew Jackson, helping him win the 1828 election.  After briefly serving as New York governor, Van Buren became Jackson's Secretary of State and later, minister to Britain.
Camden, New Jersey houses Rutgers University–Camden (founded in 1926 as the South Jersey Law School) and Cooper Medical School of Rowan University (opened in 2012).

Michigan is the tenth most populous state in the U.S., and the eleventh largest by area, being the largest east of the Mississippi River.  It is unique for having two peninsulas, making it a leader in recreational boating.

Penguin Books, beginning in the 1930s, created inexpensive, high-quality paperback fiction and nonfiction books, which were sold at high street stores such as Woolworths for sixpence, thus revolutionizing publishing by bringing these books to the mass market.
The 2008 film *Australia* was filmed in Sydney, Darwin, Kununurra, and Bowen.
