Christa McAuliffe became a social studies teacher at Concord High School in New Hampshire in 1983.
Ron Weasley is a fictional character in J. K. Rowling's Harry Potter series.
Mike Binder wrote, directed, and his brother Jack Binder produced the American drama film, *Reign Over Me*, which was distributed by Columbia Pictures and released on March 23, 2007.
Colin Kaepernick, born November 3, 1987, is an American football quarterback and current free agent.

Sheryl Lee appeared in the film *Cafe Society* (2016) and reprised her role as Laura Palmer in the Showtime revival of *Twin Peaks* (2017).  Sheryl Lee Ralph played Madame Morrible in the Broadway production of *Wicked* in 2016.
Matteo Renzi, born January 11, 1975, served as Italy's Prime Minister from February 2014 to December 2016.
The Road to El Dorado stars Kevin Kline, Kenneth Branagh, Armand Assante, Jim Cummings, Edward James Olmos, Tobin Bell, and Rosie Perez.

Selena Gomez's song, "Same Old Love," is featured on her second studio album, *Revival*, released in 2015.  *Revival* debuted at number one on the Billboard 200 chart, and "Same Old Love," along with two other singles from the album, reached the top of the Mainstream Top 40 chart.
Weekly Idol is a show hosted by comedian Jeong Hyeong-don and rapper Defconn.

Heavy metal music originated in the late 1960s and early 1970s in the United Kingdom and the United States.  Bands like Iron Maiden and Saxon continued the genre in the late 1970s as part of the new wave of British heavy metal.
Ashton Kutcher appeared in several romantic comedies, including *Guess Who* (2005), *A Lot Like Love* (2005), *What Happens in Vegas* (2008), and *No Strings Attached* (2011).
Topman, part of the Arcadia Group, is a men's clothing store chain with locations in the United Kingdom and Ireland.

The Industrial Revolution transformed Wales from an agrarian society to an industrial one, largely due to the growth of mining and metallurgy.  The South Wales Coalfield's development led to a rapid population increase.
Tool is a Grammy award-winning band that has toured worldwide and created chart-topping albums internationally.
YouTube is a video-sharing website based in San Bruno, California.  Alexa Internet ranks it as the second most popular website globally.
Sidse Babett Knudsen, born November 22, 1968, is a Danish actress who works in theater, television, and film.

Conrad Dunn's first significant film role was as Francis "Psycho" Soyer in the 1981 film *Stripes*.  *Stripes* also featured the first significant roles for John Larroquette, John Diehl, and Judge Reinhold.
The film *Raees* stars Shah Rukh Khan, Mahira Khan, and Nawazuddin Siddiqui.
Asylum Records is an American record label founded in 1971 by David Geffen and Elliot Roberts.
Guillermo del Toro created the American computer-animated fantasy series *Trollhunters*, which Netflix distributes.  DreamWorks Animation and Double Dare You produced the show.

The Armenian Genocide, also called the Armenian Holocaust, was the Ottoman government’s systematic extermination of 1.5 million Armenians, mostly Ottoman citizens.  Other groups, including Assyrians and Ottoman Greeks, were also targeted in similar genocidal campaigns.
Marcus Morgan Bentley is a British actor, broadcaster, and voice-over artist born on October 4, 1967.

William Jefferson Clinton, born August 19, 1946, served as the 42nd President of the United States from 1993 to 2001.  His first inauguration took place on January 20, 1993, at the US Capitol Building in Washington, D.C.

Danny Boyle, born October 20, 1956, is an English director, producer, screenwriter, and theatre director known for films such as *Shallow Grave*, *Trainspotting*, *The Beach*, *28 Days Later*, *Sunshine*, *Slumdog Millionaire*, *127 Hours*, and *Steve Jobs*.  *The Beach*, a 2000 film directed by Boyle, is based on Alex Garland's 1996 novel and adapted by John Hodge.
In the first week after an image of a dress appeared online, it was mentioned in over 10 million tweets using hashtags such as #thedress, #whiteandgold, and #blackandblue.
Major Bruce Middleton Hope Shand, born January 22, 1917, and deceased June 11, 2006, served as an officer in the British Army.
Advertising is a form of marketing communication that uses audio or visual methods to promote a product, service, or idea through openly sponsored, non-personal messages.

The Others, a 2001 film, won eight Goya Awards, including Best Film and Best Director, making it the first English-language film to win Best Film without any Spanish dialogue.  It also won three Saturn Awards: Best Horror Film, Best Actress (Nicole Kidman), and Best Supporting Actress (Fionnula Flanagan).

Ralph Fults, born January 23, 1911, and who died March 16, 1993, was a Depression-era outlaw and escape artist associated with the Barrow Gang, which included Raymond Hamilton, Bonnie Parker, and Clyde Barrow.

The 14th Dalai Lama, Tenzin Gyatso, was born in Taktser village, Tibet in 1935.  He was selected as the tulku of the 13th Dalai Lama in 1937 and publicly recognized in 1939. Following the 1959 Tibetan uprising, he fled to India, where he remains.

In World War II occupied Italy, four Buffalo Soldiers of the 92nd Infantry Division sought refuge in a small Tuscan village.  The film depicts their bond with the villagers and is presented as a flashback from the perspective of a survivor in 1980s New York.
Caroline Kennedy is an American author, attorney, and diplomat who served as the United States Ambassador to Japan from 2013-2017.

Home for the Holidays, a 1995 film, stars Holly Hunter, Robert Downey Jr., Anne Bancroft, Charles Durning, Dylan McDermott, Geraldine Chaplin, Steve Guttenberg, Cynthia Stevenson, Claire Danes, Austin Pendleton, and David Strathairn.
Anne Rice was born in New Orleans, lived there for a significant portion of her early life, then moved to Texas, and finally settled in San Francisco.
Stephen Hillenburg, born in Lawton, Oklahoma and raised in Anaheim, California, developed a childhood fascination with the ocean and art.

Many religious orders, including Catholic, Hindu, Sufi, Jain, and Buddhist, follow a mendicant lifestyle.  A monk, derived from the Greek word for "single, solitary," is a person who practices religious asceticism, either alone or with others, dedicating their life to serving others or living in prayer and contemplation outside of mainstream society.
The Mod Squad is an American crime drama series which aired on ABC from 1968 to 1973.
The Dark Tower is an upcoming American science fantasy western action horror film directed and co-written by Nikolaj Arcel.

Arizona, the 48th state admitted to the Union (February 14, 1912), is the sixth largest and fourteenth most populous state.  It is home to 27 federally recognized Native American tribes, including the Navajo Nation, the largest in the state and the U.S.  About one-quarter of the state consists of Native American reservations.
Smriti Mandhana, born July 18, 1996, is an Indian cricketer who plays for the Indian women's cricket team.
Emma Charlotte Duerre Watson, born April 15, 1990, is a French-British actress, model, and activist.  She was born in Paris, raised in Oxfordshire, and trained at Stagecoach Theatre Arts in Oxford.
Angela Bassett earned a bachelor's degree from Yale University and a master's degree in fine arts from drama school before beginning her film career in the mid-1980s.

The Congressional Space Medal of Honor is the highest NASA award.  Awarded by the President on the recommendation of NASA’s administrator, it recognizes astronauts’ extraordinary accomplishments during NASA-authorized spaceflights.  Frank Frederick Borman II is an example of a recipient.
The Saw franchise of films has grossed over $873 million worldwide.
*Down with Love* is a 2003 romantic comedy film.
Paul Nicholls is an actor best known for his roles as Joe Wicks in BBC's *EastEnders* and as DS Sam Casey in ITV's *Law & Order: UK*.
*Colombiana* is a 2011 French action film co-written and produced by Luc Besson and directed by Olivier Megaton.
Rick Yune was in the main cast of the Netflix series *Marco Polo* until its cancellation on December 12, 2016.
Kentucky is known for horse racing, bourbon distilleries, coal, My Old Kentucky Home, automobile manufacturing, tobacco, bluegrass music, college basketball, and Kentucky Fried Chicken.
The film *Boyhood*, filmed between 2002 and 2013, follows Mason Evans, Jr. from ages six to eighteen as he grows up in Texas with his divorced parents.
The 2016 film *Hush* was produced by Trevor Macy through Intrepid Pictures and Jason Blum through Blumhouse Productions.

The Penibaetic System, also known as the Sistema Penibético or Cordillera Penibética, is the southernmost of the three mountain ranges in the Baetic System located in the southern Iberian Peninsula.

Bonobos is a men's clothing brand offering suits, trousers, denim, shirts, shorts, swimwear, outerwear, and accessories.  Topman, part of the Arcadia Group, is a UK-based men's clothing store chain with locations throughout the UK and Ireland.
"Roar," the lead single from Katy Perry's 2013 album *Prism*, was released on August 10, 2013.
Saturn Corporation, or Saturn LLC, is a registered trademark and subsidiary of General Motors, established January 7, 1985.

The Armenian Genocide, also called the Armenian Holocaust, was the Ottoman government’s systematic extermination of 1.5 million Armenians, mostly Ottoman citizens.  Turkey, the successor state to the Ottoman Empire, denies that the term genocide accurately describes the mass killings that began in 1915.

Muslims believe the Quran was revealed by God to Muhammad through the angel Gabriel, gradually over 23 years, beginning December 22, 609 CE, when Muhammad was 40, and concluding in 632 CE with Muhammad's death.

The central nervous system contains the brain and spinal cord.  The brain is composed of the cerebrum, brainstem, and cerebellum, with the cerebrum being the largest part.  The cerebrum contains the thalamus, epithalamus, pineal gland, hypothalamus, pituitary gland, subthalamus, limbic structures (amygdala and hippocampus), claustrum, basal ganglia nuclei, basal forebrain structures, and three circumventricular organs.
T2 Trainspotting, a 2017 British comedy drama film, takes place in and around Edinburgh, Scotland.
AMGTV is an American family-oriented television network that broadcasts dramas, sports, movies, entertainment, how-to shows, hunting and fishing programs, children's shows, and other features.

Sir Donald George Bradman, an Australian cricketer, is considered the greatest batsman of all time.  Even after retirement and into his later years, he remained a national icon in Australia; Prime Minister John Howard called him the "greatest living Australian" in 2001.

Margaret Thatcher served as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 1979-1990, and Leader of the Conservative Party from 1975-1990.  She was the longest-serving British Prime Minister of the 20th century and the first woman to hold the office.  In 1975, she became the first woman to lead a major political party in the United Kingdom.

Randy Savage, whose real name was Randy Mario Poffo, was an American professional wrestler and color commentator.  He was best known for his work with the World Wrestling Federation (WWF, now WWE) and World Championship Wrestling (WCW).
Alice Cooper, born Vincent Damon Furnier on February 4, 1948, is an American singer, songwriter, and actor with a career spanning over five decades.
EA Black Box, a video game developer located in Burnaby, British Columbia, was founded in 1998 by former Radical Entertainment employees.  Electronic Arts (EA) later acquired the company.

Baiae was a resort town located on the Gulf of Naples in ancient Italy.  Herculaneum, a Roman town near Mount Vesuvius, was destroyed by volcanic flows in 79 AD.  The area near Naples contains significant historical sites including the Palace of Caserta and the ruins of Pompeii and Herculaneum.  Famous ruins exist worldwide, including sites in China, the Indus Valley, Judea, Zimbabwe, the Mediterranean, and the Americas.

No Country for Old Men is a cat-and-mouse drama set in 1980 West Texas, starring Tommy Lee Jones as Sheriff Ed Tom Bell, Javier Bardem, and Josh Brolin.  The film follows a Texas welder and Vietnam veteran.

Palo Alto, a charter city in California's Santa Clara County, is located in the San Francisco Bay Area.  Its name, meaning "tall tree," comes from the Spanish words *palo* (stick/tree) and *alto* (tall).

Albert Lawrence Brooks, born July 22, 1947, is an American actor, filmmaker, author, and comedian.  Andrew Stanton directed *Finding Dory*, co-directed by Angus MacLane, with a screenplay by Stanton and Victoria Strouse.

Morse code transmits text through a series of on-off tones, lights, or clicks, understandable by a skilled person without equipment.  Character length inversely correlates with frequency in English for faster communication.  It's less sensitive to poor signals than voice and usable in emergencies via improvised methods.
Alexandra Anna Daddario is an American actress born March 16, 1986.

On December 12, 2005, at 21:47 UTC, an earthquake of magnitude 6.5 struck northeastern Afghanistan.  The Hindu Kush mountain range, stretching 800 km near the Afghan-Pakistan border, contains numerous high snow-capped peaks, with Tirich Mir (7708m) being the highest.
As of 2015, Ripon College in Wisconsin had approximately 840 students, most of whom lived on campus.

Fox Sports is a brand name encompassing various sports channels and media worldwide, controlled or partially owned by the Murdoch family.  Rupert Murdoch, through News Corp and 21st Century Fox (created after a 2013 split of News Corporation), and his family via the Murdoch Family Trust, maintains ownership.
Wildfang is a women's clothing company in the U.S. that sells tomboy-style apparel.
Bessie Smith, born April 15, 1894, and who died September 26, 1937, was an American blues singer.
Speech recognition (SR) is a subfield of computational linguistics that uses computer science, linguistics, and electrical engineering to translate spoken language into text.
Aleister Crowley, born Edward Alexander Crowley, was an English occultist, ceremonial magician, poet, painter, novelist, and mountaineer who lived from October 12, 1875 to December 1, 1947.
*Poldark* is a British-American drama television series that premiered on BBC One on March 8, 2015.
*Dilwale Dulhania Le Jayenge*, starring Shah Rukh Khan and Kajol, was released on October 20, 1995.  Filming took place in India, London, and Switzerland between September 1994 and August 1995.

Timothy Simon Roth, born May 14, 1961, is an English actor and director.  Tim Roth, born December 6, 1975, is the guitarist, backing vocalist, and sole remaining founding member of the Canadian metal band Into Eternity.
Tatum O'Neal married John McEnroe in 1986 and they had three children together.

Sean Penn is a prominent actor who won two Academy Awards for his roles in *Mystic River* (2003) and *Milk* (2008).  His career began with *Taps* (1981), and he gained recognition through various roles in crime dramas such as *At Close Range*, *State of Grace*, and *Carlito's Way*.  He also received acclaim for *Dead Man Walking*, *Sweet and Lowdown*, *I Am Sam*, and *Into the Wild*.

Volcanic outgassing created Earth’s primordial atmosphere and oceans, which were toxic to modern life due to the lack of oxygen.  Earth cooled, forming a solid crust and allowing liquid water on the surface. Plate tectonics shape the oceans and continents.  Human activity significantly impacts the atmosphere and other surface systems, including the ozone layer, greenhouse gases, and soil and water quality. Water covers 71% of Earth's surface.
Nuuk, also known as Godthåb, is the capital and largest city in Greenland and in the municipality of Sermersooq.

Dean DeBlois wrote and directed *How to Train Your Dragon 2*, which stars Jay Baruchel, Gerard Butler, Craig Ferguson, America Ferrera, Jonah Hill, Christopher Mintz-Plasse, T.J. Miller, Kristen Wiig, Cate Blanchett, Djimon Hounsou, and Kit Harington.  The original cast returned, with Blanchett and Hounsou added as the voices of Valka and Drago.

*Down With Love*, a 2003 romantic comedy film directed by Peyton Reed, stars Renée Zellweger and Ewan McGregor.  The film is a pastiche of 1950s and 60s sex comedies, particularly those starring Doris Day and Rock Hudson.  A television series, *Down With Love*, aired in Taiwan in 2010 on CTV and GTV.
Paris (Paris Hilton album) incorporates elements of reggae, soul, and pop rock.

The 1981 American buddy military comedy film, *Stripes*, was directed by Ivan Reitman.  Starring Bill Murray and Harold Ramis, it also featured several actors in their first significant roles, including John Larroquette, John Diehl, Conrad Dunn, and Judge Reinhold.  Other actors appearing early in their careers included Joe Flaherty, Dave Thomas, Timothy Busfield, and Bill Paxton.
Janelle Monáe Robinson, born December 1, 1985, is an American singer, songwriter, actress, and model.  She is signed to her own label, Wondaland Arts Society, and Atlantic Records.
Singer Jewell is best known for her song "Love or Lust" from the film *Deep Cover*, and for singing choruses on songs by Snoop Dogg and Dr. Dre.
The University of Mississippi's student body is comprised of 55% undergraduate and 60% overall from Mississippi, with 23% minorities and international students from 90 nations.
The Mighty Ducks was produced by The Kerner Entertainment Company and Avnet-Kerner Productions and distributed by Walt Disney Pictures.
Johanna Braddy starred in the web series *Video Game High School* (2012-2014) and the Lifetime series *Unreal* (2015).  Currently, she stars in the ABC thriller *Quantico* as Shelby Wyatt.

Martin Van Buren, a member of the Democratic Party, served as the eighth President of the United States (1837-1841), eighth Vice President (1833-1837), and tenth Secretary of State (1829-1831).  He was a key supporter of Andrew Jackson, helping him win the 1828 election.  After briefly serving as New York governor, Van Buren became Jackson's Secretary of State and later, minister to Britain.
Camden, New Jersey houses Rutgers University–Camden (founded in 1926 as the South Jersey Law School) and Cooper Medical School of Rowan University (opened in 2012).

Michigan is the tenth most populous state in the U.S., and the eleventh largest by area, being the largest east of the Mississippi River.  It is unique for having two peninsulas, making it a leader in recreational boating.

Penguin Books, beginning in the 1930s, created inexpensive, high-quality paperback fiction and nonfiction books, which were sold at high street stores such as Woolworths for sixpence, thus revolutionizing publishing by bringing these books to the mass market.
The 2008 film *Australia* was filmed in Sydney, Darwin, Kununurra, and Bowen.

Billy Ray Cyrus is a country music singer, songwriter, actor, and philanthropist who popularized country music globally.  French Montana's debut album is titled *Excuse My French*.  There is also a 2014 Egyptian comedy film with the same name, directed by Amr Salama, based on his experiences with religious discrimination in Egypt.  The film faced censorship issues.
In 2013, Derek Hough starred in the South Korean-American independent dance film, *Make Your Move*, a Romeo and Juliet-inspired movie.

Lady Gaga's "Bad Romance," from her 2009 EP *The Fame Monster*, achieved global success after its debut at Paris Fashion Week, selling 12 million copies worldwide.  A separate independent drama film, *Les Mauvais Romans* (*Bad Romance*), was released in 2011.

DreamWorks Animation has released 34 feature films including the franchises Shrek, Puss in Boots, Madagascar, Kung Fu Panda, How to Train Your Dragon, and Trolls.  Other successful films include Monsters vs. Aliens, Rise of the Guardians, The Croods, and Home.  Additionally, DreamWorks Animation produced the Netflix series *Trollhunters*, created by Guillermo del Toro.

Chris Eubank (born August 8, 1966) is a British former professional boxer who competed from 1985-1998.  His son, Chris Eubank Jr. (born September 18, 1989) is also a British professional boxer.  As of May 2017, Eubank Jr. held the IBO super-middleweight title and was ranked among the top ten super middleweights and middleweights by various boxing ranking organizations.
Sophia Anna Bush, born July 8, 1982, is an American actress, director, spokesperson, and activist known for her roles in *John Tucker Must Die* (2006), *The Hitcher* (2007), and *The Narrows* (2008).

James Murdoch is the CEO of 21st Century Fox and chairman of Sky plc.  His father, Rupert Murdoch, is the chairman and acting CEO of Fox News and was chairman and CEO of News Corporation, now the world's second-largest media conglomerate.  News Corporation split into News Corp and 21st Century Fox on June 28, 2013.
In 2013, Gal Gadot was the second highest-earning actress/model in Israel, earning more than Esti Ginzburg and Shlomit Malka, but less than Bar Refaeli.  Most of her income came from acting.
Creedence Clearwater Revival (CCR) was an American rock band that was active from the late 1960s to the early 1970s.
Calcaneal spurs are usually found through radiographic examinations, which are also known as x-rays.
The South Wales Coalfield, also known as Maes glo De Cymru, is a large area in south Wales with significant coal deposits, particularly in the South Wales Valleys.

The CONCACAF Champions League, formerly known as the CONCACAF Champions' Cup, is an annual football competition for top clubs in North America, Central America, and the Caribbean.  It was first organized in 1962.

Upon the death of her husband, George, in 1936, Mary became Queen Mother.  Her son Edward abdicated the throne to marry Wallis Simpson, resulting in her son Albert's ascension as George VI.  Mary supported George VI until his death in 1952, and she died the following year during the reign of her granddaughter, Queen Elizabeth II.
The film *Poseidon* had a budget of $160 million and grossed $181,674,817 worldwide.
The NAACP Image Award for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Drama Series was first awarded in 1996.  Omar Epps and Joe Morton are tied for the most wins, with three each.

Human trafficking is the trade of humans for forced labor, sexual slavery, or commercial sexual exploitation.  In 2014, the International Labour Organization (ILO) estimated forced labor generated $150 billion in profit.  Of those forced into labor, 68% were exploited for labor, 22% were sexually exploited, and 10% were exploited in state-imposed forced labor.
The film *Rio* was released in 2011 and had a sequel, *Rio 2*, released on April 11, 2014.

Francis I (1708-1765) was Holy Roman Emperor and Grand Duke of Tuscany, though his wife held the real power.  Francis I (1494-1547) was King of France (1515-1547), known as "Francis of the Large Nose," among other names. He fought against his rival Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor and King of Spain, and later formed a controversial alliance with the Ottoman Sultan Suleiman the Magnificent.  The Italian War of 1536-1538 was fought between Francis I and Charles V.

Peking University (PKU), located in Beijing, is China’s first modern national university.  Founded in 1898 as the Imperial University of Peking, it replaced the ancient Imperial Academy and initially served as China’s education ministry.  PKU is consistently ranked as the top higher education institution in mainland China and is a member of the C9 League.
Lemmy was known for his mutton chops, gravelly voice, and bass playing style.
Global warming threatens food security through decreased crop yields and forces people to abandon homes because of rising sea levels.
Baz Luhrmann's 2008 film, *Australia*, is a historical romantic drama starring Nicole Kidman and Hugh Jackman.
Michael Vick, born June 26, 1980, is a former American football quarterback who played 13 seasons in the NFL, mostly for the Atlanta Falcons and Philadelphia Eagles.

Canadian folklore encompasses songs, legends, jokes, rhymes, proverbs, weather lore, superstitions, and practices like traditional food and craft making.  It also includes oral traditions such as tales, proverbs, and jokes.
The First Motion Picture Unit produced over 400 informative and entertaining propaganda and training films, and trained combat cameramen.

James Jones (author) won the 1952 National Book Award for his novel *From Here to Eternity*, which was made into a movie and later a television series.  James Jones (basketball player) averaged 25 points per game his senior year, winning several awards.  He won three NBA championships and finished third in the NBA in three-point percentage during the 2007-08 season.  He also won the Three-Point Contest in 2011.
In 1999, the American Film Institute ranked Humphrey Bogart as the greatest male star of Classic American cinema.

Computer animation generates animated images.  Trollhunters, a Netflix series created by Guillermo del Toro and produced by DreamWorks Animation and Double Dare You, is an example of American computer-animated fantasy television.
Shane McMahon resigned from WWE in 2009, effective January 1, 2010.

Tom Baker is an English actor best known for his role as the fourth Doctor in *Doctor Who* (1974-1981), the longest tenure of any actor in the series.  He is also known for narrating *Little Britain* and other works, including commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.
Angelsberg is a small town located in the commune of Fischbach in central Luxembourg.

Hanford Site is home to a cleanup project, the Columbia Generating Station (a commercial nuclear power plant), and research and development centers including the Pacific Northwest National Laboratory and the LIGO Hanford Observatory.

The White House Press Secretary is a senior White House official who acts as a spokesperson for the executive branch, particularly concerning the President, senior executives, and policies.  The President appoints the Press Secretary, and the position, while prominent, is not a Cabinet post and doesn't require Senate confirmation.

Kentucky, also known as the “Bluegrass State,” is home to the Bluegrass Region, encompassing major cities like Louisville and Lexington.  The state is renowned for horse racing, bourbon, coal, My Old Kentucky Home, automobile manufacturing, tobacco, bluegrass music, college basketball, and Kentucky Fried Chicken.
Broken Bridges, a 2006 film, stars Toby Keith, Lindsey Haun, Burt Reynolds, and Kelly Preston.  Preston also starred in *The Cat in the Hat*, *Old Dogs*, and *Broken Bridges*.
Kesha Rose Sebert, born March 1, 1987, is an American singer, songwriter, and rapper, formerly stylized as Ke$ha.
On May 5, 2017, two versions of "Despacito" were released: an electronic version by Major Lazer and MOSKA, and an urban version by Sky.

Starrcade, an annual professional wrestling event, was held from 1983-2000 by the NWA and later WCW.  Initially broadcast via closed-circuit television, it transitioned to pay-per-view in 1987, becoming the first NWA event to do so.  The 1983-1986 Starrcades were later added to the WWE Network in 2014 and rated TV-MA for violence.  Starrcade 1997 was the 15th annual event.
Veeru Devgan was an Indian stunt and action choreographer and film director in Bollywood.
Star Trek: Discovery is the first Star Trek series since Star Trek: Enterprise (2005), and the first developed specifically for the streaming service.

Terry Crews played defensive end and linebacker in the NFL for the Los Angeles Rams, San Diego Chargers, and Washington Redskins.  He also played in the World League of American Football with Rhein Fire.

French Montana's debut album is titled *Excuse My French*.  There is also a 2014 Egyptian comedy film with the same name, directed by Amr Salama.  Finally, British hip hop artist Plan B (Benjamin Paul Ballance-Drew) is also mentioned.

A floppy disk, also known as a floppy, diskette, or disk, is a type of disk storage consisting of a thin, flexible magnetic disk sealed within a rectangular plastic case.  The case is fabric-lined to remove dust particles.

From the mid-1800s to the late 1900s, Guatemala suffered from political instability and violence.  This included a civil war (1960-1996) between the U.S.-backed government and leftist rebels, resulting in the massacre of Mayan people.
Forceps are hinged, handheld instruments used to grasp and hold objects.  Outside of medicine, they are also known as tweezers, tongs, pliers, clips, or clamps.
On Monday, July 11, 2011, the television series *The Closer* began its seventh and final season, after concluding its sixth season as cable's highest-rated drama.

Dr. Jack Shephard, played by Matthew Fox, is the main character in the American TV show *Lost*.  *Lost*, which aired on ABC from September 22, 2004 to May 23, 2010, had six seasons and 121 episodes.  The first season averaged 16 million viewers per episode.

Matthew McConaughey, born November 4, 1969, is an American actor who has starred in films such as *The Lincoln Lawyer*, *Bernie*, *Killer Joe*, *The Paperboy*, *Mud*, *Magic Mike*, *The Wolf of Wall Street*, *Dallas Buyers Club*, *Interstellar*, *The Sea of Trees*, and *Free State of Jones*.  *Mud* (2012) also stars Tye Sheridan, Jacob Lofland, Sam Shepard, and Reese Witherspoon.

Robert Palmer was a writer, music journalist (for the *New York Times* and *Rolling Stone*), blues recording producer, and clarinet player (for the Insect Trust).  He is best known for his books, including *Deep Blues*, and producing the soundtrack for the film of the same name.

James Lincoln de la Mothe Borglum (1912-1986) was an American sculptor, photographer, author, and engineer who took over the Mount Rushmore National Memorial project after his father, Gutzon Borglum, died in 1941.  Gutzon Borglum had designed and overseen the project from 1927-1941 with Lincoln's help.

The film *Underdog*, directed by Frederik Du Chau, was written by Joe Piscatella, Adam Rifkin, and Craig A. Williams.  Starring Jim Belushi, Peter Dinklage, John Slattery, and Patrick Warburton, it features the voice talents of Jason Lee, Amy Adams, and Brad Garrett.

The 100 is a TV series following a group of teens and adults from a space habitat called "The Ark" who return to Earth after a nuclear apocalypse.  The teen group includes Clarke, Bellamy, Octavia, Jasper, Monty, Raven, Finn, Murphy, and Wells.  Adults featured include Clarke's mother, Abby; council member Marcus Kane; and Chancellor Thelonious Jaha.
The Concert for Bangladesh was a successful humanitarian aid project that raised awareness and funds.  Despite initial financial difficulties, it inspired later projects like Live Aid.
Mani Ratnam is a highly influential Indian filmmaker credited with revolutionizing the Tamil film industry and changing Indian cinema.

The Freeport Doctrine, articulated by Stephen Douglas during the second of the Lincoln-Douglas debates on August 27, 1858, in Freeport, Illinois, was one of seven debates between Douglas and Abraham Lincoln.  These debates drew large crowds from neighboring states because the issue of slavery was so significant.

The 2010 American teen comedy film, *Easy A*, was directed by Will Gluck and written by Bert V. Royal.  Starring Emma Stone, Stanley Tucci, Patricia Clarkson, Thomas Haden Church, Dan Byrd, Amanda Bynes, Penn Badgley, Cam Gigandet, Lisa Kudrow, and Aly Michalka.

Anne Rice, born Howard Allen Frances O'Brien on October 4, 1941, is an American author known for gothic fiction, Christian literature, and erotica.  She started her writing career with *Interview with the Vampire* (1976) and wrote sequels in the 1980s.  Initially receiving mixed reviews, she gained popularity in the 1980s.  She was married to Stan Rice for 41 years.

Camden, New Jersey, the 12th most populous municipality in the state, had a population of 77,344 at the 2010 Census.  At the start of the 20th century, its population primarily comprised European immigrants.
Bret Easton Ellis wrote the screenplay for the 2013 film *The Canyons*, directed by Paul Schrader.  *The Canyons* is an American erotic thriller-drama.

The Lincoln-Douglas Debates, also known as The Great Debates of 1858, were a series of seven debates between Abraham Lincoln, the Republican candidate, and Stephen Douglas, the Democratic candidate, for the U.S. Senate from Illinois.  The debates took place in seven Illinois towns.

Homer, attributed by ancient Greeks as the author of the Iliad and the Odyssey, is considered the central figure of ancient Greek literature.  The Thicket is a mystery/suspense novel written by Joe R. Lansdale.
Christopher Scott Kyle, a United States Navy SEAL veteran and sniper, was murdered on February 2, 2013, at a Texas shooting range by Eddie Ray Routh.

Audioslave was a band formed by Chris Cornell (lead singer/rhythm guitarist of Soundgarden) and the members of Rage Against the Machine: Tom Morello (lead guitar), Tim Commerford (bass/backing vocals), and Brad Wilk (drums).  Brad Wilk also played with Rage Against the Machine (1991-2000, 2007-2011) and currently plays in Prophets of Rage. Rage Against the Machine was formed in 1991 and included Zack de la Rocha (vocalist), Tim Commerford, Tom Morello, and Brad Wilk.

Janelle Monáe Robinson, born December 1, 1985, is an American singer, songwriter, actress, and model.  She is signed to her own imprint, Wondaland Arts Society, and Atlantic Records.  Her critically acclaimed first studio album, *The ArchAndroid*, a concept album and sequel to her first EP, was released in 2010 by Bad Boy Records.
"Winter's Tale" is a novel written by Mark Helprin in 1983.

Lake Providence is a town in East Carroll Parish, Louisiana, and is the parish seat.  The University of Mississippi has a student body where 55% of undergraduates and 60% of the overall student body are from Mississippi.  23% of students are minorities, and international students represent 90 nations.
In July 2016, the series *Flaked* was renewed for a six-episode second season, premiering June 2, 2017.

Aaron Burr served in the New York State Assembly (1784-1785, 1798-1799), as New York State Attorney General (1789-1791), and as a U.S. senator from New York (1791-1797).  He also served as Vice President of the United States.

Soyuz is a spacecraft series designed by the Korolyov Design Bureau in the 1960s for the Soviet space program.  It replaced the Voskhod spacecraft and was initially developed for Soviet lunar missions.  After eight unmanned test flights, it launched its first manned mission.  It remains in use today.
Steve Ditko studied at the Cartoonist and Illustrators School in New York City under Batman artist Jerry Robinson.

In 2000, Rage Against the Machine released their fourth studio album, *Renegades*.  Growing tensions caused Zack de la Rocha to leave the band the same year, leading to their breakup.  De la Rocha pursued a solo career, while the remaining members formed Audioslave with Chris Cornell.  Audioslave disbanded in 2007, the same year Rage Against the Machine reunited and performed at Coachella.

The S&P BSE SENSEX, also known as the BSE 30 or SENSEX, is a free-float market-weighted stock market index of 30 established companies listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange.  Tata Motors is one such company, listed on the BSE, NSE, and NYSE, and is a constituent of the SENSEX.

Vietnam, officially the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, is located in Southeast Asia on the Indochina Peninsula.  It is the world’s 14th most populous country, with approximately 92.7 million inhabitants.  Bordering countries include China, Laos, Cambodia, and Thailand.  Since 2000, Vietnam has experienced high economic growth, and in 2011, it ranked highest on the Global Growth Generators Index among 11 major economies.  Vietnam is one of four remaining one-party socialist states.
"Dreamer," a 2005 American sports drama film, was written and directed by John Gatins.  This was Gatins' directorial debut.

Bhagat Singh, an Indian socialist revolutionary, was executed at age 23 after committing two acts of violence against the British in India.  His death made him a popular folk hero of the Indian independence movement.
Aparshakti Khurana's Bollywood debut was in the 2016 film *Dangal*, a biographical sports drama directed by Nitesh Tiwari.

James VI and I reigned as King of Scotland from July 24, 1567, and as King of England and Ireland from March 24, 1603, until his death on March 27, 1625.  Although he ruled both Scotland and England in a personal union, they remained individual sovereign states with separate parliaments, judiciaries, and laws.  He desired a single parliament for both countries and faced many challenges with the English Parliament during his reign.

Danielle Cormack, a New Zealand actress, is known for her roles in *Shortland Street*, *Xena: Warrior Princess*, *The Cult*, *Legend of the Seeker*, *Separation City*, *Rake*, and *Underbelly: Razor*.  She is also notable for her four-year role as Bea Smith in the television series *Wentworth*.
Rob Sheridan, born October 11, 1979, is an American graphic designer, director, and photographer known for his work with Nine Inch Nails.

David Spade acted in several films, including *Tommy Boy*, *Black Sheep*, *Joe Dirt*, *Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser*, *Grown Ups*, and *Grown Ups 2*.  *Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser*, a 2015 film, was directed by Fred Wolf and written by David Spade and Fred Wolf.
Angela Bassett is an American actress born on August 16, 1958.

Artpop, Gaga's album, debuted at number one on the United States Billboard 200, selling 258,000 copies its first week and 757,000 copies total.  It was the ninth best-selling album of 2013, with 2.3 million copies sold worldwide.  Critical reception was mixed.
John Frusciante's fifth and final album with the Red Hot Chili Peppers, *Stadium Arcadium*, was released in 2006.  Frusciante left the band in 2009.

Margaret Thatcher served as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom and implemented policies known as Thatcherism.  A controversial figure, she is considered by some to be one of Britain's most influential politicians, though debate over Thatcherism continues.

Michael Andrew "Duff" McKagan, born February 5, 1964, is an American musician, singer, songwriter, and author.  Beyond music, he's a writer with weekly columns for SeattleWeekly.com, Playboy.com, and ESPN.com.
Tom Baker is an English actor who has also done narration work for commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.

Valencia, the capital of the Valencian Community, is the third largest city in Spain, with about 800,000 inhabitants in its administrative center and a metropolitan area population ranging from 1.7 to 2.5 million.  The Valencian Community is an autonomous community of Spain.
Buffy Summers was portrayed by Kristy Swanson in the film and Sarah Michelle Gellar in the television series.
On April 26, 2012, it was announced that the third season of *Make It or Break It* would be its last.  The series finale aired on May 14, 2012.

Speech recognition (SR) is a subfield of computational linguistics that translates spoken language into text.  It uses linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering.  Applications include voice user interfaces, search, data entry, and speech-to-text processing.  The field is experiencing growth due to the adoption of deep learning methods by companies such as Google, Microsoft, IBM, Baidu, Apple, Amazon, Nuance, SoundHound, IflyTek, and CDAC.

Richard Alf, an American businessman and former comic book store owner, co-founded San Diego Comic-Con International in 1970 and served as its chairman.  Initially called the Golden State Comic Book Convention, it was founded by Alf, Shel Dorf, Ken Krueger, and Mike Towry.
*Fist of Legend* is a remake of the 1972 film *Fist of Fury*, which starred Bruce Lee.

France's Dubuisson and South Africa's Van Zyl are tied for the lead at 16 under par.  McIlroy is in third at 15 under par after shooting a 67 for the third straight day.  Despite some early mistakes, including throwing his putter, McIlroy finished strong with an eagle on the 12th.  He is aiming for his first title since May and a third Race to Dubai title in four years.  He currently leads Willett by 271,214 points with three events remaining.  Wood and Bland, who were tied for second, are now fifth and seventh respectively.

Sheikh Ali Salman advocates for a meaningful national dialogue in Bahrain, requiring concrete solutions from the government and representation from the royal family.  While welcoming dialogue, he acknowledges that many young protesters have lost faith in the opposition.  He believes working with reformists, such as Crown Prince Salman, is key, referencing a prior seven-point plan that was disrupted by the arrival of GCC troops.  He expresses hope for increased US pressure for human rights under Secretary of State John Kerry and urges the UK to publicly condemn human rights abuses instead of relying on private conversations.  Finally, he insists on peaceful demonstrations and the release of imprisoned opposition leaders for the dialogue to succeed.

Christopher Hogwood, a leading figure in the early-music movement, passed away at his Cambridge home after a long illness.  He founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973, leading it for 30 years across six continents and producing over 200 CDs.  His notable achievements include a renowned recording of Handel's Messiah and significant roles with various orchestras and universities.  Tributes from colleagues highlight his generosity, influence on the early-music movement, and impact on musicians worldwide.  His funeral will be private, with a later memorial service.

In Scotland, from March 2015-2016, there were 57 homicide cases, the lowest number recorded since 1976.  This is half the number of homicides recorded nine years prior.  A sharp instrument, most often a knife, was the most common murder weapon, used in 29 of the 57 cases.  Thirty-one percent of the accused were under the influence of alcohol or drugs.  While the overall trend is encouraging,  concerns remain about the accuracy of the data and increases in other violent crimes, such as sexual crimes and attempted murder.

Bournemouth lost their first game to Sunderland this season with a score of 2-1.  Dan Gosling scored Bournemouth's only goal, their first in three games.  Despite creating many scoring opportunities in the past two games, Bournemouth failed to score, losing to goals by Victor Anichebe and a Jermain Defoe penalty.  Even after Steven Pienaar's dismissal, Bournemouth could not equalize.

To prevent migrants from dying at sea, Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott asserts that the only solution is to stop the boats bringing them to the country.  Australia detains migrants arriving by boat in offshore processing camps for resettlement.  The New York Times criticized this policy as "brutal," "inhumane," and illegal, while Abbott, though saddened by the image of Alan Kurdi, a three-year-old Syrian boy who died at sea, maintains that stopping the boats is the only way to stop the deaths.  Abbott also sparked controversy by claiming that ISIS is worse than the Nazis, a statement that Australian Jewish groups deemed injudicious.

The US blames Russia and the Syrian government for escalating attacks on civilians, suspending talks with Russia due to their failure to uphold commitments, particularly concerning Aleppo.  Russia denies responsibility and accuses the US of shirking its obligations.  The main hospital in the rebel-held eastern part of Aleppo was hit by airstrikes for the third time in a week.  Hundreds of civilians, including children, have died since the offensive began.  Approximately 250,000 people are trapped in eastern Aleppo.  While the US has suspended participation in bilateral channels with Russia, both sides will continue discussions on counter-terrorism operations to prevent clashes.

Policy Exchange proposed selling high-value social homes to fund a large social housing construction program.  The plan could generate £4.5 billion annually, enough to build 80,000–170,000 social homes.  Supporters argue this would be fairer, providing housing for more people. Critics, however, contend this would displace low-income families from affluent neighborhoods, creating segregated communities.  The government stated councils already have the option to sell high-value homes and should utilize their housing stock efficiently.  Labour proposed using a bank bonus tax to fund 250,000 affordable homes instead.

25-year-old Gareth Colfer-Williams died at his home in Swansea, a city experiencing a measles epidemic with 942 cases.  While lab tests confirmed measles, the cause of death is undetermined, pending further tests.  Since November, the outbreak has hospitalized 83 people.  Mr. Colfer-Williams had recently been treated for asthma and developed a rash before his death.  His family is unsure how he contracted measles, as no close family members have the illness.

Vincent Hudson (54) of Loweswater Avenue, Whitehaven, has been charged with a historical offense against a boy under 16.  The alleged attack reportedly occurred in 2001, and Hudson will appear before North Cumbria Magistrates' Court.

Gateshead and Guiseley ended in a 1-1 draw.  Guiseley's Jake Lawlor scored first, assisted by James Hurst. Gateshead's Wes York equalized in the second half after a slip by Guiseley's Derek Asamoah.  Prior to the match, Guiseley had a nine-game unbeaten streak and Gateshead had a five-game unbeaten streak.

Bristol Sport Ltd plans to replace two stands at the football club to increase capacity.  This plan, approved by Bristol City Council in November, is an alternative to building a new stadium.  Work is expected to begin in May, following a six-week judicial review period after the section 106 agreement is signed.

Fracking operations in Lancashire, England have been temporarily suspended following a 1.5 magnitude tremor, the second in two months.  Cuadrilla, the company conducting the fracking, will review data from the British Geological Survey (BGS) before resuming operations. The BGS reported that the tremor was similar in location and mechanism to a previous tremor.  The process of fracking involves shattering shale rocks to release gas.  While fracking has caused controversy in the US due to environmental concerns, a UK parliamentary committee has advocated for its support with proper regulation.  The BGS is monitoring the situation.

Angus Carpenter, a 62-year-old busker from Liverpool, was found guilty of one count of fraud for using a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner while busking in April 2015.  He was cleared of two other fraud charges.  Carpenter claimed the banner was a tribute, not a fundraising tool, despite having received permission to create the banner from the charity's chairman.  He will be sentenced in January.

Ipswich Town defeated Queens Park Rangers 3-0.  Grant Ward and Luke Varney scored for Ipswich, with Tom Lawrence adding a third goal.  QPR's Alex Smithies misplayed a clearance leading to Varney's goal.  Despite several scoring opportunities, Ipswich had previously struggled to score in their last 10 games.  The win moved Ipswich to 14th place, while QPR remained in 15th.  Both managers commented on the match, with Ipswich's manager highlighting Smithies' error and QPR's manager criticizing his team's mental toughness and defensive positioning.

In the T20 Blast last season, 23-year-old Wells scored 373 runs at a strike rate of 138.66 and an average of 28.69.  He noted the club's positive direction, citing the coaches' creation of an elite performance environment as a key factor in players' motivation.

In their second consecutive win, the Reds (fifth in National Two South) defeated third-placed Chinnor with a score of 29-12.  Their success was largely due to the strong performance of Phillips, Priddey, and Williams.  The Reds' upcoming matches include seven games against lower-ranked teams and a game against the league leaders, Old Elthamians.  Despite the win, Churcher believes there is significant room for improvement.

On March 14th, a 74-year-old nun was raped at a convent in Ranaghat, India, after thieves ransacked the building and stole money.  Police have arrested six suspects, including 28-year-old Nazrul (also known as Nazu), who is alleged to be the rapist.  Two suspects remain at large.  Nazrul, a Bangladeshi citizen, was arrested in Kolkata after fleeing to Bangladesh.  The incident sparked widespread protests across India.

This interactive video, created by Robert Opie, founder of the Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising in London, explains reasons behind changes in UK consumer purchasing habits.  Factors such as the introduction of home freezers, washing powder, and cheaper imports are highlighted.  The video also explores shifts in brand ownership and rankings. A non-interactive version is available for users with incompatible browsers.  Additional information is linked, covering Chinese ownership of brands, freezing food tips, and a BBC survey ranking top UK brands.

Two incidents occurred where elderly women were tricked into giving money to callers who falsely claimed to be from BT.  The first incident happened in Sandyhills on September 15th, and the second in Stranraer seven days later.  In both cases, the callers gained remote access to the victims' computers to steal money. Police warn against giving banking details or account numbers over the phone and advise caution when granting remote access to computers.

37-year-old Lee Duffy signed a one-year contract with Featherstone Rovers after leaving Swinton Lions.  Duffy, who has 16 years of playing experience, will coach Featherstone's final league game against Toulouse before the Super 8 Qualifiers.  His former assistant, Stuart Littler, replaced him at Swinton.

On Sunday at 12:50 GMT, a horse rider was found unconscious on Sker Beach near Kenfig Nature Reserve with head injuries and hypothermia.  A Porthcawl RNLI crew, a medic, and a coastguard helicopter responded, providing treatment before airlifting her to Cardiff's University Hospital of Wales.

At a UN conference in Geneva, over 160 countries agreed to dedicate a radio frequency for a global satellite tracking system for aircraft, using ADS-B transmissions.  This decision, spurred by the disappearance of MH370 in March 2014, aims to improve upon the current system, which leaves 70% of airspace uncovered.  The new system will allow real-time tracking of aircraft worldwide.  The International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) has set a November 2016 deadline for adopting new tracking guidelines.

Julian Hernandez, who went missing at age five, has been found at age 18 living in Cleveland with his father, Bobby Hernandez.  Bobby was arrested in Ohio and charged with tampering with records to obtain a driver's license and is being held on $250,000 bail.  Authorities suspected the father's involvement since Julian's disappearance in 2002.  The FBI received a tip leading to Julian's identification and his mother has been notified.

On March 2, a fire at Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited in Duncan Street caused service delays and prompted a multi-day response from firefighters.  The Environment Agency (EA) suspended the company from accepting waste, though the fire service noted it was "broadly compliant" with fire safety laws.  The EA will revoke the environmental permit on August 7 unless appealed.  The company must remove all waste.  The fire's cause is undetermined.

Two bills proposed by A Just Russia, a pro-Kremlin party, aim to expedite the process of incorporating territories from neighboring states into the Russian Federation and to fast-track Russian passport issuance for Ukrainians.  The bills cite the situation in Ukraine, particularly Crimea, as justification.  One bill would allow for the annexation of territories whose populations express a desire to join Russia, even without a treaty with the neighboring state. The second bill would streamline Russian passport applications for Ukrainians, eliminating fees and residency requirements.  The stated goal is to support Russian-speaking Ukrainians.  Several Russian MPs and celebrities have visited Crimea.

McLaren's Formula 1 team, with a history of 182 Grand Prix wins, 12 drivers' world championships, and eight constructors' titles, is currently experiencing a slump.  Their struggles began in 2013 with chassis design issues, despite having a superior engine. Now, while the car's performance has improved, the Honda engine is hindering their progress.  Past successes include dominating the 1988 season with Ayrton Senna and Alain Prost, and winning constructors' titles in 1998 and (almost) 2007, although the latter was lost due to a scandal involving Ferrari's technical information.  The team has faced several scandals and periods of decline throughout its history, but Ron Dennis, the team's principal, believes McLaren will overcome its current challenges and regain its former glory, with Alonso's return in 2015 signifying this hope.

On January 27, 44-year-old Thomas Baker was shot in the head and chest outside Stanley Meat Market in Liverpool.  Three men, ages 29, 29, and 32, are in custody. Police are searching for a silver VW Polo that fled the scene and are asking witnesses to come forward.

Here are five ways to enjoy Christmas online: 1) Everyday Church Online offers virtual services with sermons and chat rooms. 2) Guardians of Ancora, a fantasy game, includes Christmas-themed quests. 3) Viral.de's "The Digital Story of Nativity" video uses social media to tell the Christmas story. 4) The Churches Advertising Network's "Christmas Starts with a Baby's Giggle" ad shows the Christmas story across different eras. 5) Next Manga offers the nativity story in Manga form, with 25,000 Arabic copies sent to refugees.  Many groups also use social media to connect with their communities during Christmas.

A Welsh government inquiry is underway to determine whether 250 hectares of common land can be used for a motorsports development.  The developers offered 320 hectares of replacement land, but experts disagree on whether the replacement land is equal in value and whether the development will negatively impact habitats.  The Planning Inspectorate for Wales will make a recommendation to the Welsh government, which will make the final decision.

Following a report from Novaya Gazeta that over 100 people were detained in Chechnya for being homosexual, with at least three killed, Chechen Muslim clerics met to discuss the report, calling for “reprisals against journalists.”  The Russian LGBT Network confirmed the report, stating that detainees were tortured.  Ramzan Kadyrov denied the allegations, claiming there are no gay people in Chechnya.  Novaya Gazeta’s editor stated that they did not intend to insult the Chechen people and urged dialogue.  The LGBT Network is assisting victims in fleeing and will file a case at the International Criminal Court if Russia fails to act.

Investing Solutions, a letting agency, and Fresh Start Housing, a charity, both located in the same south London building, are under scrutiny for their practices.  Investing Solutions receives substantial housing benefit payments, primarily from Wandsworth Council (£2.1 million over two years), by placing single homeless men (over 35) in private rooms.  The agency profits by charging more in housing benefit than they pay landlords.  While both entities deny illegality, a homeless group criticizes their relationship.  A former tenant described unsuitable living conditions, and the agency's focus appears to be profit over tenant well-being.  The Department for Communities and Local Government states that local authorities are responsible for safeguarding taxpayer money.

Great Britain played against the Netherlands in a final warm-up game before the Eurobasket qualifying campaign.  Andrew Lawrence and Ben Gordon led the scoring for Great Britain with 14 and 13 points respectively.  Great Britain led for most of the game, but the Netherlands scored the first 10 points of the fourth quarter to take the lead and win, 71-60.  Despite the loss, Coach Prunty was pleased with Gordon's performance and emphasized the importance of consistent effort in the upcoming qualifying games.  Great Britain's next game is in Hungary.

On Wednesday, hours before the deadline, former five-weight world champion McGregor submitted a waiver to the Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) to allow the use of 8oz gloves in his upcoming fight with Mayweather.  The NAC will debate the matter on August 16.  Mayweather will come out of retirement for the bout, which has been approved by the NAC, despite criticism from boxing personalities.  The NAC director, Bob Bennett, based his approval on McGregor's fighting history, including his wins over Nate Diaz, and his assessment of McGregor's boxing skills.  McGregor's camp hired Joe Cortez as a boxing referee.  A sparring partner, Paulie Malignaggi, left the camp after a sparring session.

The Sunday Post's London office closure marks the end of an era for Fleet Street, once the heart of British journalism.  For centuries, nearly every national newspaper had offices there, creating a vibrant atmosphere filled with pubs and social gatherings.  However, Rupert Murdoch's move to Wapping in 1986, along with technological advancements, led to the decline of Fleet Street.  The last two journalists, Gavin Sherriff and Darryl Smith, have left, ending Fleet Street's role as a center for British journalism.

J.K. Rowling, author of the Harry Potter series,  tweeted that she had been called a traitor for her political views and had blocked abusive Twitter users she believed to be supporters of the Scottish National Party (SNP).  She had previously donated £1 million to the Labour party in 2008 and the same amount to the campaign for a No vote in the Scottish independence referendum last year.  Rowling stated that she feels no responsibility to quiet abusive behavior to protect the image of any political party.  She also noted that she had responded to other nice SNP supporters and that she had much in common politically with many of them.  Rowling joked about bringing marshmallows after a Twitter user suggested that her books should be burned.  The SNP won 56 of 59 Scottish seats in the recent election, becoming the third largest party in the UK.

Researchers found that children from deprived backgrounds are more likely to be involved in crime and violence than wealthier children.  A history of police involvement strongly predicts lack of education, employment, or training by age 18.  Poverty increases the likelihood of being both a victim and perpetrator of crime.  Boys are three times more likely to be violent than girls, and girls from poorer backgrounds are twice as likely to be involved in violent crime than wealthier girls.  Despite an overall decrease in crime rates in Scotland, the most deprived communities continue to experience the highest crime rates, raising concerns about inequality.

25-year-old Karl Haugh was stabbed and killed in the Marian estate in Kilkee in the early hours of Sunday.  Robbie Walsh was charged with assault causing serious harm and remanded in custody until August 14. Two other men arrested were released without charge.  Police allege Walsh was one of three who sought out Haugh, resulting in a fight with weapons.  Knives and golf clubs were recovered at the scene.

In May 2014, Fermanagh MLA Phil Flanagan tweeted false statements about Tom Elliott, who served in the UDR from 1982-1992, and is now the MP for Fermanagh and South Tyrone.  After being notified of the tweet by Ann Travers and Arlene Foster, Flanagan deleted the tweet within an hour and issued an apology.  The High Court heard that Elliott has a clear MoD record.  Flanagan's insurance company refused to cover him for compensation and costs, a decision he is challenging separately.  Elliott stated he is pleased with the outcome.

Hawick Knitwear, established in 1874 and purchased by Benny Hartop in November of last year, has increased sweater production from 7,500 to 9,500 per week. This rise is due to better-than-expected sales of its new brand launched in January and growth in its private label business.  The company employs over 230 staff and exports to various European and non-European countries including the USA, Canada, Mexico, and Japan.

72-year-old Sylvia Blackburn, a lollipop lady of 20 years, suffered serious head injuries when she was struck by Brian Wright's car outside Bedford Road Lower School.  Wright, who denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving, claims he was blinded by the setting sun and didn't see the red light.  Blackburn is now in residential care.

NATO conducted a submarine hunting exercise, “Dynamic Mongoose”, to prepare for anti-submarine warfare.  The exercise involved locating a German submarine, U33, acting as an unseen enemy, using 10 warships, anti-submarine helicopters, and underwater drones.  The exercise highlighted a critical gap in Britain’s defenses, as they lack long-range maritime patrol aircraft, unlike their NATO allies, leaving them vulnerable to Russian submarines.  Russia has been investing heavily in its submarine fleet, which is considered technologically advanced and a significant threat.  Britain’s lack of maritime patrol aircraft is a key vulnerability, allowing Russian submarines to potentially track Britain’s nuclear deterrent.

Since violence erupted in South Sudan in July, 340,000 people have fled to Uganda, surpassing the number of refugees from Syria in 2016.  The violence involves killings, rape, and the targeting of civilians along ethnic lines, with the Dinka tribe attacking the Equatorians and Nuer.  Refugees describe horrific experiences, including murder and rape.  While Uganda has been supportive, providing land and supplies, the influx is straining resources, and the UNHCR is calling for international attention and pressure on South Sudanese leaders to end the violence.

On November 12, at York Hall, 38-year-old boxer, McKenzie, will fight Jahmaine Smyle for the English super-middleweight championship.  McKenzie, formerly a football player, began his boxing career in 2013. His record is eight wins and one draw.  He is the son of former champion Clinton McKenzie and is trained by his uncle, three-time world champion Duke McKenzie.

The new Bridgwater Community Hospital, costing £33m, will include 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery unit, a minor injury unit, and X-ray and mobile scanner space.  Funding comes from a £330m national investment, with the remainder covered by NHS Somerset and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust.  The current hospital, built in 1813, is outdated and cramped.  Construction is planned for Bowers Lane (pending planning permission) with completion aimed for autumn 2014.

A man was fatally shot in the chest outside a property on Daniel Hill Terrace in Sheffield, close to a black Mercedes he had been driving.  Police responded at approximately 1:35 pm GMT and the victim was transported to Northern General Hospital where he died.  The victim was a local resident, and the shooting occurred during a family gathering. While there have been other shootings in Sheffield recently, they were all in the northern part of the city.

Ukrainian Cyber Troops, Cyber Berkut, and Anonymous International are three prominent groups engaging in cyber warfare, presenting themselves as independent activists.  Ukrainian Cyber Troops, led by Yevhen Dokukin, utilize DDoS attacks, targeting rebel websites and financial accounts.  They also monitor CCTV systems and printed pro-Ukrainian messages. Cyber Berkut, an anti-Western group, aims to disrupt Ukraine's military plans, hacking government websites and displaying anti-Ukrainian messages. Anonymous International, also known as b0ltai or Shaltay Boltay, publishes leaked documents, focusing on Russia's domestic affairs but also covering Ukraine.  The Ukrainian military denies using hacker-obtained data to direct artillery fire.

Tricia Marwick, Duncan McNeil, and Alex Salmond are among the MSPs leaving office before the May 5th election.  Salmond, in his farewell speech, reiterated his belief that Scotland is diverse, not divided, and welcomed the transfer of powers to Holyrood via the Scotland Bill, though he felt it didn’t fulfill unionist campaign promises.  McNeil, in his own farewell, warned Holyrood to learn from Westminster’s committee system to ensure accountability and scrutiny.  Annabel Goldie also delivered a farewell speech.

Sarah Rochira, Older People’s Commissioner for Wales, is conducting a review of the quality of life and care of older people in residential care in Wales.  She will gather information from pensioners, their families, care providers, social care staff, and public bodies to understand the impact of both good and poor care.  The review will consider physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment.  While Care Forum Wales supports the review’s aims, they are disappointed that the advisory panel lacks representation from care home providers.

In the year ending June 2016, Harbro Group's pre-tax profit rose to £3.5 million, an increase of £800,000, despite a £1 million decrease in turnover to approximately £100 million.  International sales increased, and the company, which manufactures and supplies animal feed and operates 19 Country Store retail locations, anticipates navigating future agricultural challenges, including Brexit.

Police found a deceased man in his 70s at a Nettleden Road home.  Another man, in his 80s, was hospitalized.  Police are searching for 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin (also known as Ian John Baker) in connection with the murder.  McLoughlin is described as a white male, approximately 6ft tall, with greying hair, average build, and was last seen wearing sunglasses, blue jeans or three-quarter length trousers, and a dark blue, light blue and white checked short-sleeved shirt.  Police urge anyone with information to contact them or Crimestoppers.

David Lipton, the IMF's second in command, recently gave a speech outlining risks to the global economy.  He stated that the IMF's latest reading shows a weakening baseline and that the global economy is at a delicate juncture.  This follows weaker-than-expected trade figures from China, showing exports plummeted by 25% year-over-year.  The IMF will likely downgrade its current global growth forecast of 3.4% in April.

Due to many issues, the Cowes ferry crossing will be free until July 2.  Since its launch on May 14, the ferry has had several issues, including breakdowns, running aground, and suspension by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency due to training issues.  Cars have also been damaged.  The council has ordered a review of the project by auditors and is discussing compensation for local businesses impacted by the ferry's problems.  A councilor stated that the issues were teething problems for a prototype and that electrical and grounding problems have been resolved.  Ramp extensions have also been authorized to prevent vehicles from scraping the concrete.

On Thursday, at approximately 7:30 a.m., a multi-vehicle crash occurred on the southbound carriageway near the Hindhead tunnel in Bramshott.  A 32-year-old man died at the scene. A 33-year-old man from Waterlooville was arrested and charged with causing death by driving without due care and attention.  The road was closed from Thursley to Liphook until early evening for investigation.

Matching Models, an international temp agency, is under fire for job postings deemed discriminatory by the Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC).  The EHRC and women’s equality campaigners criticized ads seeking a personal assistant with specific physical attributes ("classic look, brown long hair with b-c cup") and a "sexy female driver," calling them unlawful and reminiscent of the 1970s.  The agency's founder defended the requirements, citing client preferences, while an employment lawyer stated the ads were clearly unlawful and opened the agency to lawsuits.  The 2010 Equality Act prohibits such discriminatory practices.  Despite criticism, Matching Models maintains that looks matter to clients and cites examples of clients with diverse hiring preferences.

On Tuesday evening, Mahesh, an office assistant at the Pragati Residential School in Bangalore, shot and killed 18-year-old Gautami and injured another student, Sirisha, in a hostel attached to the school.  Police arrested Mahesh on Wednesday, and he was remanded until April 12th.  The motive is unclear, and such incidents are rare in India.

Between June 2016 and May 2017, there were 278 recurring LGBT characters on television.  The number of transgender characters increased from seven to sixteen.  However, over 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters were killed off.  Additionally, there was a record high percentage of black characters on broadcast television.

David Mackintosh, the Conservative MP for Northampton South, announced he would not seek re-election.  This follows a police investigation into the disappearance of £10.25 million in public funds loaned to Northampton Town FC when Mr. Mackintosh was the borough council leader.  The loan was for stadium renovations and land development; the stadium remains unfinished.  Mr. Mackintosh denies wrongdoing, but faced likely deselection by his local party.

In April, Roy Oliver, 37, shot and killed Jordan Edwards, 15, who was in a car leaving a party in Balch Springs, Texas.  Oliver, who was fired for policy violations a few days later, was indicted on a murder charge and four counts of aggravated assault.  The initial police report that the car reversed aggressively towards the officer was disproven by video footage.  Oliver faces five to 99 years in prison; if convicted, he would be the first Dallas County police officer convicted of murder since 1973.  He is currently free on bail.

Melania Trump's decision to not immediately move to the White House with her son Barron has drawn criticism on social media.  Only two other First Ladies, Martha Washington and Anna Harrison, did not live in the White House during their husbands' presidencies.  However, it's not uncommon for children of presidents to remain in their previous homes to finish the school year.  The role of First Lady is largely ceremonial, though in recent times, they have also taken on public roles and causes.  While Melania Trump's priorities are currently unknown, she has expressed interest in tackling cyberbullying.  Past First Ladies have balanced their duties with family life, and there is precedent for family members taking on some of the First Lady's responsibilities.

On October 27th of this year, a 72-year-old man was found dead in Inverness at a sheltered housing complex.  The Police Investigations and Review Commissioner (Pirc) will investigate the police’s initial response to a call from the man.  Police Scotland is cooperating with the investigation, and a report will be submitted to the Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service (COPFS).

A yellow warning was issued for strong winds, with gusts potentially reaching 75mph (120kmph), primarily west of the mountains.  The unusual easterly wind direction may worsen the impact. Travel disruptions are anticipated, and Telford Road in Menai Bridge, Anglesey, will remain closed most of Monday due to a fallen tree.  Affected counties include Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion, and Powys.

The Giants and Panthers played a close game that ended with a 4-3 victory for the Giants.  The teams will play again on Saturday.  Nottingham leads the league with 28 points, followed by Sheffield Steelers (27) and Belfast (25).

Lewis Hamilton started the Chinese Grand Prix from the back of the pack, and despite a damaged front wing and five pit stops, he fought his way up to third place.  His teammate, Nico Rosberg, won the race, extending his points lead to 36 points over Hamilton with 18 races remaining.  Sebastian Vettel finished second for Ferrari, despite a first-lap collision with Kimi Raikkonen, who recovered to fifth place.  Ricciardo took the lead initially but had to pit due to a puncture, allowing Rosberg to take the lead and win.  Hamilton's car sustained damage affecting its aerodynamic performance.

Thomas Hitzlsperger, a prominent German footballer, publicly revealed his homosexuality, a decision praised by former teammates, football officials, and politicians.  His announcement is considered a watershed moment in German football, which, like England, has struggled with homophobia.  While some, like former German captain Philipp Lahm, previously advised gay footballers to remain silent, Hitzlsperger's courageous step is hoped to encourage greater openness and acceptance of homosexuality in the sport.

34-year-old midfielder, Sidwell, has helped Brighton achieve promotion to the Premier League for the first time in 34 years.  His contract expires at the end of the season, but he wants to sign a new deal to stay with the team.  He has played 32 Championship games this season and believes he deserves another chance to play in the Premier League, having previously played for Reading, Chelsea, Aston Villa, Fulham, and Stoke.

Blackpool and Colchester United tied 1-1.  Jamille Matt scored the first goal for Blackpool, and Kurtis Guthrie equalized for Colchester.  Colchester ended the game with 10 men after Sean Murray received a red card.  Several other cards were given throughout the match, and Blackpool missed several scoring opportunities.

29-year-old,  Reíd, played 37 games for the Sky Blues last season before their relegation from League One.  He has also played for Charlton, Bradford, and Preston.  Reid may debut with the U's Wednesday against Aston Villa in the EFL Cup. Colchester's season began with a 3-1 loss to Accrington.

In March, the murder of PC Keith Palmer outside the Houses of Parliament prompted a greater need for a permanent memorial.  The UK Police Memorial Trust is appealing for £1.5 million to construct a memorial at the National Memorial Arboretum, which will list over 1,400 officers and staff.  Home Secretary Amber Rudd pledged £1 million towards the £4 million needed for the memorial, which is expected to be completed by 2019.

Manchester United beat Sunderland 1-0, extending their lead to 15 points with eight games remaining.  Manager Ferguson is focused on the next game, the Manchester derby, and is unconcerned with past records, despite the team's 25 wins in 30 matches and 50 points from their last 18 games.  Injuries to Rafael, Anderson, and David De Gea will result in changes for the upcoming FA Cup replay against Chelsea.  Wayne Rooney may also be rested due to fatigue from international duty.  Ryan Giggs and Javier Hernandez will be available.

Google paid £10 million in UK corporate taxes from 2006-2011, an amount Google chairman Eric Schmidt claims is legally compliant.  He argues that changing tax laws is the government’s responsibility, not corporations’, and that Google will comply with any changes.  A new committee is proposed to oversee tax arrangements of major firms, prompted by criticism of multinationals like Google minimizing UK tax payments by routing sales through Ireland.  The EU is also working to tackle tax avoidance through information exchange between tax authorities.  Schmidt has advocated for corporate taxes to be levied where economic activity occurs, not just where products are consumed, and called for international tax reform.

NHS Improvement sought to reduce the agency bill by £1bn by the end of the fiscal year, from £3.6bn the previous year.  A cap introduced in October saved £600m, but the NHS is still 10% short of its goal.  While progress is promising, it is unclear if spending in other areas of the pay bill has increased.  The regulator will publish league tables of best and worst performing trusts later this year, and will collect data on the 20 highest-earning agency staff per trust due to suspicions of inflated agency fees.  Examples of hospitals being quoted double the rates for doctors were found.

The Longford Town Centre, initially envisioned as a commercial hub, now reflects Ireland's economic downturn.  However, some businesses report increased sales, attributing the improvement to diversification.  Politically, the opposition criticizes the government's handling of the midlands economy, citing a lack of foreign investment and suggesting alternative uses for funds allocated to water meters.  The government points to the planned Center Parcs development as a positive step, anticipating job creation.  Local business owners, though, suggest that addressing issues like parking charges could further stimulate the local economy.

Eight teams will compete in a tournament ending May 29th.  The top four teams will move on to the playoffs.  BBC Sport will provide updates on scores, fixtures, and results.  The leading run-scorers are Warner (294), Kohli (267), and De Villiers (249).  Warner and De Villiers each hit 12 sixes, while Kohli hit 8.  De Kock had the highest score in an innings (108). McClenaghan has the most wickets (9). Four former or current England players will participate.  Matches begin April 25th.

In England, the number of plastic carrier bags has increased by 200 million since 2013.  Many cannot be recycled and end up in landfills and rivers. Starting in October, England will charge 5p per plastic bag to encourage reuse.  Other parts of the UK already have this charge and have seen a decrease in plastic bag use as a result.

High winds caused damage and disruption across Wales on Friday.  A school roof was damaged, hundreds of homes lost power, trains were delayed, and bridges had speed and lane restrictions.  Irish Ferries canceled sailings, and the National Trust closed some properties.  While restrictions on bridges were later lifted, the Rhyl Boxing Day Dip was postponed until December 27th.

Michael B. Jordan will star in Black Panther alongside Lupita Nyong'o and Chadwick Boseman.  Jordan is reuniting with his Creed director Ryan Coogler for the film, which will be released in February 2018.  Nyong'o won an Oscar for her role in 12 Years a Slave, and Boseman currently stars as Black Panther in Captain America: Civil War.

The Alexandra Palace's east wing, including a theatre and BBC studios, will undergo a £26.6 million restoration.  Funding comes from the Heritage Lottery Fund (£18.8m), Haringey Council (£6.8m), and fundraising by the Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust (£1m).  The theatre, built in 1875, will host various performances including theatre, cinema, comedy, and live music, and is expected to reopen in 2018.  The project will also renovate the glazed east court into a public exhibition space.

James Milner, 30, a former Manchester City player, earned 61 senior caps for England since his debut in 2009.  He participated in two World Cups and two European Championships, but only played three minutes at Euro 2016.  He also holds the record for most England Under-21 caps (46), and scored one international goal in a 5-0 win against Moldova.

A fire destroyed the Smith family's home in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador.  The family escaped, but their pets perished.
