Barrow's 27-year-old center-back, Anderson, mutually terminated his contract to join a National League rival team and may play against his former club on February 18.  21-year-old striker Keating, whose move is pending international clearance, joined the team, bringing his experience from Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps.  The Gulls, currently four points from relegation, having won only one of their last six games, sought Anderson for his leadership and Keating for his eagerness.

Ten-year-old Many Clouds, an Irish-bred horse, died from a severe pulmonary hemorrhage after winning the Cotswold Chase.  While rare, this can occur in horses without underlying health issues.  Many Clouds had previously experienced post-race ataxia, characterized by overheating and wobbling, but showed no such symptoms on the day he died.  His trainer called him the "horse of a lifetime".

Tricia Marwick, Duncan McNeil, and Alex Salmond are among the MSPs leaving office before the May 5th election.  Salmond's farewell speech reiterated his belief that Scotland is diverse, not divided, and welcomed the Scotland Bill's power transfer to Holyrood, while noting it didn't fulfill unionist campaign pledges.  McNeil's speech warned Holyrood to learn from Westminster's committee system to ensure accountability and scrutiny.  Annabel Goldie also delivered a farewell speech.

Emma Watson will play Belle in Disney's live-action Beauty and the Beast, directed by Bill Condon.  Other cast members include Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston, Josh Gad as LeFou, Kevin Kline as Maurice, and Emma Thompson as Mrs. Potts.  The film's release date is March 17, 2017.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) will announce its decision at 11:00 BST today during a meeting with families of the 96 Liverpool fans who died in the Hillsborough disaster.  Last year, new inquests ruled that the fans were unlawfully killed.  In January, files on 23 suspects were sent to the CPS to determine if charges should be filed; 15 suspects are from the Operation Resolve investigation into the disaster's causes, and 8 are from an Independent Police Complaints Commission probe into the police's conduct.  Margaret Aspinall, whose son died in the disaster, said the families are hoping for accountability.

Chelmsford Prison has seen numerous packages thrown over its walls recently.  A nearby resident witnessed this four times in two weeks.  A former inmate said the prison is rife with contraband, including mobile phones and synthetic cannabis, and that drones are sometimes used to deliver it.  The Ministry of Justice acknowledges the problem and is working to improve security measures, noting that smuggling contraband can result in a two-year prison sentence.

72-year-old Sylvia Blackburn, a lollipop lady of 20 years, suffered serious head injuries when Brian Wright, 55, hit her with his car outside Bedford Road Lower School.  Wright claims he was blinded by the setting sun and didn't see the red light, but he accepts responsibility and expresses remorse.  Blackburn is now in residential care, and the trial continues.

Scottish runner, Muir, will not compete in the Commonwealth Games in Australia next April due to veterinary medicine exams in May.  She finished fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5000m at the World Athletics Championships, achieving a new personal best in the 5000m.  While disappointed to miss the Commonwealth Games, she is focusing on her final year of university and believes she has several more Olympics in her future, with the World Indoor Championships in March as a potential target.

On December 2000, Trevor Deely, 22, went missing after attending a Christmas party.  A search involving excavation started Saturday morning in a three-acre woodland area beside the R112 in Chapelizod, Dublin.  This follows a review of the case earlier this year, and the release of enhanced CCTV footage showing Mr. Deely speaking with an unidentified man in black.  Police are appealing for this man to come forward.

Juan Martin del Potro, ranked 165th, won his first Grand Slam match since 2014, defeating Stan Wawrinka 3-6 6-3 7-6 (7-2) 6-3.  Del Potro will next play either Lucas Pouille or Donald Young.  Nick Kyrgios also advanced, winning a rain-delayed match against Dustin Brown 6-7 (3-7) 6-1 2-6 6-4 6-4.  Kyrgios will play Feliciano Lopez next, with the winner potentially facing Andy Murray in the last 16.  Other notable wins include those by Tomas Berdych and Jo-Wilfried Tsonga.

Tunisia and Morocco both had issues that almost prevented them from participating in the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations.  Tunisia was almost expelled for complaints lodged against the Confederation of African Football (Caf) following a controversial penalty call in the 2015 quarterfinals against Equatorial Guinea.  They avoided expulsion after apologizing to Caf.  Morocco was banned after refusing to host the 2015 tournament due to Ebola concerns, but the Court of Arbitration for Sport overturned the ban, reducing their fine.  Both countries are now participating in the 2017 qualifying rounds.

McLaren's Formula 1 team, with a history of 182 grand prix wins, 12 drivers' world championships, and eight constructors' titles, is currently experiencing a slump.  Their decline began in 2013 due to chassis design issues, despite having a superior engine. While the car's performance has improved, the Honda power unit is now the problem.  Past successes included a dominant 1988 season with Ayrton Senna and Alain Prost, and further victories with Mika Hakkinen and Mercedes engines.  Scandals in 2007 and 2009 involving Ferrari data and misleading stewards respectively, also impacted the team.  Despite periods of success with drivers like Lewis Hamilton and Jenson Button, McLaren's current struggles are seen as part of a cyclical pattern of triumph and decline throughout their history.  Ron Dennis, who has played a significant role in the team's successes and setbacks, believes a return to winning is imminent, fueled by Alonso's return and improvements to the car and engine.  However, currently, their success depends entirely on their belief in their ability to overcome their challenges.

On October 6, 2014, paramedics responded to a death at Joe’s Bar in Dungiven at 6:00 a.m.  Police found people still at the bar, with receipts showing alcohol sales until 4:49 a.m.  The bar was closed for three months.  Colleen O'Neill (license holder) and James Thomas were charged with allowing alcohol consumption outside of licensing hours.  O'Neill received a £3,000 fine and Thomas a £1,000 fine due to the bar's history of non-compliance with licensing laws.

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA record for most three-pointers in a season, scoring 45 points and hitting eight three-pointers in the Golden State Warriors’ 116-105 win over the Portland Trail Blazers.  The Warriors overcame a 13-point deficit.  In another game, the Chicago Bulls overcame a 19-point halftime deficit to defeat the Miami Heat 89-78.  Pau Gasol led the Bulls with 16 points and 15 rebounds.

Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic were surprised by YouTube star Bas van Velzen, a free-kick specialist, who they believed was a competition winner.  Van Velzen showcased his impressive free-kick skills, surprising the Liverpool players.  Van Velzen enjoyed the experience of meeting his idols and pretending to be a poor free-kick taker, while also revealing Balotelli's infamous slogan from a t-shirt he wore during a Manchester City game.

A study of 676 breast cancer patients with BRCA1 or BRCA2 gene mutations revealed that those with BRCA1 mutations who had an oophorectomy (ovary removal) after diagnosis experienced a 62% reduction in breast cancer death risk and a 65% reduction in death from all causes.  The protective effect was most significant within two years of diagnosis (73% reduction in death) and lasted 15 years.  This effect was not seen in patients with BRCA2 mutations.  The study suggests oophorectomy should be considered as part of the treatment discussion for BRCA1 mutation carriers with early-stage breast cancer.

On Easter Sunday, Derek Lowe (38) and Tina Lowe (33) were struck and killed by Amtrak train No. 80 in Durham, North Carolina.  The train, traveling from Charlotte to New York City, was delayed for nearly three hours.  None of the 166 passengers were injured, though one passenger fell ill during the delay and received treatment.  The Lowes may have been homeless.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former mid-level member of the Medellín cartel, spent 27 years working as a DEA informant after fleeing Colombia in the 1980s.  He was promised U.S. citizenship in exchange for his work, which aided in the prosecution of major drug traffickers like Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega.  Now retired and facing deportation, Toro fears for his life if returned to Colombia.  Despite his invaluable service, the DEA has refused to help him obtain citizenship, leaving him in legal limbo and unable to access social security benefits.  A former colleague recently gave him $5,000 after the DEA's refusal to assist.

The US internet address regulator is investigating Vox Populi Registry Ltd., a Canadian company, for potentially illegal activity.  Vox Populi is selling ".sucks" domain names to celebrities and companies for approximately $2,499 per year,  with many resold for around $2,000.  Celebrities like Kevin Spacey and Taylor Swift have paid to remove their names from these domains.  The ".sucks" domain was approved by ICANN but is now under scrutiny following complaints that the practice is predatory.  ICANN may take action if regulators deem Vox Populi's actions illegal.

In 1988, the body of a baby boy was found in a pond.  Twenty-seven years later, a DNA match led police to his mother.  She admitted to concealing her pregnancy and delivering the stillborn baby.  The charges of infanticide were dropped, but she may face charges for failing to register the birth and preventing a lawful burial. The baby, originally buried as an unknown, was reburied with a headstone and named Peter.  Police stated there was no foul play involved.

Kristopher Hicks suffered severe brain injuries after jumping from a taxi driven by Michael Young, who mistakenly believed Hicks was trying to avoid paying his fare.  Young drove Hicks almost a mile against his wishes, leading Hicks to jump from the vehicle at over 20mph.  The High Court ruled that Young unlawfully imprisoned Hicks and is liable for damages, though the final amount is yet to be determined but will be around 50% of the family's request (hundreds of thousands of pounds).  Hicks now requires 24-hour care due to his injuries, which include epilepsy, headaches, fatigue, and social and behavioral problems.

Severe storms and tornadoes hit Kansas and Missouri on Wednesday night.  Spotters reported a tornado near Goddard, Kansas, and several others in southwestern Kansas.  A possible tornado touched down in Potosi, Missouri, causing wind damage and flooding.  More storms are predicted for Thursday in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the Southern Great Lakes.

Luke Rockhold will fight Lyoto Machida in a middleweight match in New Jersey.  Rockhold is aiming for his fourth consecutive win and a title shot. He plans to be aggressive and dominate Machida, who prefers a more elusive fighting style.  Rockhold has identified weaknesses in Machida’s fighting style and believes he has a significant advantage. Machida is confident he can win by using his own style and technique, and believes the winner of this match deserves a title shot.

In Fort Pierce, Florida, an 85-year-old pilot, Chris Georgaklis, landed a light general aviation aircraft without deploying the landing gear.  The plane skidded on its belly, with the propellers hitting the runway. Despite damage, Georgaklis, accompanied by his dog, managed to fly 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale and land safely. The FAA is investigating; the most common cause of such incidents is pilot error.

Manchester City’s manager, Manuel Pellegrini, is disappointed in midfielder Yaya Touré’s performance this season but will support him until the season ends.  City will listen to offers for Touré in the summer.  Meanwhile, Pellegrini faces questions about his own future, and the team is struggling, having earned only 18 points from the last 39.  Captain Vincent Kompany may miss the rest of the season due to injury.  Goalkeeper Joe Hart says the players, not just the manager, should take responsibility for the team's poor performance.  Additionally, Manchester City is interested in signing West Ham’s Aaron Cresswell.  Sam Allardyce, West Ham’s manager, cautions Cresswell against making the same mistake as other players who moved to City and didn’t play much.

Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian Mafia fugitive, will remain in the UK after his extradition to Italy was dropped.  Convicted in absentia in 1999 for being a member of the Cosa Nostra and sentenced to seven years, his case expired in October 2014 due to Italian law stating that a sentence is extinguished after double the penalty time has passed.  Although his conviction remains, the Italian court of appeal agreed to extinguish it, and the European arrest warrant will be withdrawn.  The case will be heard by the Italian Supreme Court.

Mr. Mole, ridden by A.P. McCoy, is one of three co-favorites in the seven-runner Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday.  This will be McCoy's last Grade One race; his full schedule for his final day as a professional jockey will be released Friday morning.  McCoy's announcement to retire came after winning at Newbury with Mr. Mole in February.  Other runners include Somersby.

In 1975, Marcia Trimble Ritter was raped and murdered by Jerome Sydney Barrett.  Her body was found 33 days later.  Her mother, Virginia, recently viewed crime scene photos for the first time, 40 years after the murder, and expressed a desire for revenge.  Barrett was convicted of second-degree murder in 2009 and sentenced to 44 years.  The case was unsolved for 33 years until DNA evidence linked Barrett to the crime.

Rory McIlroy aims to win the Masters Tournament to complete his career grand slam, joining an elite group of five other golfers.  His 2011 Masters collapse, where he held a four-shot lead going into the final round but ultimately finished ten shots behind the winner, was a pivotal moment in his career, teaching him valuable lessons.  Despite having only one top-10 finish in six Masters appearances, McIlroy views winning at Augusta as a long-term goal and believes it's "unthinkable" he won't win at some point. He will tee off at the Arnold Palmer Invitational on March 19.

This week's trending topics included: four rainbows appearing in the New York sky after heavy rain; the increasing, yet soon-to-end, practice of hiring exotic dancers for wakes in rural China;  Robert Downey Jr.'s irritation with a UK interviewer's questions about his private life; the "Kylie Jenner Challenge," involving lip plumping by sucking on a jar; 102-year-old Alice Barker revisiting her past with the help of filmmakers; a promposal deemed inappropriate by one school; Ewan McGregor's casting as Lumiere in "Beauty and the Beast"; Johnny Depp's appearance in the "Black Mass" trailer; a "Fresh Prince of Bel-Air"-themed pregnancy announcement; and a military dad photobombing his son's picture.

Data from the health and social care information center shows that 272 children were hospitalized in England in the past year due to Fetal Alcohol Syndrome (FAS).  The World Health Organization suggests that the actual number of babies born in the UK with learning, behavioral, and physical problems from alcohol exposure may be as high as 7,500 yearly.  FAS is incurable, and often vastly underdiagnosed.  The condition can cause a range of issues, including problems with the liver, kidneys, heart, cerebral palsy, sight loss, and epilepsy.  The government advises pregnant women to limit alcohol consumption, but some experts recommend abstaining completely.

On March 15, at 8 pm, Shaun Andrew McKerry, a 31-year-old man with a history of criminal offenses, attempted to rob Shildon Post Office and Stores in County Durham.  McKerry, wielding an axe, was tackled by the store owner, Sab Dhillon, and hit with a baseball bat by Dhillon's wife.  The police arrived and arrested McKerry, who pleaded guilty to attempted robbery and was sentenced to six years in prison.  McKerry, known as "Boomerang Boy" for his habit of returning home after committing crimes, had a lengthy criminal record starting at age 12, including 80 arrests by age 15.

Four Royal Navy sailors—Joshua Finbow (23), Craig Stoner (24), Simon Radford (31), and Darren Smalley (35)—are charged with the gang rape of a young woman at a Canadian barracks.  They were released on bail with conditions including surrendering their passports, residing at the Stadacona Naval Base in Halifax, Nova Scotia, maintaining their Navy employment, and not contacting the victim or six witnesses.  The alleged assault occurred on April 10th after a hockey tournament.  The men will return to court on May 27th and face charges punishable by up to 14 years in prison; further charges are possible.  The British High Commission is assisting Canadian authorities with the investigation.

Valerie Jackson's four-year-old son, RJ, has Netherton's syndrome, an extremely rare skin disease affecting only 70 people worldwide.  His skin appears red, inflamed, and scaly, causing him significant pain.  Due to public misunderstanding, Valerie has faced accusations of child abuse, police involvement, and bullying.  Despite the challenges, Valerie and her husband diligently care for RJ, using creams to soothe his skin and advocating for greater awareness of Netherton's syndrome.

Protein World's "Are you beach body ready?" ad campaign in London's Underground has been met with significant backlash from feminists and body image campaigners.  A Change.org petition garnered over 50,000 signatures demanding the ads' removal.  Many posters were defaced, and over 200 complaints were filed with the Advertising Standards Authority (ASA).  Transport for London (TFL) confirmed the ads' removal, citing the end of the three-week advertising period.  Protein World defended the campaign, claiming the image was unphotoshopped and that the negative reaction was from an "irrational minority."  The company also reported receiving threats, including a bomb threat.  Despite the controversy, Protein World stated they would not change their advertising methods.  The ASA is reviewing the complaints.

Rail companies are raising fares by as much as 87 percent, despite promises from the main political parties to freeze prices.  The Prime Minister is asking First Great Western to review its decision to almost double some fares on the London to Cotswolds route.  Other significant increases include a 24.5 percent hike on the Stafford to Liverpool route and a 22 percent increase on the Manchester to Stoke route.  While some companies claim the increases affect only a portion of their fares and are below the industry average, the increases have angered passengers.

66-year-old former soldier John Young was struck in the eye by a brick thrown by vandals.  The attack occurred when Young opened his door to confront the thugs who were throwing stones at his Oldham home.  Young, who was recently married, now has permanent blindness in one eye as a result.  Police are investigating but have not yet established a motive, suggesting it may have been a random act of vandalism.  The couple plan to move because they no longer feel safe.

Derbyshire wicketkeeper Tom Poynton signed a one-year contract extension after a successful return from a leg injury and ankle operation.  He missed the 2014 season due to injuries sustained in a road accident that killed his father.  Poynton returned during Derbyshire's pre-season tour of Abu Dhabi and will be available for the start of the 2016 season.  Derbyshire's elite performance director, Graeme Welch, praised Poynton's character and work ethic.

Five-year-old Harley Renshaw was diagnosed with neuroblastoma, a rare and aggressive childhood cancer, affecting his kidney, neck, lungs, and bones.  He underwent intensive chemotherapy, surgery, a stem cell transplant, and radiotherapy.  He decorated his radiotherapy mask as a Ninja Turtle to cope with his treatment. After over a year of battling the disease, Harley is now cancer-free and will have regular check-ups.  His story gained international attention, and he received gifts from Nickelodeon.  His father is overjoyed and looking forward to the future.

Aston Villa's 19-year-old player, Jack Grealish, is currently deciding between playing for the Republic of Ireland or England.  His coach, Tim Sherwood, wants Grealish to focus on his Aston Villa career before making a decision.  Grealish's father agrees with Sherwood.  Grealish is expected to decide at the end of the season.

Landing fees for private jets vary dramatically.  The highest fees are found in some surprising locations, including Salzburg, Austria, and Darwin, Australia.  In 2013, there were 2.5 million private flights in the US and 705,000 in Europe.  The busiest times are during major sporting events like the Super Bowl and Monaco Grand Prix.  Haneda Airport in Tokyo has the highest landing fee at £4,559 ($6,850), followed by Narita International Airport in Tokyo and Kansai International Airport in Osaka.  Other airports with high fees include Toronto Pearson, Darwin International, Bristol, Chubu Centrair, Dublin, and LaGuardia.  The cost of a private jet flight from New York to Glendale for the Super Bowl was estimated at $38,000-$54,000 round trip.

In a viral video, Cooper the Labrador eats a McDonald's ice cream cone in one bite, while his smaller companion, Daisy, only gets a few licks.  His owner, Katie Gallegos, states that Cooper always eats quickly and that the ice cream is an occasional treat.  The video has over seven million views, with some viewers criticizing Gallegos for giving her dogs ice cream, while others find it cute.  Gallegos defends her actions, noting Cooper's health and that her previous dog also enjoyed ice cream.  Another video shows the dogs enjoying a Starbucks "pup-uccino," which Cooper also consumes quickly.

Gary Locke, former Hearts boss, has been named Kilmarnock's permanent manager after a successful interim period.  He signed a three-year contract.  Locke took over in February after Allan Johnston left and has a record of one loss in seven games since then.  He will speak at a press conference Friday morning.

Jessica Kemp, a Florida mother, claims that Seminole County Elementary threatened to suspend her 5-year-old autistic son, Logan, for wearing Doterra essential oils to help calm and focus him.  While the school cited the oils as a distraction, Kemp says Logan has used them all year without issue until a teacher's aide complained.  The school board stated the oils created a problem, but the Lake County School District later said they would not suspend Logan, classifying it as a health issue.  The oils used include lavender, chamomile, and sandalwood.

On Wednesday, at 3 pm, a fire destroyed a 90-unit condo complex in Westhampton Beach.  The fire was so intense that it melted paint on nearby buildings and was visible from three miles away. Twelve fire crews responded, but couldn't enter the building due to the intensity of the flames.  The cause is under investigation, but one theory involves a car parked near the complex.  The building, used as a holiday home between May and November, is a total loss.

At 88 years old, Queen Elizabeth enjoys riding her Fell pony, Carltonlima Emma, in Windsor Great Park.  She has ridden horses her whole life, starting at age four with a Shetland pony named Peggy.  While she has been encouraged to wear a helmet, she prefers a silk scarf, reportedly because of her hairstyle.  She has reduced her riding in recent years due to a knee injury but remains an enthusiastic equestrian, breeding Fell ponies at Hampton Court and other breeds at Balmoral.  Her grandchildren now ride some of her horses.  Fell ponies, her pony's breed, originated in Cumbria and have been used for various purposes throughout history.

55-year-old Leon Yeaman died after being punched in the head by his neighbor, 28-year-old Phillip Pama, during a noise dispute on Thursday night.  Pama, a father of three, was granted bail but is charged with manslaughter.  Yeaman was reportedly known for being loud and playing music late at night, while Pama claimed he acted in self-defense.  The case will return to court on May 18.

Jose Mourinho, Chelsea's manager, revealed that he prays daily, but never about football.  He keeps his professional and family lives separate, and prays only for personal matters.  He and his family are involved in fighting hunger through work with the World Food Programme.  Despite his on-field persona, he considers himself a good person and family man.  Currently, Chelsea is leading the league.  Earlier this season, Mourinho was fined £25,000 for claiming a campaign against Chelsea.

Bob Barker, the 91-year-old former host of *The Price is Right*, guest hosted the April 1st edition of the show.  He hadn't hosted in eight years, but handled the first game, "Lucky Seven," before Drew Carey finished the show.

Off-duty Secret Service agent Arthur Baldwin was arrested in Washington, D.C. at 12:30 AM on Friday, for felony charges of attempted burglary and destruction of property.  The arrest occurred on the 3200 block of D Street SE.  His security clearance has been revoked, and he has been placed on leave from his position in the foreign missions branch.  This arrest follows another recent incident involving a high-ranking supervisor accused of misconduct, and a March 4th incident where two high-ranking officials allegedly drove into a secure White House area after drinking.  The Homeland Security Department’s inspector general is investigating these matters.

A 38-year-old freelance photographer, Atif Saeed from Lahore, Pakistan, risked his life to take a picture of a lion at the city's safari park.  He approached the lion to within 10 feet, lying on the ground to take photos. The camera's clicking sound alerted the lion, causing Saeed to quickly retreat to his car as the lion charged.  Saeed stated that he wanted to capture the lion's character and status, and while he laughed at the time, he wouldn't repeat the action.

On March 22, an unidentified woman between 25 and 45 years old was found dead near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue in Brooklyn.  She had a heart tattoo on her right leg that said "Monique," and police have released images of the tattoo hoping to identify her.  The cause of death is still pending.  Anyone with information should contact NYPD Crime Stoppers at 800-577-TIPS.

A New Zealand couple, Hannah and Alex, built a two-bedroom home on a 1986 Hino flatbed truck after returning from the UK in 2009.  Unable to afford land, they spent a year and a half constructing a solar-powered home using wood and steel.  The home, located in Nelson, New Zealand, features a wood-fired stove, stained glass windows, and water from a nearby spring.  Their first electricity bill was only $25.  The project cost approximately $25,000.

Researchers found that kindergarten children sharing iPads in class scored approximately 30 points higher on early literacy tests than those who had individual iPads or no iPads at all.  The study, involving 352 students, suggests that collaborative learning around the technology, rather than collaboration itself, is key to the improved test scores.  The researcher recommends that schools reconsider how iPads are used, especially in early grades, to maximize effectiveness.

A piglet born without back legs has become an internet sensation in China.  The piglet, nicknamed "Super Pig," has learned to walk on its front trotters, balancing remarkably well.  A video of the piglet walking and foraging for food has garnered thousands of views.  The piglet lives with its littermates and a local farmer, Ms. Duan, in Sichuan province.  This isn't the first two-legged animal to become famous in China; a rabbit at Liuzhou zoo also gained popularity for walking on its front paws.

During the inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana, a pit crew member, Todd Phillips, was injured when he was hit by Francesco Dracone's car on lap 25.  Dracone spun while exiting his pit box, hitting Phillips' leg. Phillips received stitches for a leg wound and was released from the infield care center.  Dracone did not finish the race.

Milton Vieira Severiano, 32, murdered his wife, dancer Cicera Alves de Sena, 29, four days after their wedding.  Severiano beat his wife's head against the pavement 11 times and shot her in the face five times because he was jealous of men looking at her.  He yelled at her, calling her a slut and whore before the attack.  After the murder, Severiano stole a neighbor's car, crashing it during his escape. Police found four handguns, a shotgun, and a bulletproof vest in the car.  He confessed to the crime and faces life in prison.

Sarah Wilson, author of *I Quit Sugar*, revealed in an interview that she nearly committed suicide due to anxiety, stress, thyroid disease, and feelings of isolation.  She felt increasingly alone, lacking a husband and children, and unable to see a way out. While she has found some peace, she believes depression and anxiety are linked and that anxiety is becoming increasingly prevalent among Australian women.  Beyond Blue reports that one in three Australian women will experience anxiety in their lifetime.

Elena Curtin, a seven-months pregnant Oregon woman, will not face prosecution for assaulting her boyfriend’s ex-girlfriend with a crowbar in November 2014.  Curtin found the ex-girlfriend using heroin in her bathroom and, after the ex-girlfriend refused to leave, Curtin beat her.  The charges were dropped because the prosecution believed Curtin was justified under Oregon law, which allows the use of physical force against intruders who refuse to leave a residence.  The ex-girlfriend had a history of harassing and threatening Curtin.  Curtin gave birth in January and is now living with her parents.

Gemma, a pit bull in California, was filmed reacting with disgust to a piece of broccoli her owner gave her as a treat.  She spit it out on the floor.  When not eating, Gemma sleeps and spends time with her family, which includes two children.

A link on HSBC's official website led to a pornographic site.  The issue stemmed from a defunct Young Entrepreneur Awards page that was allowed to expire in 2011, after which a porn site took over the URL.  HSBC apologized for the error, removed the link, and stated that it had no association with the pornographic site.  The bank also confirmed that its internet banking services remained secure.

On Sunday morning, a fire broke out on the first floor of a Clinton home.  13-year-old Marcus and his 9-year-old sister Aaliyah were trapped in a second-floor bedroom. Marcus called 911, calmly providing directions to firefighters, who rescued the children through a window.  The siblings were treated for non-life-threatening injuries, while three other family members escaped and were treated at a different hospital.

Pictures of blue fluorescent algae illuminating Australia's east coast were taken in Jervis Bay, located on the south coast of New South Wales.  Photographer Andy Hutchinson described the scene as "beautiful and supernatural," caused by millions of plankton emitting light.  A similar event occurred in Sydney's Manly Beach in August 2014.  According to Iain Suthers of the University of New South Wales, the algae, *Noctiluca scintillans*, blooms in spring and autumn, and the glow is a defense mechanism.

New tests, such as the Endopredict test, can determine the aggressiveness of breast cancer tumors and predict the likelihood of recurrence.  These tests analyze cancer cells to assess risk, potentially sparing some women from chemotherapy.  While most tests are currently private and cost around £2,500, there's hope for NHS availability.  Chemotherapy is a grueling treatment with significant side effects, and the tests allow for informed decisions, avoiding unnecessary treatment for low-risk patients.  For some women, the test shows a recurrence risk as low as 5%, comparable to or better than the odds with chemotherapy.

Over the last nine years, more than 25 pregnant Royal Navy sailors were airlifted from their ships, including five from HMS Ocean.  At least one woman was airlifted from HMS Illustrious.  Eighteen other ships had similar emergency evacuations. A "no touching" rule is in place at sea, suggesting conceptions occurred before deployment or during leave.  This follows a case where Commander Sarah West, the first female warship captain, was flown back to the UK after allegations of a relationship with a crew member.  Since 1990, women have served in the Royal Navy; in 2014, around 9% of personnel were female.  Similar evacuations occurred in Afghanistan (99 servicewomen between 2006-2013) and Iraq (102 women).  Military rules prohibit pregnant servicewomen in war zones.

A drone carrying traces of radioactive cesium was found on the roof of the Japanese Prime Minister’s residence.  The drone, equipped with a camera and smoke flares, prompted concerns about terrorism, particularly regarding future events like the Olympics and G7 summit.  While Japanese law restricts drone flights near airports, there are currently no restrictions in most of Tokyo.  The Prime Minister was out of the country at the time of the discovery.

Lu Xincai, a security guard in China, takes his 84-year-old Alzheimer's-stricken mother to work with him every day because he fears she will get lost if left alone.  He drives his motorbike slowly, taking an hour for the four-kilometer trip, tying a sash around both of them for safety. His employers have provided his mother with a room at the bank where he works, and he regularly checks on her.  He feels obligated to care for her as she devoted her life to raising her children.

Between 2005 and 2012, heavy drinking among Americans increased by 17.2%, largely due to increased rates among women.  In 2012, 8% of Americans were heavy drinkers and 18% were binge drinkers.  The rise is attributed to shifting social norms making heavy drinking more acceptable for women, increased alcohol advertising, and cheaper alcohol due to stagnant taxes.  The economic impact of excessive drinking is estimated at over $220 billion annually, with approximately 88,600 U.S. deaths attributed to alcohol in 2010.

The UN warns that doctors are performing too many Cesarean sections, unnecessarily endangering mothers and babies.  The current rate in England is over 25%, more than double the rate of the early 1990s, while the World Health Organization (WHO) recommends a rate between 10-15%.  Cesarean sections, while life-saving in some cases, can cause infections, disability, or death, and are more costly than natural births.  The WHO statement contradicts current NHS guidelines, which allow Cesareans even without medical justification, including for women with tokophobia (childbirth anxiety).

Michelle Filkins, 44, was arrested on April 17 in Edgartown, MA, and charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property.  She was found by homeowner Mark Conklin in his $800,000 home, where she had allegedly been living for at least a week and selling the homeowner's possessions at a yard sale.  Police found a broken window covered with a blanket. Filkins will next appear in court on May 14.  The police are asking anyone who received items from the yard sale to return them to the Edgartown Police Department.

Bella Crooke lost her phone at a friend's birthday party.  Albury police found it unlocked, and used it to post selfies and humorous messages to her Facebook page to locate her.  The posts included photos of the phone in a "holding cell" and puns about charging the battery.  Bella's friends shared the posts, and police easily identified her when she arrived.  She got her phone back, and added a password.

In South Africa’s Isimangaliso Wetland Park, a five-day-old hippo calf was killed after getting caught in a fight between two adult male hippos.  The calf’s mother watched helplessly as one of the males tossed the calf into the air and dragged it through the water.  A tour operator witnessed the event, noting the mother had previously kept other hippos away from her baby.  The calf died from its injuries hours later.

A three-bedroom apartment in Knightsbridge, London is on the market for £575,000, significantly less than comparable properties.  However, the lease has only three years remaining.  While needing modernization, the 1,990 sq/ft apartment could be worth upwards of £6 million with a lease extension, costing between £3.35-£4.5 million for a 90-year extension.  The current cost is comparable to the monthly rent for a similar property in the area.  There is high interest from potential buyers, including developers.

A computer outage at 8,000 Starbucks stores in the US and Canada caused a system-wide shutdown on Friday evening.  This resulted in baristas giving away free drinks because registers were unable to process sales.  The outage, caused by a daily system refresh failure, affected credit card transactions but cash payments were still accepted at some locations.  Starbucks stated that stores would reopen for normal business on Saturday.  The outage also impacted Evolution Fresh and Teavana stores.

Terrorist training and radicalization of Muslims is happening in rural West Wales, specifically Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire.  Individuals involved participate in seemingly normal community activities while secretly pursuing ulterior motives.  Incidents of this activity have occurred since 1998, with notable examples including the 7/7 bombers' presence in North Wales and the involvement of individuals connected to the murder of Fusilier Lee Rigby.  A former institute of human sciences in Llanybydder is also linked to terrorist activity.  Community intelligence is vital in addressing this issue.

An Omura's whale, a species rarely seen, was discovered on a beach in Western Australia.  This is only the second time this whale has been found in Australia and the first in Western Australia.  The 5.68 m juvenile female was identified through DNA profiling.  The discovery is significant because little is known about this species, which was only first described in scientific journals in 2003.  The whale's carcass has been buried, and the skeleton will be recovered later for further study.

A Texas businesswoman, Cheryl Rios, believes Hillary Clinton shouldn't be president because of potential hormonal influences on her decision-making abilities, specifically the risk of starting unnecessary wars.  This opinion is contrasted with studies showing women leaders take fewer unnecessary risks than men.  The article highlights a broader issue of gender bias against women in leadership positions, citing examples of bias in corporate boards and academic settings.  The author argues that this bias negatively impacts not only women's opportunities but also overall societal progress, impacting businesses, families, and the economy.  Rios's statement that she would move to Canada if Clinton were elected is countered by the fact that Canada had a female prime minister in 1993.

Robert Hardy, the 89-year-old actor known for his roles in *All Creatures Great and Small* and as Winston Churchill, is downsizing and selling his antique collection at auction.  The auction, which takes place this Saturday at Dominic Winter Auctioneers in Gloucestershire, includes over 200 items, such as furniture, paintings, swords, and a hand-painted diorama of the Battle of Agincourt.  Hardy, a military history expert who studied under J.R.R. Tolkien, is selling the collection due to downsizing his home.

Michael Scott Shemansky is a suspect in the murder of his mother, Sandra Shemansky, 57, whose body was found in their shared Winter Garden home after an out-of-state family member requested a wellness check.  Police launched an investigation after Shemansky failed to appear for a supervised visit with his son.  He has a history of violence, including battery on law enforcement and an attempted suicide, and was on parole.  Neighbors suggest his divorce may have contributed to the incident.  Shemansky was last seen fleeing on foot without supplies or medication.  Authorities have a murder weapon but haven't released details of the death.  Anyone with information should contact 407-656-3636.

The International Association of Athletics Federations (IAAF) Council awarded Eugene, Oregon the right to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships.  This decision bypassed the usual bidding process due to what the IAAF considered a unique strategic opportunity to host the event in the U.S. for the first time.  Eugene previously lost a bid to host the 2019 event (awarded to Doha, Qatar), but a recent presentation convinced the IAAF that Eugene could successfully host the championships.  The IAAF president noted this decision was made to take advantage of the combined support of public authorities, the private sector, the national Olympic committee, NBC, and the public.  The 2007 World Championships in Osaka, Japan were also awarded without a bidding process.

Leonie Granger, 25, was jailed for 16 years for the manslaughter of 56-year-old professional gambler Mehmet Hassan.  Granger, an aspiring model, befriended Hassan at a casino, showering him with gifts and then leaving his unlocked flat, allowing her boyfriend and an accomplice to enter. They tied him up, beat him to death, and robbed him.  Her co-defendants, Kyrron Jackson and Nicholas Chandler, were found guilty of murder and received life sentences with a minimum of 36 years.  The judge described the attack as "pitiless and wicked."

Cesc Fabregas, a Chelsea midfielder, has significantly declined in performance since around Christmas.  His assists have dropped from 15 by mid-January to only one in five games since. While he had been on track to break Thierry Henry's Premier League assist record of 20, his current form makes that unlikely.  Despite his slump, Chelsea still has nine games left, six of which are against teams Fabregas has previously assisted goals against.  His former club, Barcelona, had previously noted his tendency to underperform in the latter half of the season.  His manager, Jose Mourinho, will be hoping for a resurgence in Fabregas's performance to help Chelsea secure the Premier League title.

West Ham is negotiating a deal with 17-year-old Jamaican forward Deshane Beckford, who impressed the club's coaches during a two-week trial.  Beckford, considered one of the top Caribbean prospects, also has offers from Belgian clubs.  Separately, West Ham announced season tickets for the 2016-17 season at the Olympic Stadium will start at £289, the cheapest in the Premier League.

Mike Lane, the joint master of the Tedworth Hunt, was viciously assaulted by hunt saboteurs on January 24.  Despite providing Wiltshire Police with video evidence, names, and car registration numbers, the police have dropped the investigation due to insufficient evidence.  Lane and others involved are highly critical of the police's handling of the case, noting the suspect's face was clearly visible in the video.  The police state the case is closed unless further evidence is provided.

Adam Gadahn, a 36-year-old American known as al Qaeda's chief English-language propagandist, was killed in a U.S. counterterrorism operation in January.  While not a top leader, Gadahn was a prominent member, delivering numerous statements on behalf of the organization.  He converted to Islam in 1995, left the U.S. in 1998, and rose through al Qaeda's ranks, appearing in videos threatening attacks and criticizing U.S. presidents.  A federal grand jury indicted him in 2006 for treason and material support to al Qaeda.  Another U.S. citizen, Ahmed Farouq, also died in a likely separate operation, along with U.S. hostage Warren Weinstein.

Five-year-old Mai Zizhuo of China is a basketball prodigy who has been playing since he was two and a half.  A viral video shows him displaying impressive skills, including scoring hoops and dribbling two basketballs simultaneously.  His talent has garnered significant attention and praise online in China.

Tom O’Carroll, a former key activist of the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE), which campaigned to legalize sex with children in the 1970s and 80s, joined the supporters of the media pressure group Hacked Off.  O’Carroll attended a Hacked Off rally on February 25th to lobby MPs for state involvement in media regulation.  Hacked Off is campaigning against the Independent Press Standards Organisation and wants a statutory body to regulate the press.  O’Carroll’s involvement is embarrassing for Hacked Off.

The Icebergs Club pool in Bondi was drained to create a unique catwalk for Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia.  The Ten Pieces label, headed by Icebergs restaurateur Maurice Terzini and Lucy Hinckfuss, showcased a monochrome, unisex collection of ten pieces designed to be worn twenty ways.  Models walked through the empty pool and along the breakwall, with the ocean as a backdrop.  The show took place on a warm day, with guests enjoying food and drinks while onlookers watched from the balcony and the road above.

Amir Khan, a boxer from Bolton, took a family trip to a Northern California safari park.  He posed with and fed a white tiger, giraffes, and sea lions at Six Flags Discovery Kingdom with his wife, Faryal Makhdoom Khan, and daughter, Lamysa.  Khan also announced his next fight will be against Chris Algieri on May 30th.

Sixteen-year-old Mohammed Abu Khdeir's name was mistakenly added to a memorial wall at Jerusalem's Mount Herzl, honoring victims of terrorism.  His family and the Israeli organization Almagor objected to his inclusion, citing his death as a result of a rogue attack, not terrorism.  Following objections, the National Insurance Institute of Israel removed his name from the memorial wall and website.

A YouTube user filmed his young son using their family cat as a pillow in the garden.  The cat tolerated this briefly before moving, with the boy following and repeating the action two more times.  The cat eventually left, but the video later shows the pair reconciled, with the boy feeding the cat treats.

Robert Kushner, a trial witness in a Philadelphia police corruption case, lost his coaching job after testifying about his past marijuana sales.  He claims officers stole from him during a 2007 arrest, charges that were expunged.  Despite passing a background check in 2010, subsequent arrests in 2008 and 2011 resulted in probation sentences.  Kushner maintains he did not intend to deceive the school and is sorry for his past actions.  Defense lawyers claim the government’s case relies on unreliable witnesses.

An explosion and fire occurred at a paraxylene (PX) producing plant in Zhangzhou City, China on Monday night.  Six people were injured, five by broken glass.  Over 600 firefighters brought the blaze under control. The plant, originally slated for Xiamen, was relocated in 2007 due to pollution concerns and protests.  A previous explosion occurred at the plant in July 2013.

Aston Villa's Jack Grealish will continue to wear his socks low, despite referees' requests to pull them up.  This is due to superstition; he's worn them this way his whole life.  He also uses children's shin guards.  Grealish made his first Premier League start against QPR in a 3-3 draw, a game he described as tough but was pleased to have played in.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, has irreversible brain damage and is unresponsive, according to her grandmother, Cissy Houston.  While no longer in a medically induced coma, she remains in the same neurological state for three months, showing no response to visitors or familiar voices.  Although Bobby Brown stated she is awake and watching him,  her attorney said that while she has improved and will have a long life, the quality of that life is unknown and will take years to determine.

Russia is close to winning the Fed Cup after winning two matches against Germany.  Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova defeated Sabine Lisicki in three sets, 4-6, 7-6 (4), 6-3, after saving a match point. Svetlana Kuznetsova also won her match against Julia Goerges in straight sets.  Russia needs one more win on Sunday to reach the final and win their first Fed Cup title since 2008.

New South Wales residents are bracing for another storm predicted to hit later this week, bringing more floods and damage.  An east coast low, the same weather system that caused three days of damage last week, may hit again, bringing heavy rain from Thursday. The State Emergency Service (SES) still has over 4,000 jobs to complete from the previous storm and is concerned that more storms will hamper cleanup efforts.  The Hunter region is of particular concern due to the extensive damage already sustained.  The SES is urging residents to prepare their homes and families.  While a trough of low pressure is forming along the coast, meteorologists say it's too early to determine the severity of the upcoming weather system.

Nina Moric, a model known for her appearance in Ricky Martin’s “La Vida Loco” video, denied reports that she attempted suicide.  Instead, she claims she was hospitalized due to low blood pressure after a fall at home, resulting in bruising.  Her boyfriend, Luigi Mario Favoloso, initially confirmed the suicide attempt to the media, but Moric stated he was in Naples at the time of the incident.  Italian media previously reported a suicide attempt in 2009.  Moric was once married to Fabrizio Corona, a paparazzo jailed for blackmailing celebrities.

A new poll reveals that if Kate and William's second child is a girl, the British public would like her to be named Diana, after William's mother.  Alice and Charlotte are second and third in preference. If it's a boy, James is the favorite name, followed by Alexander.  A quarter of the 2,200 people polled want a baby girl, and 68% approve of William taking six weeks of paternity leave.

A suicide bomber killed 17 and wounded 64 in eastern Afghanistan on Thursday.  The bombing targeted a group of protesters in Khost, including a member of parliament, who were heading to a rally against the provincial governor.  The Taliban denied responsibility, and no other group has claimed responsibility.

Dani Alves will leave Barcelona this summer after rejecting the club's final contract offer.  The 31-year-old's agent confirmed that a three-year contract extension was rejected because it was contingent on Alves playing in 60% of the club's matches.  Alves has spent seven years with Barcelona, winning four Spanish titles and two Champions League titles.

Pablo Osvaldo urged Italian legends Andrea Pirlo and Francisco Totti to join him at Boca Juniors in Argentina.  Osvaldo, who is on loan from Southampton, has scored three goals in six games and believes Pirlo and Totti's skills would be a great fit for Boca, thrilling the fans.

18-year-old amateur jockey Lee Lewis Ferguson had a spectacular fall from his horse,Merrion Square, at the 4:20 pm race in Wincanton.  Ferguson, who only received a cut on his nose, was back at the stables mucking out the following morning.  He has viewed the replay of his fall, which has gained hundreds of thousands of online views, with fellow jockeys.  Ferguson is undeterred and plans to continue racing.

James Haskell, captain of the London Wasps, posted a picture of himself dressed as Iron Man on Instagram, referencing the release of Avengers: Age of Ultron.  Haskell, who started his rugby career with the Wasps in 2002, left in 2009 to play in France, Japan, and New Zealand before returning to the Wasps in 2012.  Since his return, he has made over 100 appearances for the club and earned 57 caps for England.

Wide-leg trousers are a current fashion trend.  They offer a stylish alternative to skinny jeans, which, while remaining fashionable, have been popular for many years.  The wide-leg style has made previous comebacks, notably in the 1970s.  To wear them flatteringly, especially if shorter in height, pair them with high heels and a simple top to avoid being overwhelmed by fabric.  Denim wide-leg trousers are an easy way to adopt the trend, as seen in collections by Gucci and Topshop.  Other designers, such as Celine and Stella McCartney, have also featured the style.

The University of Michigan will show the movie *American Sniper* as part of a student social event series despite a petition signed by over 200 students asking the school not to.  The initial decision to cancel the screening was reversed because it was inconsistent with the university's values of freedom of expression.  A second movie, *Paddington*, will be offered as an alternative.

On April 3, two 18 and 24-year-old French tourists living in Cockburn Central ignited an aerosol can near a quokka on Rottnest Island off the coast of Perth, Western Australia.  The quokka sustained minor burns but survived.  Police collected video evidence, questioned the men, and evicted them from the island.  Both men were charged with animal cruelty and will appear in Fremantle Magistrates Court on April 17.

Alice Barker, a 102-year-old former dancer in 1930s-40s New York nightclubs, was shown early music videos ("soundies") of herself dancing.  Barker had lost her photos and memorabilia and had never seen footage of her performances until now.  She reacted with delight.

A recent study by vehicle leasing firm OSV found that washing one's own car is becoming less common in Britain.  Thirty-one percent of men surveyed admitted to never having washed their own car, and only 12% of those who do wash their cars do so regularly.  Three-quarters of women also reported never washing their own car.  Reasons cited for the decline include the rise of hand car washes, larger car sizes, and competing weekend activities.  However, car washing does increase during holidays, with Birmingham, Chelmsford, and Sheffield showing the highest rates of owner-washing.  Audis, Toyotas, and BMWs are most likely to be washed by their owners, while Range Rovers, Peugeots, and Mercedes are least likely.

Martin Skrtel praised Steven Gerrard's impact on his Liverpool career since 2008, but believes the team can overcome the challenge of replacing him.  Gerrard aims to end his Liverpool career with an FA Cup victory before moving to LA Galaxy.  Skrtel credits Gerrard for helping him settle in at Liverpool and considers him one of the best players in the world, but believes Liverpool has players who can fill Gerrard's void with the right support.  Both Gerrard and Skrtel may return to the lineup for the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa.

At 75 years old, Jack Nicklaus aced the fourth hole during the par-3 contest at Augusta National.  This was his first hole-in-one at Augusta.  Five hole-in-ones were made that day, tying the 2002 record.  Camilo Villegas also aced the fourth and eighth holes but lost the contest to Kevin Streelman.  Nicklaus first wore a green jacket in 1963 at age 23 and won his sixth in 1986.  He is one of five golfers to complete a career grand slam.

Severe storms and tornadoes hit Kansas and Missouri on Wednesday night.  Spotters reported a tornado near Goddard, Kansas, and several others in southwestern Kansas.  A possible tornado touched down in Potosi, Missouri, causing wind damage and flooding.  More storms are predicted for Thursday in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the Southern Great Lakes.

Robert Bates, a 73-year-old reserve deputy for the Tulsa County Sheriff’s office, pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter for the shooting death of Eric Harris.  Bates claims he accidentally shot Harris with his gun instead of a taser during an arrest.  The judge granted Bates permission to go on a family vacation to the Bahamas, a decision that angered Harris’ family.  Bates’ preliminary hearing is scheduled for July 2nd.  The Harris family’s lawyer alleges Bates received preferential treatment due to donations and friendship with the sheriff, and that supervisors were told to forge Bates’ records.  The Sheriff’s office denies these allegations.  Two deputies involved in the arrest have been reassigned due to threats.  Bates’ lawyer released his training documents to prove he had proper training.

Conor McGregor will challenge Jose Aldo for the featherweight title on July 11th in Las Vegas.  McGregor recently got a tiger tattoo on his stomach and claims to have more motivation to win than Aldo has to defend his title.  During a promotional tour in Dublin, McGregor grabbed Aldo's belt in front of 5,000 fans.

Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott's rapid consumption of a beer at a sporting function has sparked controversy.  Critics, including cultural studies professor Julie Robert, argue this glorifies binge drinking and promotes the idea that masculinity is linked to heavy alcohol consumption.  They contend this sets a poor example, especially given concerns about binge drinking.  Conversely, Health Minister Sussan Ley defended Abbott, emphasizing his fitness and hard work.  While Abbott isn't the first prime minister to engage in such behavior, Robert notes changing attitudes toward heavy drinking.  The incident prompted comments from Opposition Leader Bill Shorten.

Indiana is experiencing a significant HIV outbreak in Scott County, with 120 confirmed cases and 10 preliminary positive cases, a sharp increase from 106 cases the previous week.  Governor Pence approved a 30-day needle exchange program on March 26th in response, distributing 5,322 clean syringes and receiving 1,400 used ones.  The outbreak is primarily among intravenous drug users using Opana.  While the program's effectiveness is being evaluated,  the governor will decide whether to extend it beyond April 25th early next week.  Legislation to allow needle exchange programs in other Indiana counties is under consideration, but faces opposition due to concerns that such programs could promote drug use.  Federal funding for needle exchange programs is banned.

An Arsenal fan quizzed his girlfriend, Saskia, on his favorite football club.  Saskia scored 43.5 out of 50, earning an "A" and avoiding a breakup. The quiz included multiple choice, fill-in-the-blank, and short answer questions.  Saskia's answers, posted on Twitter, generated mixed reactions, with some praising her knowledge and others criticizing the boyfriend's actions.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former mid-level member of the Medellín cartel, spent 27 years working as a DEA informant after fleeing Colombia in the 1980s.  He was promised U.S. citizenship in exchange for his work, which aided in the prosecution of major figures like Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega.  Now retired and facing deportation, Toro lives in fear for his life and is seeking help to obtain a green card or passport.  The DEA has refused to assist him with his citizenship application.

A 14-year-old girl in India is hospitalized with 70% burns after setting herself on fire.  She had allegedly been gang-raped by five men from her village, and her family reportedly told her to remain silent. The accused have been arrested.  This incident follows other recent sexual assault cases in India, including the gang rape and murder of Jyoti Singh Pandey, which sparked widespread protests and a ban on a documentary about the case.  Another case involved the mob killing of a man accused of raping and murdering an 11-year-old girl.

Louis van Gaal says that Manchester United will play against Manchester City on Sunday without Robin van Persie and Luke Shaw due to their injuries.  Van Gaal dreams of beating City and securing a high position in the league, possibly third place.  He acknowledges that City will be a tough opponent but hopes his team has learned from their previous loss.  Van Gaal also praises Manchester United's fans for their support.

Arsenal and Liverpool fans protested against high ticket prices at the Emirates Stadium during their match.  For the first 10 minutes, a portion of fans from both teams left their seats empty.  Tickets started at £64, considered high, especially in light of the Premier League's £5.14 billion TV rights deal.  Fans displayed banners inside and outside the stadium expressing their discontent, such as "£5bn and what do we get? £64 a ticket".  Organizers called the prices "extortionate" and fear that rising costs will alienate working-class fans.  Further protests are anticipated after the game.

Star Reader, a newborn, was diagnosed with biliary atresia, a life-threatening liver condition causing blocked bile ducts.  After an unsuccessful operation to unblock her ducts, she needed a liver transplant. Her mother's twin sister, Shanell, donated part of her liver, saving Star's life. Star has since recovered well but requires ongoing medical care.

Chelsea players Eden Hazard and Nathan Ake competed against teammates Loic Remy and Willian in Audi's football challenge.  Hazard and Ake won the first two rounds, which included shooting balls into car boots and playing tennis over an Audi R8.  Remy and Willian won the final round, which involved long-range shots at Audis, but Willian broke a car's wing mirror during the challenge.

Robert Dellinger, a 54-year-old former Fortune 500 executive, was sentenced for a fatal car crash that killed Amanda Murphy (24) and Jason Timmons (29), along with their unborn baby.  Dellinger pleaded guilty to negligent homicide and assault.  He claims he wasn't suicidal, despite telling investigators he was trying to kill himself when he crossed the median at over 100 mph, causing the crash.  His defense cited medication withdrawal and health issues as contributing factors.  Dellinger faces 12–24 years in prison and a wrongful death lawsuit.

Lacey Spears was sentenced to 20 years to life for the salt poisoning death of her 5-year-old son, Garnett-Paul Spears.  The boy's father, Chris Hill, expressed anger on Facebook, hoping she would die in prison.  Prosecutors argued Spears poisoned her son for attention, while her lawyer claimed she was innocent and blamed the hospital.  The judge noted Spears' mental illness but called the crime "unfathomable in its cruelty".

Australia will receive an improved influenza vaccine in April, a month later than expected.  The vaccine protects against influenza A strain H3N2 and influenza B strain B/Phuket, strains that caused a spike in deaths in the U.S. and Europe due to a mismatch with the previous vaccine.  High-risk groups will receive free vaccines from April 20, but Dr. Hampson recommends everyone get vaccinated to protect themselves and high-risk individuals.  The vaccine also protects against influenza A strain H1N1.

On the 150th anniversary of Abraham Lincoln's assassination, the caretakers of his tomb are dealing with an unflattering critique in *National Geographic* and potential budget cuts.  The magazine described the tomb's interior as having "all the historical character of an office lobby," a view disputed by many.  Despite recent renovations costing over $2.5 million, Illinois's financial crisis and Governor Bruce Rauner's proposed elimination of the state historic preservation agency threaten the tomb's future.  Reduced hours and staffing have already resulted from previous budget cuts.  The tomb, designed by Larkin Mead and dedicated in 1874, has undergone several reconstructions due to initial foundation issues.

The return of JNCO jeans has sparked a discussion about 90s and 2000s fashion trends that should remain in the past.  Several trends are highlighted, including bucket hats (Rihanna), camouflage print (Jourdan Dunn), double denim (Kylie Jenner), Ugg boots (Kristen Bell), Daisy Dukes (Miley Cyrus), Juicy Couture tracksuits (Nicki Minaj), colored sunglasses (Cara Delevingne and Kylie Jenner), corsets as outfits (Selena Gomez), and harem pants (Elle Macpherson).  Each example cites a past celebrity who popularized the trend and a current celebrity who is continuing to wear it.

This week's trending news included: four rainbows appearing in the New York sky after heavy rain; a crackdown on exotic dancers performing at wakes in rural China; Robert Downey Jr.'s irritation at questions about his private life; the Kardashian-inspired lip plumping challenge; 102-year-old Alice Barker revisiting her past with the help of filmmakers; a promposal deemed inappropriate by a school; Ewan McGregor cast as Lumiere in "Beauty and the Beast"; Johnny Depp's new look in the "Black Mass" trailer; and creative pregnancy and photobomb announcements.

Serena Williams won her 700th career victory at the Miami Open, advancing to the semifinals with a win over Sabine Lisicki.  Andy Murray also celebrated his 500th match win at the tournament.  Williams will play Simona Halep in the semifinals.

Sabeen Mahmud, a Pakistani activist known for her outspoken views on human rights and women's issues, was shot and killed outside her Karachi cafe.  Mahmud, who hosted discussions on sensitive topics such as the situation in Balochistan, had received death threats in the past.  Her death has sparked widespread grief and condemnation, with many praising her bravery and commitment to free speech in a country where such expression can be dangerous.  No one has claimed responsibility for the attack.

Mangu Ram, an 82-year-old Hindu refugee from West Pakistan, has lived in Indian Kashmir for 70 years without citizenship rights, unable to own property or vote.  Around 100,000 West Pakistan refugees (WPRs) are in the same situation, living in poverty for generations due to a pre-independence law and successive governments' fears of upsetting the state's demographic balance.  However, with the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) gaining power in Kashmir, there is hope that the WPRs will finally receive full rights, though some activists threaten to take action if their hopes are dashed.

Yoshinori Muto, a forward for FC Tokyo, is considering Chelsea's offer of about £4 million.  Muto wants a club where he can play regularly and develop his potential.  Chelsea plans to loan him to Vitesse Arnhem.  His former manager, Ranko Popovic, believes Muto has amazing potential and is a unique player.  Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho is aware of Muto but says it's inappropriate to comment on players from other clubs, though he acknowledges that commercial interests influence Chelsea's transfer policy.

Australia’s decision to select players from overseas teams is a positive change, leaving England’s policy of not selecting players who play abroad outdated.  England’s coach, Stuart Lancaster, should be able to choose the best players regardless of where they play, as the World Cup should feature the world’s best players.  Many players, like Jonny Wilkinson, have improved their game while playing overseas.  The policy hurts England’s chances of winning the World Cup and the players’ confidence.  The Rugby Football Union (RFU) and Premier Rugby should not dictate player selection.

Firechat, an app with over 5 million downloads, allows users to communicate without needing a mobile signal or web connection by using a wireless mesh network.  The app uses Apple’s Multipeer Connectivity Framework (MCF) or a similar Android feature to create a localized network where phones act as nodes, passing data between each other.  Messages are sent securely and anonymously using usernames. While messages can travel up to 200 feet, the range is limited.  Greenstone, a new device, aims to extend this range by acting as a booster for these networks.  It is currently under development and works with Firechat within a 20-foot radius.  Greenstone has a one-year battery life and can store up to 1,000 messages.

Lillian Bustle, a burlesque performer, gave a TED Talk about her positive experience embracing the word "fat" to describe her body.  She argues that "fat" is simply a descriptor, not a synonym for "ugly," and that societal negativity surrounding the word is harmful.  Bustle notes that size discrimination in the workplace has risen 66 percent in the past 30 years and that many young girls wish to be thinner. However, studies show increased exposure to body diversity leads to greater tolerance and acceptance of different body types.  Bustle's burlesque performances help promote this body positivity, and her TED Talk, which has received overwhelmingly positive feedback, has similarly inspired many.

Theo Walcott, along with six Arsenal colleagues—Calum Chambers, Jack Wilshere, Mikel Arteta, David Ospina, Mathieu Flamini, and Mesut Ozil—participated in a photoshoot for Lanvin, Arsenal's official tailor.  Walcott has been on the bench for most of the season, appearing in only six minutes of the recent 0-0 draw with Chelsea.  He hopes to start in the upcoming match against Hull.  The Arsenal team will wear similar attire at the FA Cup final.

On May 29th, 2024, an auction will be held at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles and online at Propstore.com, featuring over 400 props and puppets from the collection of make-up effects artist Rick Baker.  The collection, from Baker's Cinovation studio, includes items from films such as *Men in Black*, *Batman Forever*, *How the Grinch Stole Christmas*, *An American Werewolf in London*, *Planet of the Apes*, *Batman & Robin*, *Hellboy*, *Mighty Joe Young*, *Gremlins 2: The New Batch*, and Michael Jackson's *Moonwalker*.  Individual items are expected to sell for between $1,500 and $40,000+, with the total collection valued at $746,100.

Seven-year-old Carwyn Scott-Howell, a British boy, died in a skiing accident in the French Alps.  While skiing with his family, he became separated from his mother and fell 164 feet in dense woodland. His body was found by police following his footprints in the snow.  The family described Carwyn as a daring, outgoing, and determined boy who loved skiing and snowboarding. They were on their last run of a happy ski holiday when the accident occurred.  His family is devastated by his death.

15-year-old Laura Scurr, from Whitley Bay, developed anorexia after becoming obsessed with being thin.  Her obsession led her to eat as little as one piece of fruit a day, hide food, and lie to her mother.  She collapsed from starvation and spent a week in intensive care on a heart monitor.  After recovering with the help of eating disorder organizations, she is now a semi-finalist in Miss Teen GB.  Laura attributes her anorexia to societal pressure on girls to be a size zero, as well as some bullying she experienced.

Liverpool fans voiced their desire for Raheem Sterling to stay with the team at a new kit launch.  The new kit, designed by New Balance in a record-breaking £300 million deal, was unveiled at Anfield.  Sterling, along with other players, participated in the launch, and while he recently rejected a £100,000-a-week contract offer and expressed interest in other teams, Liverpool maintains he will remain with the club.  The event also included discussion of the upcoming FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa.

Researchers at the University of Manchester have created the largest-ever high-definition map of dark matter, showing clumps of the mysterious particles across 0.4 percent of the sky.  The map, part of the Dark Energy Survey (DES), uses data from the Dark Energy Camera and the Victor M. Blanco telescope to study the gravitational effects of dark matter on galaxies.  The goal is to eventually map 12.5 percent of the sky over five years, creating a 3D view to better understand galaxy formation and dark energy.  The map's creation involved analyzing 130 million telescope images and required significant computing power.

Manchester United made an official offer for 21-year-old PSV Eindhoven and Netherlands star Memphis Depay.  PSV confirmed the approach, noting that manager Louis van Gaal, who previously coached Depay during the 2014 World Cup, is interested in signing him.  Depay, who scored 20 goals in 26 league games this season, is also attracting interest from Paris-Saint Germain and another unnamed European club.  While Tottenham Hotspur made a £15 million bid last summer, PSV expects a higher offer this time.  Depay's former scout, Ed van Steijn, believes Depay is better than Cristiano Ronaldo was at the same age.  PSV manager Phillip Cocu compares Depay to Arjen Robben.

Chelsea's young team defeated Manchester City's youth team with a final score of 3-1.  Tammy Abraham scored two goals, and Dominic Solanke added another.  Several players from both teams are highlighted for their performance, including strong showings from Chelsea's Abraham and Solanke, and City's Adarabioyo and Barker.  Despite some strong performances from City players, Chelsea ultimately dominated the match.

Marco Rubio, a presidential candidate, believes people are born with a sexual preference but that the definition of marriage should be decided by state legislatures, not courts.  He doesn't believe same-sex marriage is a constitutional right, but he would attend the same-sex wedding of a loved one.  Rubio has already secured significant financial backing for his presidential campaign.

Pablo Mandado, 27, and Ilze Zebolde, 31, are cycling the world on a budget of less than 3 euros per day.  In 356 days, they have covered almost 7,000 miles through 16 countries, relying on free accommodations like camping, Couchsurfing, and Warmshowers.  Their expenses are primarily food (2.74 euros/day), and they supplement this with dumpster diving and the generosity of strangers.  They started in London and have cycled through Europe, recently crossing into Asia with plans to continue across the Pacific and the Americas.

A Texas couple's 2012 wedding photos contained a racial slur printed at the bottom.  The couple sued James Evans, owner of Premiere Photos, alleging negligence and breach of contract. Evans denies the allegations and the couple's claim of mental anguish.  The bride's sister delayed informing the couple to avoid ruining their wedding day.  Mediation is scheduled, with a trial set for July if an agreement isn't reached.  The couple's attorney states they primarily seek an apology, not monetary compensation.

Mike Brown, an England fullback, will adopt a cautious approach to recovering from his concussion.  He is unsure when he will return to play after pulling out of a recent match.  His caution is driven by increased awareness of concussion symptoms from World Rugby online modules, and he advises other players to prioritize their health over playing through symptoms.  George North will not play this season after suffering four concussions.  Johnny Sexton was sidelined for twelve weeks due to concussion.

A leading expert suggests that the decline in the frequency of sexual intercourse among couples may be attributed to smartphone use.  Research indicates that Britons are having sex less often than in the past; a typical heterosexual couple now has sex three times a month, compared to four times in 2000 and five times in 1990.  This decline is linked to increased connectivity and the blurring of boundaries between work and personal life, leaving less time for intimacy.  One researcher states that competing demands on time cause sex to become a lower priority, with late-night work emails contributing to a lack of focus on partners at bedtime.

The popularity of Tibetan Mastiffs in China has plummeted.  Once fetching prices up to £1.2 million, they are now being sent to slaughterhouses due to China's anti-corruption campaign (which reduced gifting of the dogs to officials) and bans on dogs over 50kg in major cities.  A glut of poor-quality dogs from unscrupulous breeders also contributed to the collapse of the market.  Animal welfare workers have rescued mastiffs from transport to slaughterhouses where their meat is used in hot pot and their skin for leather.  The breed's unsuitability for city life also impacted its popularity.

A survey of 600 women in the Paris area found that every woman polled had experienced some form of sexual harassment on public transportation, with half experiencing it before age 18.  The harassment ranged from insults and intimidation to rape.  Six out of ten women were afraid of being attacked on public transport because of this.  The report, given to the French women’s rights ministry, stated that this limits women’s freedom, forcing them to change their routines to avoid harassment.  The results led to calls for a campaign to address sexist and threatening behavior on public transportation.

Direct Line, a Leeds-based company, held a competition called #EverydayFix, asking groups to design products to solve common problems.  The top three designs were: Snooze, an alarm clock that silences phone notifications for better sleep; Forget-Me-Lock, a device that indicates whether a door is locked; and Nipper, a small mobile phone charger powered by household batteries.  The winning design, chosen by Twitter retweets with the #EverydayFix hashtag by April 4th, will be funded through Kickstarter.  Other designs that did not make the final shortlist included a parking pin that alerts you to available parking spaces, a helmet with bone conduction headphones for cyclists, and an app that forwards messages when a phone dies.

Vera Baird, the Police and Crime Commissioner for Northumbria, and Chief Constable Sue Sim are under investigation by the Ministry of Justice.  Baird allocated over £500,000 of public funds to Victims First Northumbria, a charity for which she is a director and Sim is also a director.  Critics cite a conflict of interest, calling the situation a "soap opera," and question the Home Secretary's decision to allow PCCs to allocate funds to charities.  Baird maintains that all procedures were followed, while Sim is retiring in June.

Corry "Corey" Campbell, 21, led a gang known as the "tattoo terrorists" in the torture of Greg Valecce, 53.  Campbell believed Valecce hurt his cat.  Over three days, Valecce was beaten, tied to a chair, and given offensive tattoos by Campbell, Carl Halin, 18, and Sandra Ng, 19.  Valecce suffered multiple injuries and has since had the tattoos removed.  Campbell was sentenced to 20 years, Halin to 20 years, and Ng to 23 months.  David Thomas, 28, awaits sentencing, and Jennifer Pratt, 40, awaits trial.

Manchester United made an official offer for 21-year-old PSV Eindhoven and Netherlands star Memphis Depay.  PSV confirmed the approach, noting that manager Louis van Gaal, who previously coached Depay during the 2014 World Cup, is interested in signing him.  Depay, who scored 20 goals in 26 league games this season, is also attracting interest from Paris-Saint Germain and another unnamed European club.  While Tottenham Hotspur made a £15 million bid last summer, PSV expects a higher offer this time.  Depay's former scout believes he is better than Cristiano Ronaldo was at the same age.  PSV manager Phillip Cocu believes Depay could be as good as Arjen Robben.
