Rubio has already secured significant financial backing for his presidential campaign.

Pablo Mandado, 27, and Ilze Zebolde, 31, are cycling the world on a budget of less than 3 euros per day.  In 356 days, they have covered almost 7,000 miles through 16 countries, relying on free accommodations like camping, Couchsurfing, and Warmshowers.  Their expenses are primarily food (2.74 euros/day), and they supplement this with dumpster diving and the generosity of strangers.  They started in London and have cycled through Europe, recently crossing into Asia with plans to continue across the Pacific and the Americas.

A Texas couple's 2012 wedding photos contained a racial slur printed at the bottom.  The couple sued James Evans, owner of Premiere Photos, alleging negligence and breach of contract. Evans denies the allegations and the couple's claim of mental anguish.  The bride's sister delayed informing the couple to avoid ruining their wedding day.  Mediation is scheduled, with a trial set for July if an agreement isn't reached.  The couple's attorney states they primarily seek an apology, not monetary compensation.

Mike Brown, an England fullback, will adopt a cautious approach to recovering from his concussion.  He is unsure when he will return to play after pulling out of a recent match.  His caution is driven by increased awareness of concussion symptoms from World Rugby online modules, and he advises other players to prioritize their health over playing through symptoms.  George North will not play this season after suffering four concussions.  Johnny Sexton was sidelined for twelve weeks due to concussion.

A leading expert suggests that the decline in the frequency of sexual intercourse among couples may be attributed to smartphone use.  Research indicates that Britons are having sex less often than in the past; a typical heterosexual couple now has sex three times a month, compared to four times in 2000 and five times in 1990.  This decline is linked to increased connectivity and the blurring of boundaries between work and personal life, leaving less time for intimacy.  One researcher states that competing demands on time cause sex to become a lower priority, with late-night work emails contributing to a lack of focus on partners at bedtime.

The popularity of Tibetan Mastiffs in China has plummeted.  Once fetching prices up to £1.2 million, they are now being sent to slaughterhouses due to China's anti-corruption campaign (which reduced gifting of the dogs to officials) and bans on dogs over 50kg in major cities.  A glut of poor-quality dogs from unscrupulous breeders also contributed to the collapse of the market.  Animal welfare workers have rescued mastiffs from transport to slaughterhouses where their meat is used in hot pot and their skin for leather.  The breed's unsuitability for city life also impacted its popularity.

A survey of 600 women in the Paris area found that every woman polled had experienced some form of sexual harassment on public transportation, with half experiencing it before age 18.  The harassment ranged from insults and intimidation to rape.  Six out of ten women were afraid of being attacked on public transport because of this.  The report, given to the French women’s rights ministry, stated that this limits women’s freedom, forcing them to change their routines to avoid harassment.  The results led to calls for a campaign to address sexist and threatening behavior on public transportation.

Direct Line, a Leeds-based company, held a competition called #EverydayFix, asking groups to design products to solve common problems.  The top three designs were: Snooze, an alarm clock that silences phone notifications for better sleep; Forget-Me-Lock, a device that indicates whether a door is locked; and Nipper, a small mobile phone charger powered by household batteries.  The winning design, chosen by Twitter retweets with the #EverydayFix hashtag by April 4th, will be funded through Kickstarter.  Other designs that did not make the final shortlist included a parking pin that alerts you to available parking spaces, a helmet with bone conduction headphones for cyclists, and an app that forwards messages when a phone dies.

Vera Baird, the Police and Crime Commissioner for Northumbria, and Chief Constable Sue Sim are under investigation by the Ministry of Justice.  Baird allocated over £500,000 of public funds to Victims First Northumbria, a charity for which she is a director and Sim is also a director.  Critics cite a conflict of interest, calling the situation a "soap opera," and question the Home Secretary's decision to allow PCCs to allocate funds to charities.  Baird maintains that all procedures were followed, while Sim is retiring in June.

Corry "Corey" Campbell, 21, led a gang known as the "tattoo terrorists" in the torture of Greg Valecce, 53.  Campbell believed Valecce hurt his cat.  Over three days, Valecce was beaten, tied to a chair, and given offensive tattoos by Campbell, Carl Halin, 18, and Sandra Ng, 19.  Valecce suffered multiple injuries and has since had the tattoos removed.  Campbell was sentenced to 20 years, Halin to 20 years, and Ng to 23 months.  David Thomas, 28, awaits sentencing, and Jennifer Pratt, 40, awaits trial.

Manchester United made an official offer for 21-year-old PSV Eindhoven and Netherlands star Memphis Depay.  PSV confirmed the approach, noting that manager Louis van Gaal, who previously coached Depay during the 2014 World Cup, is interested in signing him.  Depay, who scored 20 goals in 26 league games this season, is also attracting interest from Paris-Saint Germain and another unnamed European club.  While Tottenham Hotspur made a £15 million bid last summer, PSV expects a higher offer this time.  Depay's former scout believes he is better than Cristiano Ronaldo was at the same age.  PSV manager Phillip Cocu believes Depay could be as good as Arjen Robben.

Chelsea's young team defeated Manchester City's youth team with a final score of 3-1.  Tammy Abraham scored two goals, and Dominic Solanke added another.  Several players from both teams are highlighted for their performance, including strong showings from Chelsea's Abraham and Solanke, and City's Adarabioyo and Barker.  Despite some strong performances from City players, Chelsea ultimately dominated the match.

He doesn't believe same-sex marriage is a constitutional right, but he would attend the same-sex wedding of a loved one.  Rubio has already secured significant financial backing for his presidential campaign.

They rely on free accommodation (camping, Couchsurfing, and Warmshowers), and their only major expense is food (€2.74 per day).  They started in London and have cycled through Europe, recently crossing into Asia (Turkey, Georgia, and Armenia), with plans to continue across Asia, the Pacific, and the Americas.

The top three prototypes, chosen from a shortlist based on a survey of 2,000 people, are: Snooze (an alarm clock that silences phone notifications), Forget-Me-Lock (a device that indicates if a door is locked), and Nipper (a small mobile phone charger).  The winning product, determined by a Twitter retweet competition using the #EverydayFix hashtag by April 4th, will be funded through Kickstarter.  Other ideas that did not make the final cut included a parking pin, a messaging app for when phones die, and a helmet with bone conduction headphones for cyclists.

The 2009 convention included over 512 guests and performers, with notable attendees including Patrick Stewart, William Shatner, Leonard Nimoy, Terry Gilliam, Bruce Boxleitner, James Marsters, and Mary McDonnell.

The 2009 convention included over 6000 guests and performers, with notable attendees including Patrick Stewart, William Shatner, Leonard Nimoy, Terry Gilliam, Bruce Boxleitner, James Marsters, and Mary McDonnell.
Over 180 countries and 200 territories have reported more than  COVID-19 cases, resulting in more than  deaths.
Over 190 countries and 200 territories reported more than  COVID-19 cases and more than deaths.

As of March 12th, Italy had the world's highest per capita rate of positive coronavirus cases (206.1 per million people) among nations with at least one million citizens—3.6 times higher than China's rate.  Italy also had the second-highest number of positive cases and deaths globally, after China.

As of March 12th, Italy had the highest per capita rate of positive coronavirus cases globally (206.1 per million), exceeding the number of confirmed cases in mainland China (excluding Hubei province).
